Calgary]] [[Category:Art festivals in Canada]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Carter Page |image = Carter Page MSNBC June 2017 YouTube.png |birth_name = Carter William Page |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1971|06|03}} |birth_place = [[Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |education = [[United States Naval Academy]] ([[Bachelor of Science|BS]])
[[Georgetown University]] ([[Master of Arts|MA]])
[[New York University]] ([[Master of Business Administration|MBA]])
[[SOAS, University of London]] ([[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]]) |occupation = Investment banker
[[Foreign policy]] analyst |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |allegiance = {{Flagu|United States|1960}} |branch = {{flag|United States Navy}} |serviceyears = 1993–98 (Navy)
1998–2004 ([[United States Navy Reserve#Individual Ready Reserve|Navy Reserve]]) |rank = [[File:US Navy O3 infobox.svg|25px]] [[Lieutenant (navy)|Lieutenant]] |mawards = }} '''Carter William Page''' (born June 3, 1971) is an American [[petroleum industry]] consultant and a former foreign-policy adviser to [[Donald Trump]] during his [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|2016 Presidential election campaign]].{{cite news|last1=Rogin|first1=Josh|title=Trump's Russia adviser speaks out, calls accusations 'complete garbage'|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/josh-rogin/wp/2016/09/26/trumps-russia-adviser-speaks-out-calls-accusations-complete-garbage/ |work=The Washington Post |date=September 26, 2016 |access-date=September 29, 2016}} Page is the founder and managing partner of Global Energy Capital, a one-man investment fund and consulting firm specializing in the Russian and Central Asian oil and gas business.{{cite news|last1=Ioffe|first1=Julia|authorlink1=Julia Ioffe|title=Who Is Carter Page?|url=http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/09/the-mystery-of-trumps-man-in-moscow-214283 |work=Politico |date=September 23, 2016 |access-date=September 24, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160924010026/http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/09/the-mystery-of-trumps-man-in-moscow-214283|archive-date=September 24, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Isikoff|first1=Michael|title=U.S. intel officials probe ties between Trump adviser and Kremlin|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/u-s-intel-officials-probe-ties-between-trump-adviser-and-kremlin-175046002.html |publisher=Yahoo! News |date=September 23, 2016 |access-date=September 24, 2016}} He has been a focus of the [[Special Counsel investigation (2017–present)|2017 Special Counsel investigation]] into [[links between Trump associates and Russian officials]] and [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections|Russian interference on behalf of Trump during the 2016 Presidential election]].{{cite news | work = New York Times | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/18/magazine/what-if-anything-does-carter-page-know.html | date = December 18, 2017 | title = What (if Anything) Does Carter Page Know? | first = Jason | last = Zengerle}} ==Life and career== Carter Page was born in [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]], on June 3, 1971,{{cite web |url=https://www.ancestry.com |title=Carter William Page in the Minnesota Birth Index, 1935–2002 |date=June 3, 1971 |publisher=Ancestry.com |subscription=yes}} the son of Allan Robert Page and Rachel (Greenstein) Page.{{cite news |last=Howland |first=Jack |date=March 3, 2017 |title=Page, Poughkeepsie Native, Linked to Trump-Russia |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/local/2017/03/03/page-poughkeepsie-native-linked-trump-russia/98704982/ |work=Poughkeepsie Journal |location=Poughkeepsie, N.Y.}}{{cite web |url=https://www.ancestry.com |title=Minnesota, Marriage Index, 1958–2001 |date=June 20, 1970 |publisher=Ancestry.com |subscription=yes}} His father was from [[Galway, New York]], and his mother was from Minneapolis.{{cite news |date=March 28, 1970 |title=Hennepin County Marriage License Applications, Allan R. Page and Rachel Greenstein |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/185133377/ |work=Minneapolis Star Tribune |location=Minneapolis, MN |page=18 |subscription=yes}} His father was a manager and executive with the [[Central Hudson Energy Group|Central Hudson Gas & Electric Company]].{{cite news |date=August 2, 1984 |title=2 Workers Promoted at Central Hudson |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/114966137/ |work=Poughkeepsie Journal |location=Poughkeepsie, N.Y. |page=22 |subscription=yes}} Page was raised in [[Poughkeepsie, New York]], and graduated from Poughkeepsie's [[Our Lady of Lourdes High School]] in 1989. Page graduated with a [[Bachelor of Science|BS]] degree from the [[United States Naval Academy]] in 1993; he graduated with distinction (top 10% of his class) and was chosen for the Navy's Trident Scholar program, which gives selected officers the opportunity for independent academic research and study.{{cite news |last=Gidda |first=Mirren |date=April 12, 2017 |title=Who is Carter Page and Why is the FBI Surveilling Him? |url=http://www.newsweek.com/carter-page-fbi-surveillance-us-presidential-election-russia-donald-trump-583066 |work=Newsweek |location=New York}}{{cite news | last = Mufson |first=Steven |author2=Tom Hamburger| date=July 8, 2016 | title=Trump Adviser's Public Comments, Ties to Moscow Stir Unease in Both Parties | newspaper = [[The Washington Post]] | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/trump-advisers-public-comments-ties-to-moscow-stir-unease-in-both-parties/2016/08/05/2e8722fa-5815-11e6-9aee-8075993d73a2_story.html | access-date=September 24, 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.dtic.mil/dtic/tr/fulltext/u2/a271110.pdf |title="Balancing Congressional Needs for Classified Information: A Case Study of the Strategic Defense Initiative" |last=Page |first=Carter W. |date=May 17, 1993 |publisher=Defense Technical Information Center |location=Ft. Belvoir, Va.}} During his senior year at the Naval Academy, he worked in the office of [[Les Aspin]] as a researcher for the [[United States House Committee on Armed Services|House Armed Services Committee]].{{cite news |last=Hall |first=Kevin G. |date=April 14, 2017 |title=Why did FBI suspect Trump campaign adviser was a foreign agent? |url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/politics-government/white-house/article144722444.html |publisher=McClatchy DC Bureau |location=Washington, D.C.}} He served in the [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] for five years, including a tour in western [[Morocco]] as an [[intelligence officer]] for a [[United Nations peacekeeping]] mission, and attained the rank of [[Lieutenant (navy)|lieutenant]].{{cite news |last1=Dilanian |first1=Ken |last2=Memoli |first2=Mike |date=February 5, 2018 |title=Who is Carter Page and what does he have to do with the Russia probe? |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/who-carter-page-what-does-he-have-do-russia-probe-n844821 |work=NBC News |location=New York, NY}} In 1994, he completed an [[Master of Arts|MA]] degree in National Security Studies at [[Georgetown University]]. After leaving active duty in 1998, Page was a member of the Navy's [[United States Navy Reserve|inactive reserve]] until 2004. ===Education and business=== After leaving the Navy, Page completed a fellowship at the [[Council on Foreign Relations]], and in 2001 he received an [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] degree from [[New York University]].{{cite news |last=Lucas |first=Ryan |date=November 7, 2017 |title=Carter Page Tells House Intel Panel He Spoke To Sessions About Russia Contacts |url=https://www.npr.org/2017/11/07/562537269/inquiry-widens-following-disclosure-of-trump-aides-told-about-russia-contacts |page=Transcript, page 41 |work=NPR.org |location=Washington, D.C.}} In 2000, he began work as an investment banker with [[Merrill Lynch]] in the firm's [[London]] office, was a vice president in the company's Moscow office, and later served as [[Chief operating officer|COO]] for Merrill Lynch's energy and power department in New York. Page has stated that he worked on transactions involving [[Gazprom]] and other leading Russian energy companies. According to business people interviewed by ''[[Politico]]'' in 2016, Page's work in Moscow was at a subordinate level, and he himself remained largely unknown to decision-makers. After leaving Merrill Lynch in 2008, Page founded his own investment fund, Global Energy Capital, with partner James Richard and a former midlevel Gazprom executive, Sergei Yatsenko.{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=58104064 |title=Capital Markets: Company Overview of Global Energy Capital LLC |date=2017 |publisher=Bloomberg News |location=New York}} The fund operates out of a Manhattan [[Coworking|co-working space]] shared with a booking agency for wedding bands, and as of late 2017, Page was the firm's sole employee. Other businesspeople working in the Russian energy sector said in 2016 that the fund had yet to actually realize a project. Page received a [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] degree from [[SOAS, University of London]] in 2012, where he was supervised by [[Shirin Akiner]]. His doctoral dissertation on the transition of Asian countries from communism to capitalism was rejected twice before ultimately being accepted by new examiners.{{cite news |last=Sabur |first=Rozina |date=December 22, 2017 |title=Carter Page, Donald Trump's former adviser, blamed British academics after two failed PhD attempts |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/12/22/carter-page-donald-trumps-former-adviser-blamed-british-academics/ |work=The Telegraph |location=London, UK}} One of his original examiners later said Page "knew next to nothing" about the subject matter and was unfamiliar with "basic concepts" such as [[Marxism]] and [[state capitalism]].{{cite news |last=Harding|first=Luke |date=December 22, 2017 |title=Ex-Trump adviser Carter Page accused academics who twice failed his PhD of bias |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/dec/22/trump-carter-page-phd-thesis-trump |work=The Guardian |location=London}} He sought unsuccessfully to publish his dissertation as a book; a reviewer described it as "very analytically confused, just throwing a lot of stuff out there without any real kind of argument." Page blamed the rejection on anti-Russian and anti-American bias. He later ran an [[International relations|international affairs]] program at [[Bard College]] and taught a course on energy and politics at [[New York University]].{{cite news |last=Scott |first=Shane |date=April 19, 2017 |title= Trump Adviser's Visit to Moscow Got the F.B.I.'s Attention |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/19/us/politics/carter-page-russia-trump.html |work=The New York Times |location=New York, NY}} In more recent years, he has written columns in ''Global Policy Journal'', a publication of [[Durham University]]. ===Foreign policy and ties to Russia=== In 1998, Page joined the [[Eurasia Group]], a strategy consulting firm, but left three months later. In 2017, Eurasia Group president [[Ian Bremmer]] recalled on his [[Twitter]] feed that Page's strong pro-Russian stance was "not a good fit" for the firm and that Page was its "most wackadoodle" alumnus.{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/apr/14/carter-page-trump-adviser-pro-kremlin-views-1998-consulting-russia-ties |title=Former Trump adviser Carter Page held 'strong pro-Kremlin views', says ex-boss |author=Stephanie Kirchgaessner |author2=Spencer Ackerman |author3=Julian Borger |author4=Luke Harding |date=April 14, 2017 |work=The Guardian |access-date=2017-04-14}} [[Stephen Sestanovich]] later described Page's foreign-policy views as having "an edgy Putinist resentment" and a sympathy to Russian leader [[Vladimir Putin]]'s criticisms of the United States. Over time, Page became increasingly critical of United States foreign policy toward Russia, and more supportive of Putin, with a United States official describing Page as "a brazen apologist for anything Moscow did". Page is frequently quoted by [[Television in Russia|Russian state television]], where he is presented as a "famous American economist". In August 2013, Page wrote, "Over the past half year, I have had the privilege to serve as an informal advisor to the staff of the Kremlin in preparation for their Presidency of the G-20 Summit next month, where energy issues will be a prominent point on the agenda."{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/5132126/carter-page-russia-2013-letter/|title=Carter Page Touted Kremlin Contacts in 2013 Letter|website=Time|language=en|access-date=2018-07-23}} Page described his role differently in 2018: "I sat in on some meetings, but to call me an advisor is way over the top."{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/07/22/politics/donald-trump-fisa-tweet/index.html|title=Carter Page says FISA warrant accusations 'so ridiculous' and 'misleading'|last=Tatum|first=Sophie|date=|work=CNN|access-date=2018-07-23}} Also in 2013, [[Evgeny Buryakov|Russian intelligence operatives]] attempted to recruit Page, and one of them, Victor Podobnyy, described Page as enthusiastic about business opportunities in Russia but an "idiot".{{cite news | work = New York Times | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/04/us/politics/carter-page-trump-russia.html | title = Russian Spies Tried to Recruit Carter Page Before He Advised Trump | date = April 4, 2017 | first = Adam | last = Goldman}} "I also promised him a lot," Podobnyy reported to a fellow Russian intelligence officer at the time, according to an FBI transcript of their conversation, which was covertly recorded. "How else to work with foreigners?"{{Cite news|url=https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/alimwatkins/a-former-trump-adviser-met-with-a-russian-spy#.qwGOegqoqd|title=A Former Trump Adviser Met With A Russian Spy|last=Watkins|first=Ali|date=April 3, 2017|work=Buzzfeed News|access-date=September 22, 2018}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/opa/press-releases/attachments/2015/01/26/buryakov-complaint.pdf|title=Sealed complaint, United States v. Evgeny Buryakov, Igor Sporyshev, and Victor Podobnyy|last=Monaghan|first=Gregory|date=January 23, 2015|website=US Department of Justice|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 22, 2018}} News accounts in 2017 indicated that because of these ties to Russia, Page had been the subject of a warrant pursuant to the [[Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act]] (FISA) in 2014, at least two years earlier than was indicated in the stories concerning his role in the [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|2016 Presidential campaign]] of [[Donald Trump]].{{cite news |last=Phillips |first=Ariella |date=August 3, 2017 |title=Former Trump adviser Carter Page under FISA warrant since 2014: Report |url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/former-trump-adviser-carter-page-under-fisa-warrant-since-2014-report/article/2630576 |work=[[The Washington Examiner]] |location=Washington, D.C.}}{{cite news |last1=Perez |first1=Evan |last2=Brown |first2=Pamela |last3= Prokupecz |first3=Shimon |date=August 4, 2017 |title=One year into the FBI's Russia investigation, Mueller is on the Trump money trail |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/08/03/politics/mueller-investigation-russia-trump-one-year-financial-ties/index.html?CNNPolitics=Tw |work=CNN.com |location=Atlanta, GA}} ===Trump 2016 presidential campaign=== Trump announced Page as a foreign policy adviser in his campaign on March 21, 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-partisan/wp/2016/03/21/a-transcript-of-donald-trumps-meeting-with-the-washington-post-editorial-board/|title=Opinion - A transcript of Donald Trump’s meeting with The Washington Post editorial board|website=Washington Post|accessdate=July 24, 2018}} In September 2016, U.S. intelligence officials investigated [[Links between Trump associates and Russian officials|alleged contacts between Page and Russian officials subject to U.S. sanctions]], including [[Igor Sechin]], the president of state-run Russian oil conglomerate [[Rosneft]]. After news reports began to appear describing Page's links to Russia and Putin's government, Page stepped down from his role in the Trump campaign.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/19/us/politics/carter-page-russia-trump.html|title=Trump Adviser’s Visit to Moscow Got the F.B.I.'s Attention|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=April 19, 2017|first1=Scott|last1=Shane|first2=Mark|last2=Mazzetti|first3=Adam|last3=Goldman |author3link=Adam Goldman}} Upon his departure, Trump campaign communications director [[Jason Miller (communications strategist)|Jason Miller]] said of Page, "He’s never been a part of our campaign. Period."{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/297599-trump-campaign-backs-away-from-adviser-suspected-of-ties-to-kremlin|title=Trump camp backs away from adviser suspected of Kremlin ties|first=Harper|last=Neidig|date=September 24, 2016|publisher=|accessdate=July 24, 2018}} Shortly after Page resigned from the Trump campaign, the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] obtained another warrant (he was subject to one beginning in 2014) from the [[United States Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court]] (FISC) in October 2016 to surveil Page's communications.{{cite news|first1=Matthew|last1=Rosenberg|authorlink1=Matthew Rosenberg|first2=Matt|last2=Apuzzo|authorlink2=Matt Apuzzo|title=Court Approved Wiretap on Trump Campaign Aide Over Russia Ties|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/12/us/politics/carter-page-fisa-warrant-russia-trump.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=13 April 2017 |page=A13 |access-date=13 April 2017}} To issue the warrant, a federal judge concluded there was [[probable cause]] to believe that Page was a [[foreign agent]] knowingly engaging in clandestine intelligence for the Russian government.{{cite magazine |last1=Beckwith |first1=Ryan Teague |last2=Abramson |first2=Alana |date=February 1, 2018 |title=Who Is Carter Page? Meet the Donald Trump Advisor at the Center of the GOP Memo |url=http://time.com/5128614/carter-page-gop-memo-fisa-warrant/ |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |location=New York, NY |publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]] |access-date=2018-02-08}} The initial 90-day warrant was subsequently renewed more than once.{{cite news|last1=Nakashima|first1=Ellen|last2=Barrett|first2=Devlin|last3=Entous|first3=Adam|title=FBI obtained FISA warrant to monitor Trump adviser Carter Page|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/fbi-obtained-fisa-warrant-to-monitor-former-trump-adviser-carter-page/2017/04/11/620192ea-1e0e-11e7-ad74-3a742a6e93a7_story.html|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=April 12, 2017|page=A1}} ''The New York Times'' reported on May 18, 2018 that the surveillance warrant expired around October 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/18/us/politics/trump-fbi-informant-russia-investigation.html|title=F.B.I. Used Informant to Investigate Russia Ties to Campaign, Not to Spy, as Trump Claims|date=May 18, 2018|publisher=|accessdate=May 20, 2018|via=NYTimes.com}} In January 2017, Page's name appeared repeatedly in the [[Trump–Russia dossier|"Trump–Russia / Steele dossier"]] containing [[Trump–Russia dossier#Allegations|allegations of close interactions]] between the Trump campaign and the Kremlin.{{cite news|last1=Sengupta|first1=Kim|title=US Senate calls on British spy Christopher Steele to give evidence on explosive Trump-Russia dossier|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/donald-trump-russia-christopher-steele-dossier-us-senate-intelligence-hotel-british-spy-mi6-evidence-a7608456.html |date=2 March 2017 |access-date=6 March 2017}}{{cite web | last = Bensinger| first=Ken|author2=[[Miriam Elder]] | author3=[[Mark Schoofs]] | authorlink1= | date = January 10, 2017 | title = These Reports Allege Trump Has Deep Ties To Russia | publisher = [[BuzzFeed]] News | location = New York | url = https://www.buzzfeed.com/kenbensinger/these-reports-allege-trump-has-deep-ties-to-russia | access-date = January 12, 2017}} See also the attached full transcript of [https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/3259984-Trump-Intelligence-Allegations.html#document/p1 the dossier].First major new report, from Bernstein, et al., at CNN: {{cite news | author1 = Evan Perez|author2=Jim Sciutto|author3=[[Jake Tapper]] |author4=[[Carl Bernstein]] | date = January 10, 2017 | title = Intel Chiefs Presented Trump with Claims of Russian Efforts to Compromise Him | publisher = [[CNN]] | url = https://www.cnn.com/2017/01/10/politics/donald-trump-intelligence-report-russia/index.html | access-date = January 12, 2017}}Editorial regarding the journalist issues raise by the published leak and subsequent story: {{cite news | author = Wemple, Erik | date = January 10, 2017 | title = BuzzFeed's Ridiculous Rationale For Publishing the Trump-Russia Dossier | newspaper = [[The Washington Post]] News | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/erik-wemple/wp/2017/01/10/buzzfeeds-ridiculous-rationale-for-publishing-the-trump-russia-dossier/ | access-date = January 12, 2017}} By the end of January 2017, Page was under investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the [[Central Intelligence Agency]], the [[National Security Agency]], the [[Director of National Intelligence]], and the [[Financial Crimes Enforcement Network]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/19/us/politics/trump-russia-associates-investigation.html|title=Intercepted Russian Communications Part of Inquiry Into Trump Associates|last1=Schmidt|first1=Michael S.|authorlink1=Michael S. Schmidt|first2=Matthew|last2=Rosenberg|authorlink2=Matthew Rosenberg|first3=Adam|last3=Goldman|authorlink3=Adam Goldman|first4=Matt|last4=Apuzzo|authorlink4=Matt Apuzzo|date=2017-01-19| newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2017-01-20}} Page was not accused of any wrongdoing.{{cite news |last1= Ballhaus |first1=Rebecca |last2=Tau |first2=Byron |title=Former Trump Aide Carter Page Was on U.S. Counterintelligence Radar Before Russia Dossier |newspaper=Wall Street Journal |date=February 2, 2018 |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/former-trump-aide-carter-page-was-on-u-s-counterintelligence-radar-before-russia-dossier-1517486401 |quote=Court documents, testimony show foreign-policy adviser was known to authorities as early as 2013… Mr. Page hasn’t been accused of wrongdoing.}} The [[Presidency of Donald Trump|Trump Administration]] attempted to distance itself from Page, saying that he had never met Trump or advised him about anything, but a December 2016 Page press conference in Russia contradicts the claim that Page and Trump never met.{{cite news |last=O'Meara Morales |first=Kelly |date=February 6, 2018 |title=Carter Page told George Stephanopoulos he never met Donald Trump. Here's a video of him telling Russian media they had 'a number of meetings.' |url=http://theweek.com/speedreads/753642/carter-page-told-george-stephanopoulos-never-met-donald-trump-heres-video-telling-russian-media-number-meetings |work=The Week |location=New York, NY |access-date=2018-02-07}} Page responded to a question about his contact with Trump saying, "I've certainly been in a number of meetings with him and I've learned a tremendous amount from him."{{cite news |last=Savaransky |first=Rebecca |date=February 6, 2018 |title=Carter Page told Russian TV he was in 'a number of meetings' with Trump |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/372547-carter-page-previously-said-he-has-been-in-a-number-of-meetings-with |work=The Hill |location=Washington, DC |access-date=2018-02-07}} In October 2017, Page said he would not cooperate with requests to appear before the [[United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence|Senate Intelligence Committee]] and would assert his [[Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fifth Amendment right]] against [[self-incrimination]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/10/10/carter-page-russia-probe-243648|title=Carter Page says he won't testify before Senate Intelligence panel in Russia probe|work=Politico |access-date=2017-10-11}} He said this was because they were requesting documents dating back to 2010, and he did not want to be caught in a "[[perjury trap]]". He expressed the wish to testify before the committee in an open setting.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/10/17/politics/carter-page-subpoena-senate-intel-committee/index.html|title=Carter Page subpoenaed by Senate intel committee|last=|first=|date=|work=CNN|access-date=2017-11-01|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} On July 21, 2018, the Justice Department released a heavily [[redaction|redact]]ed version of the October 2016 [[FISA]] warrant application for Page, which expressed in part the FBI's belief that the Russian government was collaborating with Page and possibly others associated with the Trump campaign,{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/21/us/politics/carter-page-fisa.html?hp&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&clickSource=story-heading&module=first-column-region®ion=top-news&WT.nav=top-news|title=Justice Dept. Releases Secret Carter Page Surveillance Documents at Center of Partisan Clash|publisher=|accessdate=July 21, 2018}} as well as that Page had been the subject of targeted recruitment by Russian intelligence agencies.{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/07/22/631260082/trump-administration-releases-classified-warrants-for-fbi-wiretap-of-carter-page|title=Trump Administration Releases Classified Warrants For FBI Wiretap Of Carter Page|last=Cheslow|first=Daniella|date=July 22, 2018|work=NPR|accessdate=23 July 2018}} The application also said that Page and a Russian intelligence operative had met in secret to discuss compromising material (''[[kompromat]]'') the Russian government held against "Candidate #2" (presumed to be [[Hillary Clinton]]) and the possibility of the Russians giving it to the Trump campaign.{{cite news|url=http://jamiedupree.blog.ajc.com/2018/07/21/fbi-releases-declassified-carter-page-fisa-application/|title=FBI releases declassified Carter Page FISA applications|newspaper=[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]|date=July 21, 2018|first=Jamie|last=Dupree}} ===House Intelligence Committee testimony=== On November 2, 2017, Page testified{{cite web|url=https://intelligence.house.gov/uploadedfiles/carter_page_hpsci_hearing_transcript_nov_2_2017.pdf|title=Testimony of Carter Page, U.S. House Select Committee on Intelligence, Nov. 7, 2017|publisher=|accessdate=May 20, 2018}} to the [[United States House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence|House Intelligence Committee]] that he had he kept senior officials in the Trump campaign such as [[Corey Lewandowski]], [[Hope Hicks]], and [[J.D. Gordon]] informed about his contacts with the Russians{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/11/06/politics/carter-page-testimony-released/index.html|title=Carter Page reveals new contacts with Trump campaign, Russians|first=Manu Raju, Jeremy Herb and Katelyn Polantz,|last=CNN|publisher=|accessdate=May 20, 2018}} and had informed [[Jeff Sessions]], Lewandowski, Hicks and other Trump campaign officials that he was traveling to Russia to give a speech in July 2016.{{cite news |last1=Raju |first1=Manu |last2=Herb |first2=Jeremy |date=November 2, 2017 |title=Carter Page testifies he told Sessions about Russia trip |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/11/02/politics/carter-page-testimony-russia-trip/index.html |work=CNN.com |location=Atlanta, GA}}{{cite news |last=Price |first=Greg |date=November 7, 2017 |title=Carter Page Says Russia Trip was Approved by Trump Campaign Manager Lewandowski |url=http://www.newsweek.com/page-trump-russia-trip-campaign-703831 |work=Newsweek |location=New York, NY}}{{cite news |last=Correll |first=Diana Stancy |date=November 6, 2017 |title=Corey Lewandowski and Hope Hicks knew about Carter Page's trip to Russia |url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/corey-lewandowski-and-hope-hicks-knew-about-carter-pages-trip-to-russia/article/2639835 |work=[[The Washington Examiner]] |location=Washington, D.C.}} Page testified that he had met with Russian government officials during this trip and had sent a post-meeting report via email to members of the Trump campaign.{{cite news |last1=Mazzetti |first1=Mark |last2=Goldman |first2=Adam |date=November 3, 2017 |title=Trump Campaign Adviser Met With Russian Officials in 2016 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/03/us/politics/trump-campaign-page-russian.html |work=New York Times |location=New York, NY}} He also indicated that campaign co-chairman [[Sam Clovis]] had asked him to sign a non-disclosure agreement about his trip.{{cite news |last1=Raju |first1=Manu |last2=Herb |first2=Jeremy |last3=Polantz |first3=Katelyn |date=November 8, 2017 |title=Carter Page reveals new contacts with Trump campaign, Russians |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/11/06/politics/carter-page-testimony-released/index.html |work=CNN.com |location=Atlanta, GA}} Elements of Page's testimony contradicted prior claims by Trump, Sessions, and others in the Trump administration.{{cite news |date=November 3, 2017 |title= Ex-Trump adviser Carter Page contradicts Sessions in testimony about Russia trip |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/11/03/ex-trump-advisers-testimony-about-russia-trip-contradicts-sessions.html |work=Fox News |location=New York, NY}}{{cite news |last=Tacopino |first=Joe |date=November 2, 2017 |title=Carter Page: I told Jeff Sessions about my trip to Russia |url=https://nypost.com/2017/11/02/carter-page-i-told-jeff-sessions-about-my-trip-to-russia/ |work=New York Post |location=New York, NY}} Lewandowski, who had previously denied knowing Page or meeting him during the campaign, said after Page's testimony that his memory was refreshed and acknowledged that he had been aware of Page's trip to Russia.{{cite news |last=Lima |first=Cristiano |date=November 8, 2017 |title=Lewandowski: 'My memory has been refreshed' on Carter Page Moscow trip |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/11/08/corey-lewandowski-carter-page-email-244689 |work=Politico |location=Washington, D.C.}} Page also testified that after delivering a commencement speech at the [[New Economic School]] in Moscow, he spoke briefly with one of the people in attendance, [[Arkady Dvorkovich]], a Deputy Prime Minister in [[Dmitry Medvedev]]'s cabinet, contradicting his previous statements not to have spoken to anyone connected with the Russian government.{{cite news |last=Chia |first=Jessica |date=November 3, 2017 |title=Carter Page flew to Moscow, met with Russian government officials during presidential campaign: report |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/carter-page-met-russian-government-officials-report-article-1.3610111 |work=New York Daily News |location=New York, NY |quote=He has previously denied meeting with any Russian government officials during the trip. Just yesterday, Page said he traveled to Moscow to deliver a speech and that the trip was “completely unrelated to my limited volunteer role with the campaign.”}} In addition, while Page denied a meeting with Sechin as alleged in the [[Trump–Russia dossier]], he did say he met with Andrey Baranov, [[Rosneft]]'s head of investor relations.{{cite news |last=Tracy |first=Abigail |date=November 7, 2017 |access-date=November 7, 2017 |title=Is Carter Page Digging the Trump Administration's Grave? |url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2017/11/carter-page-hearing-donald-trump-russia |work=Vanity Fair}} The dossier alleges that Sechin offered Page the brokerage fee from the sale of up to 19 percent of Rosneft if he worked to roll back [[Magnitsky Act]] economic sanctions that had been imposed on Russia in 2012.{{cite web|last1=Shepherd|first1=Todd|title=Carter Page: Committees have 'completely blocked' me from testifying|url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/carter-page-committees-have-completely-blocked-me-from-testifying/article/2625554 | website=[[The Washington Examiner]] | access-date=1 December 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Bertrand|first1=Natasha|title=Memos: CEO of Russia's state oil company offered Trump adviser, allies a cut of huge deal if sanctions were lifted|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/carter-page-trump-russia-igor-sechin-dossier-2017-1|website=Business Insider|access-date=1 December 2017}} It also alleges that Page confirmed, on Trump's "full authority", that this was Trump's intent.{{cite web | last=Bertrand | first=Natasha | title=The timeline of Trump's ties with Russia lines up with allegations of conspiracy and misconduct | website=Business Insider | date=February 11, 2017 | url=http://www.businessinsider.com/trump-russia-ties-michael-flynn-dossier-2017-2 | access-date=December 29, 2017}}{{cite web | last=Withnall | first=Adam | last2=Sengupta | first2=Kim | title=The 10 key Donald Trump allegations from the classified Russia memos | website=The Independent | date=January 12, 2017 | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/donald-trump-russia-10-allegations-dossier-kremlin-michael-cohen-sex-claims-intelligence-reports-a7522056.html | access-date=December 29, 2017}}{{cite web | last=Bertrand | first=Natasha | title=Memos: CEO of Russia's state oil company offered Trump adviser, allies a cut of huge deal if sanctions were lifted | website=Business Insider | date=January 27, 2017 | url=http://www.businessinsider.com/carter-page-trump-russia-igor-sechin-dossier-2017-1 | access-date=December 29, 2017}}{{cite web | last=Roazen | first=Ben | title=What Else Does the Donald Trump–Russia Dossier Tell Us? | website=GQ | date=February 21, 2017 | url=https://www.gq.com/story/trump-russia-dossier-matryoshka | access-date=December 29, 2017}}{{cite web | last=Raju | first=Manu | last2=Herb | first2=Jeremy | last3=Polantz | first3=Katelyn | title=Carter Page reveals new contacts with Trump campaign, Russians | website=CNN | date=November 7, 2017 | url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/11/06/politics/carter-page-testimony-released/index.html | access-date=February 9, 2018}} Page testified that he did not "directly" express support for lifting the sanctions during the meeting with Baranov, but that he might have mentioned the proposed Rosneft transaction. ==See also== * [[Michael Flynn]] * [[Paul Manafort]] * [[Roger Stone]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * [http://globalenergycap.com/ globalenergycap.com] — Global Energy Capital site * {{YouTube|id=bsgSl8s2GeM|title=Former Trump adviser says he had no Russian meetings in the last year}}, February 15, 2017 [[PBS NewsHour]] interview * [https://intelligence.house.gov/uploadedfiles/carter_page_hpsci_hearing_transcript_nov_2_2017.pdf Testimony of Carter Page, U.S. House Select Committee on Intelligence, Nov. 7, 2017] * [https://int.nyt.com/data/documenthelper/95-carter-page-fisa-documents-foia-release/full/optimized.pdf FISA warrant on Carter Page, redacted] {{DEFAULTSORT:Page, Carter}} [[Category:1971 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Alumni of SOAS, University of London]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] {{multiple issues| {{cleanup-reorganize|date=January 2017}} {{external links|date=January 2017}} {{news release|1=article|date=January 2017}} {{more references|date=January 2017}} }} [[File:Eswgeneric-1.jpg|thumb|right|The Earth Science Week logo]]
'''Earth Sciences Week''' is a yearly event run by the [[American Geosciences Institute]] to promote the knowledge of Earth sciences at local, state, national, and international levels. It is typically held in the second week of October. The 2018 date is October 14-20. <ref>http://www.earthsciweek.org/about-esw</ref>
The events are partially funded and sponsored by the [[United States Geological Survey|USGS]], the [[National Park Service]], and the [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]].
== Earth Science Week objectives == * To engage students in discovering the Earth sciences. * To remind people that Earth science is all around us. * To encourage Earth stewardship through understanding. * To motivate geoscientists to share their knowledge and enthusiasm about the Earth.
== Web resources == The [http://www.earthsciweek.org Earth Science Week website] is updated regularly to reflect the new theme, contests, proclamations, events, and classroom activities for each year’s Earth Science Week.
== Events == The Earth Science Week website maintains a listing of groups in the Earth Science World Network, as well as a state-by-state listing of Earth Science Week events. These events are sponsored by member societies, state geological surveys, colleges and universities, public and private schools, museums, parks, and other organizations and businesses with interests in Earth Science.
== Toolkits == Earth Science Week Toolkits feature AGI’s traditional event poster and school-year calendar showcasing geoscience careers, classroom investigations, and important dates of Earth science events. Also included are posters, flyers, electronic disks, bookmarks, and activities from AGI and its member societies and sponsors. Toolkits are distributed to state geological surveys, Earth Science Week sponsors and may be purchased through the ESW website.
== National contests == AGI has held national contests in connection with Earth Science Week for five consecutive years. The contests are designed to encourage K-12 students, teachers, and the general public to get involved in the celebration by exploring artistic and academic applications of Earth science.
There are three mediums in which contests are held: Photography, Visual Arts, and Essay. Each contest explores a new theme every year; past themes have included "People Discovering Earth's Treasures" and "Extreme Earth Science" for Photography, "Changing Earth" and "Earth Science in Your Home Town" for Visual Arts, and "Be A Citizen Scientist" and "Studying the Active Earth" for Essays.
== Official proclamations == The [http://www.stategeologists.org/ Association of American State Geologists] adopted a resolution designating the second full week of October as Earth Science Week. In July, 1998, Senator Ron Wyden (D-OR) read a statement containing this resolution into the Congressional Record. In 2002, AASG passed a motion to reaffirm their support of Earth Science Week.
AGI currently works with each state geological survey to encourage proclamations to be made on the state and national level for each year's Earth Science Week.
Seven states have issued perpetual proclamations: Alaska, Delaware, Illinois, Nevada, North Dakota, Oklahoma, and South Dakota.
=== Presidential recognition === AGI has obtained Presidential proclamations for Earth Science Week in past years from Presidents Bill Clinton and George W. Bush.
== Newsletters == Earth Science Week releases a monthly Update Newsletter to teacher, student, and geoscientist subscribers. This electronic newsletter keeps planners and participants up-to-date on Earth Science Week planning at the national level and encourages participation in local areas.
== Themes == *2002: Water Is All Around Us *2003: Eyes on Planet Earth: Monitoring Our Changing World *2004: Living on a Restless Earth: Natural Hazards and Mitigation *2005: Geoscientists Explore the Earth *2006: Be a Citizen Scientist! *2007: The Pulse of Earth Science *2008: No Child Left Inside *2009: Understanding Climate *2010: Exploring Energy *2011: Our Ever-Changing Earth *2012: Exploring Careers in the Earth Sciences *2013: Mapping Our World *2014: Earth's Connected Systems *2015: Visualizing Earth Systems *2016: Our Shared Geoheritage *2017: Earth and Human Activity *2018: Earth as Inspiration
== See also ==
*[[American Geosciences Institute]] *[[List of geoscience organizations]] *[[National Fossil Day]]
==References== <references />

Television]] | budget = | network = [[NBC]] | first_aired = {{Film date|TV=y|2014|12|16}} | last_aired = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = }} '''''Elf: Buddy's Musical Christmas''''' is a 2014 [[United States|American]] [[stop-motion]] [[Animation|animated]] [[Christmas]] [[Musical film|musical]] [[television special]] directed by Mark Caballero and Seamus Walsh and written by [[Aaron Horvath]], [[Michael Jelenic]], [[Bob Martin (comedian)|Bob Martin]] and [[Thomas Meehan (writer)|Thomas Meehan]]. It is based on the 2003 film ''[[Elf (film)|Elf]]'' and the [[Broadway theatre]] [[Musical theatre|musical]] ''[[Elf: The Musical]]''. While [[Ed Asner]] reprises his role of Santa Claus from the film, the rest of the cast consists of [[Jim Parsons]], [[Mark Hamill]], [[Kate Micucci]], [[Max Charles]], and [[Rachael MacFarlane]]. The special premiered on December 16, 2014, on [[NBC]]. ==Plot== {{more plot|date=December 2016}} Santa narrates the story of Buddy's travels to New York City to meet his father. Along the way, his unrelenting cheer transforms the lives of everyone he meets and opens his father's eyes to the magic of the holiday. ==Cast== * [[Jim Parsons]] as William "Buddy" Hobbs * [[Mark Hamill]] as Walter Hobbs * [[Kate Micucci]] as Jovie * [[Ed Asner]] as [[Santa Claus]] * [[Max Charles]] as Michael Hobbs * [[Rachael MacFarlane]] as Emily Hobbs, Fake Santa #3 * [[Fred Armisen]] as Matthews * [[Kevin Michael Richardson]] as Fake Santa #2, Jerry Hobbs * [[Gilbert Gottfried]] as Mr. Greenway * [[Jay Leno]] as Fake Santa #1 * [[Steve Higgins]] as Chadwick * [[Matt Lauer]] as Mr. Sea Serpent * [[Kevin Shinick]] as Fake Santa #4 ==Reception== The special was viewed by 4.82 million viewers.{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2014/12/17/tuesday-final-ratings-ncis-the-voice-adjusted-up-no-adjustment-for-person-of-interest-or-masterchef-junior/340466/|title=Tuesday Final Ratings: 'NCIS' & 'The Voice' Adjusted Up, No Adjustment for 'Person of Interest' or 'MasterChef Junior'|last=Kondolojy|first=Amanda|work=TV by the Numbers|date=December 17, 2014|accessdate=December 17, 2014}} ''Elf: Buddy's Musical Christmas'' received positive reviews from critics. The review-aggregation website [[Metacritic]], which assigns a normalized rating out of 100 top reviews from mainstream critics, calculated a score of 74 out of 100 based on 8 reviews, indicating "generally favorable reviews".{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/elf-buddys-musical-christmas|title=Elf: Buddy's Musical Christmas|work=Metacritic|accessdate=17 December 2014}} Ray Rahman of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave the special a B+, saying "''Elf: Buddy's Musical Christmas'' probably won't become a classic, but it's a fun break from the usual standards."{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/tv/tonights_best_tv/0,,2,00.html|title=Tonight's Best - TV - Entertainment Weekly|publisher=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=17 December 2014}} Brian Lowry of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' gave the special a positive review, saying "''Elf: Buddy’s Musical Christmas'' suits the genre well, and suggests there is an alternative to simply running the sprockets off old holiday perennials. And in albeit in a minor way, that’s good reason to be happy — if not all the time, at least for an hour or so."{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/tv/reviews/tv-review-elf-buddys-musical-christmas-1201376770/|title=‘Elf: Buddy’s Musical Christmas’ TV Review on NBC |work=Variety|accessdate=17 December 2014}} Erik Adams of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' gave the special a B, saying "Narratively and emotionally rushed, at least ''Buddy’s Musical Christmas'' smartly emphasizes its animated nature, through visual inventiveness and top-flight voice talent."{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/animated-retelling-elf-justifies-its-existence-vis-212956|title=Review: An animated retelling of Elf justifies its existence with visual daring |publisher=The A.V. Club|accessdate=17 December 2014}} ==Home media== [[Warner Home Video]] released ''Elf: Buddy's Musical Christmas'' on DVD and Blu-ray on November 3, 2015.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Elf-Musical-Christmas-Jim-Parsons/dp/B010ELXQPU |title=Elf: Buddy's Musical Christmas: Jim Parsons, Mark Hamill, Kate Micucci, Edward Asner, Mark Caballero, Seamus Walsh: Movies & TV |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2016-01-17}} ==Accolades== The film was nominated for seven [[Annie Award]]s and won one for Character Design in an Animated Television/Broadcast Production{{cite web|url=http://annieawards.org/nominees/ |title=Annie Awards Nominees |publisher=Annieawards.org |date= |accessdate=2016-01-17}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|4147830}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|elf_buddys_musical_christmas}} * {{Metacritic tv|elf-buddys-musical-christmas}} * {{tv.com show|elf-buddys-musical-christmas}} {{Warner Bros. animation and comics}} [[Category:2014 television specials]] [[Category:2010s American animated films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American television films]] [[Category:Animated short films]] [[Category:Christmas musicals]] [[Category:Christmas television specials]] [[Category:Musical television specials]] [[Category:NBC television specials]] [[Category:New Line Cinema animated films]] [[Category:Warner Bros. Animation animated films]] [[Category:Elf (film)]]

revision.text:
{{primary sources|date=July 2013}} {{Coord|45|24|44.5|N|75|37|55.5|W|display=title}} {{Infobox music festival | name =Escapade Music Festival | image = | caption = | location =[[Ottawa]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]] | years_active =2010-present | founders = | dates = | genre = [[Electronic music]], | attendance = | capacity = | website =[http://www.escapademf.com/ EscapadeEMF.com] }} '''Escapade Music Festival''' is an annual [[electronic dance music]] (EDM) festival usually held on [[Canada Day]] (July 1) in [[Ottawa]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]] and hosts some of the biggest names in the electronic dance music industry.<ref name="Escapade Music Festival"/>
==History== Escapade Music Festival made its debut in 2010 as a one day event in the Byward Market with Deadmau5 headlining it and a few hundred attendees.
In 2011, Escapade Music Festival grew in size to accommodate the growth of the festival, taking place in a large market parking space and featuring 3 Major headlining DJs, Tiesto, Laidback Luke and Calvin Harris (Estimated 5000 in attendance).
In 2012, Escapade grew exponentially in size and scale to accommodate an estimated 15,000 people over 2 days (June 30 – July 1) at the Ottawa Baseball Stadium in East Ottawa, with 40+ DJs performing over 3 stages. Headliners included: Avicii, Afrojack, Excision, Aly & Fila, Project 46, OVERWERK, Alesso, Tommy Trash, Dada Life, Marcus Schossow, Kill The Noise, Dillon Francis and Zeds Dead (Note: Chuckie could not make his flight on time to perform his set and ended up not performing).
In 2013, Escapade moved to the RA Centre Grounds in Central Ottawa and expanded to host an estimated 20,000+ attendees over 3 days in 2 locations (June 29 – June 30, RA Centre Grounds, July 1, Downtown in the Byward Market). This new location allowed for bigger production (Fireworks being the most notable as the RA Centre borders the Rideau River, thereby providing a safer place to launch them and expanded facilities across the festival grounds). 40+ DJs performed over 2 stages at the main event, plus several more on the 3rd, Canada Day stage in the market. Headliners included: Ferry Corsten, Steve Angello, Mark Knight, Krewella, Above & Beyond, Markus Schulz, Ben Gold, [[3LAU]], Wolfgang Gartner, Benny Benassi, Candyland and Seven Lions (Notes: Bingo Players was to perform but because of Paul's bout with cancer, Project 46 was brought in as a last minute replacement. Hard Rock Sofa also didn't show due to Visa complications and Rusko failed to show due to illness, thereby allowing Krewella to play an extended set. Umek also arrived late for his set on the Tech Stage, thereby allowing Mark Knight to play later into his already extended set). Tiesto headlined the Canada stage downtown on July 1, along with Quintino and Alvaro.
In 2014, Escapade celebrated its 5th year anniversary at the Rideau Carleton Raceway in Southeast Ottawa. The festival expanded in size and attendance with 30,000+ attendees and expansion to a 4-day format (June 28 - June 29, Main Festival at R.C.R, June 30, Club Series, Multiple Downtown venues, July 1, Downtown in the Byward Market). This years rendition featured 40+ DJs performing over 3 stages at the main event, plus several more on the 4th, Canada Day stage in the market. Headliners included: Main Stage: Eric Prydz, [[Kaskade]], Dimitri Vegas & Like Mike, Fedde Le Grand, Nervo (Note: Chuckie failed to show for the 2nd time) On Day 1: "#Goldrush" stage (Trance): Andrew Rayel, Orjan Nilsen, Ben Gold, "The Deep End" stage (Deep House/Chill House): Lee Foss with Anabel Englund, [[The Martinez Brothers]]. On Day 2: "Tech Fusion Tent" stage (Tech House): Danny Tenaglia, Nicole Moudaber, "Temple of Bass" stage (Bass Music): Zeds Dead, Noisia, Zomboy (Note: [[Grandtheft]] also failed to show). Dada Life headlined the Canada stage downtown July 1, alongside Project 46 and GTA (Surprise guests Stafford Brothers showed up alongside Joe Ghost during his Canada stage set).
This year hosted a 4th extra day called the "Escapade Club Series" between the Main Festival and the Canada Day event at various Downtown Ottawa Nightclubs. Artists included Borgeous, The Stafford Brothers, Victor Calderone, Alvin Risk, Figure, and Simon Patterson.
The festival has been supported by such sponsors as: Hot 89.9 FM, Heineken, Jägermeister, Smirnoff, Smart Set, TD Bank, Casino Lac Leamy and Courtyard Marriott. Escapade Music Festival is a DNA Presents Production, a merger of two of Ottawa's biggest EDM event producers, [[Projekt Events]] and [[A-list Entertainment]], which hosted the 2010 and 2011 editions of the music festival.<ref name="Escapade Music Festival"/>
In 2018, the festival hosted many big names including: [[Armin van Buuren]], [[Zedd]], [[Fetty Wap]], [[Ty Dolla Sign]], [[Alesso]], [[Kaskade]], [[Rezz]], [[Carnage (DJ)]], [[Brohug]], [[Mac (rapper)|MAC]], [[Quintino]], [[Tchami]], [[Robotaki]], [[Sander Van Doorn]], [[Joe Ghost]], [[Ryan Shepherd]], [[Markus Schulz]], [[Zomboy]], [[Mark Knight]], [[Borgore]] and many others.
==See also== {{Commons category|Escapade Music Festival}} *[[List of electronic music festivals]]
== References == {{one source|date=July 2013}} {{Reflist| refs= <ref name="Escapade Music Festival"> {{Cite web |publisher = Escapade Music Festival |title = Escapade Music Festival |date = 2013-06-27 |url = http://www.escapademf.com/ |accessdate = 2013-06-27}}</ref>
}}
==External links== *[http://www.escapademf.com/ Official Website] {{Electronic music festival}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox legislation |short_title = European Union Bill 2004–05 |legislature = [[Parliament of the United Kingdom]] |image = [[File:Crowned_Portcullis.svg|110px]] |imagesize = |imagealt = |caption = |long_title = To make provision in connection with the Treaty signed at Rome on 29th October 2004 establishing a Constitution for Europe; and to require a referendum to be held about it. |citation = [https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200405/cmbills/045/2005045.pdf Bill 45 2004–05] |introduced_by = [[Jack Straw]] |1st_reading = 25 January 2005 |2nd_reading = 9 February 2005 |3rd_reading = Not read a third time. |bill2 = |bill_citation2 = |bill_date2 = |introduced_by2 = [[Jack Straw]] |1st_reading2 = 24 May 2005 |2nd_reading2 = Not read a second time. |3rd_reading2 = |white_paper = |summary = Bill 45 of 2004/05. Bill 5 in 2005/06. |keywords = |status = withdrawn }} {{Brexit}} {{seealso|United Kingdom European Constitution referendum}}
The '''European Union Bill 2004–05''' (Bill 45) was a [[Bill (law)|bill]] of the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|United Kingdom Parliament]] which proposed to ratify the [[Treaty establishing a Constitution for Europe|European Constitution]] and to incorporate it into the domestic law of the United Kingdom and to amend the [[European Communities Act 1972 (UK)|European Communities Act 1972]] to include it in the list of Treaties and hold a [[United Kingdom European Constitution referendum|referendum]] throughout the [[United Kingdom]] and [[Gibraltar]] on whether to approve the proposed Constitution which would be overseen by the [[Electoral Commission (United Kingdom)|Electoral Commission]].
The bill was first introduced during the parliamentary session of 2004/05 and received a second reading. It fell at the end of that parliament. The bill was reintroduced in the new parliament and the 2005/06 session, however it was withdrawn after its first reading by [[Jack Straw]] on 6 June 2005 following "no" votes in referendums that were held on ratifying the European Constitution in [[French European Constitution referendum, 2005|France]] and in the [[Dutch European Constitution referendum, 2005|Netherlands]].<ref>{{cite hansard |jurisdiction=United Kingdom |title=Debates |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200506/cmhansrd/vo050606/debtext/50606-05.htm#50606-05_head0 |house=House of Commons |date=6 June 2005 |column=991 |speaker=Jack Straw |position= Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs}}</ref> If the referendum had gone ahead it would have been the first UK-wide referendum to have been held since the [[United Kingdom European Communities membership referendum, 1975|1975 European Communities membership referendum]] which at the time had been the only nationwide referendum to be held.. No date for the proposed referendum was ever set however the expectation was at the time that it would have been held sometime in the first six months of 2006 with the possibility that it could have been held on the same day as the [[United Kingdom local elections, 2006|2006 UK local elections]] which were scheduled and duly held on 4 May 2006.
House of Commons Library Research paper for the European Union Bill.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gay|first=Oonagh|last2=Miller|first2=Vaughne|last3=Mills|first3=Claire|title=European Union Bill (Bill 45 of 2004/05)|url=http://researchbriefings.parliament.uk/ResearchBriefing/Summary/RP05-12}}</ref>
==Proposed referendum question== The bill gave the question to appear on ballot papers: {{Quotation| '''Should the United Kingdom approve the Treaty establishing a Constitution for the European Union?''' }} and in [[Welsh language|Welsh]]: {{Quotation| '''A ddylai’r Deyrnas Unedig dderbyn y Cytuniad a fyddai’n sefydlu Cyfansoddiad i’r Undeb Ewropeaidd?''' }} permitting a simple '''YES'''/'''NO''' answer
==See also== *[[Treaty of Lisbon]] *[[European Union (Amendment) Act 2008]] *[[European Union Act 2011]] *[[European Union Referendum Act 2015]] *[[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:United Kingdom and the European Union]] [[Category:2005 in the European Union]] [[Category:Proposed laws of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Referendums in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:2004 in British politics]] [[Category:2005 in British politics]] [[Category:2004 in British law]] [[Category:2005 in British law]] [[Category:Brexit]]

revision.comment: It is the main celebration in the Brazilian city of [[Córrego Danta]]. '''Festa do Rosário''', a celebration which involves almost all of the [[Catholicism|Catholic]] people in Córrego Danta, starts with a [[Catholic mass|mass]] in the main church and then a procession from the church to the Church of Our Lady of Rosary. Here is another celebration when the flag with an image of the saint is raised. It takes place in the city during the third weekend of August.

{{Infobox company | name = GigMasters Inc | logo = GigMasters Logo 2017.png | type = [[Internet]] | industry = | fate = | predecessor = <!-- or: | predecessors = --> | successor = <!-- or: | successors = --> | founded = <!-- if known: {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} in [[city]], [[state]], [[country]] --> | founder = <!-- or: | founders = --> | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hq_location_city = [[Norwalk, Connecticut]] | hq_location_country = [[United States]] | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = Michael Caldwell, CEO; Kevin Kinyon, President | products = | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | num_employees = | num_employees_year = <!-- Year of num_employees data (if known) --> | parent = }}
'''GigMasters Inc'''. is an event services booking platform.<ref name="Snoman2013">{{cite book|author=Rick Snoman|title=Dance Music Manual: Tools, Toys, and Techniques|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=GRdmAQAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=ISBN1135964092&hl=en&sa=X&ei=45xhVab-NY2VyQSssoKgBA&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=gigmasters%20craigslist&f=false|date=15 October 2013|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-1-135-96409-2}}</ref><ref name="Kotarba2013">{{cite book|author=Joseph A. Kotarba|title=Baby Boomer Rock 'n' Roll Fans: The Music Never Ends|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YpEEpjQKdqUC&pg=PA10|year=2013|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=978-0-8108-8483-0|pages=10–}}</ref> It is headquartered in South Norwalk, Connecticut.<ref>[http://www.stamfordadvocate.com/news/article/GigMasters-finds-a-new-stage-in-South-Norwalk-1603414.php GigMasters Finds a New Stage in South Norwalk]. ''Stamfor Advocate'' Richard Lee, Staff Writer, July 26, 2011</ref> GigMasters matches entertainers with planners of weddings, dances, parties, festivals, celebrations and corporate events.<ref name="ChertkowFeehan2012">{{cite book|author1=Randy Chertkow|author2=Jason Feehan|title=The Indie Band Survival Guide, 2nd Ed.: The Complete Manual for the Do-it-Yourself Musician|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lLxn6DIiptgC|date=4 September 2012|publisher=St. Martin's Press|isbn=978-1-250-01753-6|pages=172–173}}</ref><ref>[http://www.app.com/story/life/family/2015/06/12/fathers-day-experiences-worth-trying/71134084/ "10 Father's Day experiences you have to try"]. ''Ashbury Park Press'', Kelly-Jane Cotter, June 14, 2015</ref><ref>[http://www.app.com/story/life/style/indulge/2016/08/08/simple-ways-hire-help/87967254/ "Simple ways to hire help"]. ''Ashbury Park Press'', Liz Dennerlein. Aug. 8, 2016</ref>
== History ==
GigMasters was founded in 1997 by New York area entrepreneurs Michael Caldwell and Kevin Kinyon. In February of that year, the company launched the first version of its website. In September 2010, GigMasters raised $200,000 in expansion funding from investor James Marciano.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}
In 2013, about half of the company's booking were wedding-related.<ref>[http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/fading-glory-demand-elvis-impersonators-isnt-what-it-used-be "Fading glory: Demand for Elvis impersonators isn't what it used to be"]. ''Las Vegas Review-Journal'', September 7, 2013. by LAURA CARROLL</ref> In November 2013, the company raised $1.3 million in series A funding by [[XO Group]], parent company of TheKnot.com.<ref>[http://digiday.com/media/bridal-publishers-tie-knot-content-commerce/ "Bridal publishers tie the knot between content and commerce"]. ''[[Digiday]]'', October 27, 2015 by Ricardo Bilton</ref> Kristin Savilia, XO Group's Executive Vice President, joined GigMasters' board of directors.<ref>[http://marketbrief.com/gigmasters-com-inc-form-d-sec-filng-2014-2-24 GigMasters Inc. Raises $1.3m] ''Marketbrief'' {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140731023057/http://marketbrief.com/gigmasters-com-inc-form-d-sec-filng-2014-2-24 |date=2014-07-31 }}</ref>
In September 2014, Inc. Magazine ranked GigMasters as one of the nation's 5000 fastest growing private companies.<ref>[http://www.inc.com/inc5000/list/2014/state/ct Top Companies in Connecticut on the 2014 Inc. 5000] ''INC'', 2014.</ref>
In October, 2015, the Caldwell and Kinyon, creators of GigMasters, sold the company for $8.5 million to [[XO Group]].<ref>[http://www.stamfordadvocate.com/business/article/The-Knot-owner-buys-Norwalk-s-GigMasters-6550809.php "The Knot owner buys Norwalk‘s GigMasters"]. ''Stamford Advocate'', By Alexander Soule, October 5, 2015</ref>
==Features== GigMasters sorts entries by instrument and by event or service type.<ref name="Adams2010">{{cite book|author=Simon Adams|title=101 Ways To Market Your Music On The Web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QVcMAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA166|date=27 August 2010|publisher=Lulu.com|isbn=978-1-4457-5776-6|pages=166–}}</ref> Musicians create profiles and describe their services.<ref name="Roos2008">{{cite book|author=Anne Roos|title=The Musician's Guide to Brides: How to Make Money Playing Weddings|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EMtOrLe7-UQC&pg=PA111|year=2008|publisher=Hal Leonard Books|isbn=978-1-4234-3874-8|pages=111–}}</ref><ref name="Johnson2014">{{cite book|author=Margy Johnson|title=Start Your Own Costume Character Business & Make Great Money Working at Home|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CFHQAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA43|date=24 March 2014|publisher=Xlibris Corporation|isbn=978-1-4931-7516-1|pages=43–}}{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=December 2017}}</ref> Potential customers can enter their location and search for the service they need.<ref>[https://smallbiztrends.com/2016/11/santa-for-hire.html "25 Places to Hire a Santa Claus for Your Small Business"]. ''Small Business Trends'', Nov 25, 2016 by Annie Pilon</ref>
== References ==
{{reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Use British English|date=March 2017}} '''Glasgow Science Festival''' (GSF) is a [[science festival]] held every June in Glasgow, Scotland.<ref name="University of Glasgow">{{cite web|title=University of Glasgow - Public Engagement Group in STEMM|url=http://www.gla.ac.uk/services/publicengagementgroupinstemm/|publisher=University of Glasgow}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Glasgow Science Festival|url=http://www.glasgowsciencefestival.org.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Glasgow Science Festival: Weegie Science|url=http://www.theskinny.co.uk/latest/301950-glasgow_science_festival_weegie_science|newspaper=The Skinny|date=31 May 2012}}</ref> It was founded in 2007 and provides science-themed events for children, schools and adults at various venues in the city, including lecture theatres, laboratories, cafes, pubs, theatres and cinemas.<ref>{{cite web|title=Glasgow Science Festival - Events Programme|url=http://www.glasgowsciencefestival.org.uk/events/sciencefestival/events/|publisher=Glasgow Science Festival|accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref>
The majority of events are free of charge to promote accessibility and events are developed primarily with practicing scientists in order to showcase real research.<ref>{{cite web|title=About Us|url=http://www.glasgowsciencefestival.org.uk/events/sciencefestival/aboutus/|website=Glasgow Science Festival|accessdate=21 January 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128101902/http://www.glasgowsciencefestival.org.uk/events/sciencefestival/aboutus/|archivedate=28 January 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Events include science comedy nights,<ref>{{cite news|title=Silliness and songs as Helen Arney stands up for science in Glasgow|url=http://news.stv.tv/west-central/228874-helen-arney-at-admiral-and-blackfriars-for-glasgow-science-festival/|newspaper=STV News|date=10 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Comedian Helen Arney talks geeks and nerds|url=http://www.list.co.uk/article/50980-comedian-helen-arney-talks-geeks-and-nerds/|newspaper=The List|date=15 May 2013}}</ref> pub quizzes, whisky tastings, art classes, workshops and tutorials on the science of 'zombie-ism'.<ref>{{cite web |title=Life Drawing: Under the Skin |url=http://www.glasgowsciencefestival.org.uk/events/sciencefestival/events/adult/35-lifedrawing/ |publisher=Glasgow Science Festival |accessdate=16 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130623101254/http://www.glasgowsciencefestival.org.uk/events/sciencefestival/events/adult/35-lifedrawing/ |archivedate=23 June 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Fun for everyone at Glasgow Science Festival|url=http://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/features/fun-for-everyone-at-the-glasgow-science-festival-124863n.21007848|newspaper=The Evening Times|date=21 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Food, Festivals, Scotland|url=http://www.theskinny.co.uk/latest/304767-food_festivals_scotland|newspaper=The Skinny|date=5 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=What if Glasgow really had a zombie apocalypse?|url=http://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/news/what-if-glasgow-really-had-a-zombie-apocalypse-126105n.21180669|newspaper=The Evening Times|date=3 June 2013}}</ref> Science Sunday is a day of family activities at the University of Glasgow which coincides with the [[West End Festival]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Blast off for the Glasgow Science Festival 2012|url=http://www.gla.ac.uk/news/headline_234155_en.html|newspaper=University of Glasgow|date=28 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Science Sunday |url=http://www.westendfestival.co.uk/events/science-sunday |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130717083928/http://www.westendfestival.co.uk/events/science-sunday |dead-url=yes |archive-date=17 July 2013 |publisher=West End Festival |accessdate=16 July 2013 }}</ref>
The festival is primarily funded by the [[University of Glasgow]] and the [[Scottish Government]]. It also involves partnerships with a variety of organisations including the [[University of Strathclyde]], [[Glasgow Caledonian University]], the [[Medical Research Council (United Kingdom)|MRC]], [[Kelvingrove Art Gallery & Museum]], the [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds|RPSB]], [[Glasgow School of Art]], the [[British Science Association]], [[Glasgow Botanic Gardens]] and [[Glasgow Science Centre]]<ref>{{cite web |title=Event Partners |url=http://www.gla.ac.uk/events/sciencefestival/partners/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120621093109/http://www.gla.ac.uk/events/sciencefestival/partners/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=21 June 2012 |publisher=Glasgow Science Festival |accessdate=16 July 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The festival director is Dr Deborah McNeill, a [[marine biologist]] and Head of Public Engagement in [[STEM fields|STEM]] at the University of Glasgow.<ref name="University of Glasgow"/><ref>{{cite web|title=School of Life Sciences - Dr Deborah McNeill - Staff Profile|url=http://www.gla.ac.uk/schools/lifesciences/staff/deborahmcneill/|publisher=University of Glasgow|accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref>
In 2013 the festival was launched on a [[barge]] on the [[Forth and Clyde Canal]], chartered by The Clipperton Project and attended by Scottish Minister [[Alasdair Allan]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Step aboard the Clipperton Project's floating lab on the Clyde|url=http://news.stv.tv/west-central/228108-the-clipperton-project-on-the-clyde-for-glasgow-science-festival/|newspaper=STV News|date=4 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Science sets sail from Glasgow|url=http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2013/06/Science-festival|newspaper=Scottish Government|date=4 June 2013}}</ref>
In 2017 the festival was awarded a Herald Higher Education Award for Outstanding Contribution to the Community for gravitational waves-inspired show 'Chasing the Waves'.<ref>http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/15395869.In_pictures__Glasgow_University_takes_main_prize_at_The_Herald_Higher_Education_Awards/</ref>. 'Chasing the Waves' was also a finalist in the Times Higher Education Awards <ref>https://www.the-awards.co.uk/2017/en/page/shortlisted-page-2017</ref>
== Other projects ==
Outside of the festival period in June, the festival delivers a range of public engagement projects that bring [[Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics|STEM]] subjects to new audiences:
• 'A Shed Load of Science', funded by the [[Royal Society of Chemistry]], involved working with scientists and artists to deliver free arts-science activities for communities in the North of Glasgow, including [[Possilpark]] and [[Lambhill]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Stewart|first1=Catriona|title=Chemistry workshops going off with a bang|url=http://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/news/13525459.Chemistry_workshops_going_off_with_a_bang/|accessdate=20 January 2016|date=3 August 2015}}</ref>
• 'Cleaner Canal Science' was a collaboration with [[Scottish Canals]] and the [[Scottish Waterways Trust]], funded by Zero Waste Scotland. This project engaged primary schools, community groups and local businesses in hands-on science, as a means of tackling the problem of litter on canals in Maryhill, Firhill and Clydebank.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Scottish Waterways Trust|title=Maryhill Schoolchildren Become ‘Citizen Scientists’ for the Day to Tackle Litter on the Forth & Clyde Canal|url=https://www.scottishcanals.co.uk/news/maryhill-schoolchildren-become-citizen-scientists-for-the-day-to-tackle-litter-on-the-forth-clyde-canal/|website=Scottish Canals|accessdate=20 January 2016}}</ref>
• 'CLAN' (Community Led Ambassador Network) was funded by a Scottish Government Talking Science grant and connected University of Glasgow researchers with communities in the top 0.5% most deprived in Scotland, through free community-led public engagement activity.<ref>{{cite web|title=CLAN: Community Led Ambassadors Network (Scottish Government Talking Science Award for 2013-14)|url=http://www.gla.ac.uk/services/publicengagementgroupinstemm/clan/|website=University of Glasgow|accessdate=20 January 2016}}</ref>
• 'Panto Science: The Periodic Fable' is a theatre show which blends pantomime with science. The idea was conceived by Dr Zara Gladman, Public Engagement Co-ordinator for Glasgow Science Festival,.<ref>{{cite web|title=Glasgow Science Festival: Meet the Team|url=http://www.gla.ac.uk/events/sciencefestival/aboutus/meettheteam/|website=University of Glasgow}}</ref> The story was developed by Dr Gladman with University of Glasgow researchers and comedian Bruce Morton, who wrote the script for a live show. The show aims to promote the message of gender equality in STEM to children.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Panto Science|url=http://www.pantoscience.co.uk/?page_id=7|website=Panto Science|title=Panto Science|accessdate=20 January 2016}}</ref>
• 'Chasing the Waves' was a live, musical show co-written by Dr Zara Gladman and Emily Benita which shared the story of how Glasgow scientists helped detect gravitational waves. The show was the first of its kind to bring gravitational waves to the theatre. <ref>http://www.gla.ac.uk/events/sciencefestival/eventsandprojects/projects/chasingthewaves/</ref>
== References ==
