{{Infobox SCOTUS case |Litigants=James v. United States |ArgueDate=November 17 |ArgueYear=1960 |DecideDate=May 15 |DecideYear=1961 |FullName=James v. United States |USVol=366 |USPage=213 |ParallelCitations=81 S. Ct. 1052; 6 [[Lawyers' Edition|L. Ed. 2d]] 246; 1961 [[LexisNexis|U.S. LEXIS]] 2014; 61-1 U.S. Tax Cas. ([[CCH (company)|CCH]]) ¶ 9449; 7 A.F.T.R.2d (RIA) 1361; 1961-2 C.B. 9 |Prior=Certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit |Subsequent= |Holding=Ill-gotten gains constitute taxable income, even if they must be repaid. |SCOTUS=1958-1962 |Plurality=Warren |JoinPlurality=Brennan, Stewart |Concurrence/Dissent=Black |JoinConcurrence/Dissent=Douglas |Concurrence/Dissent2=Clark |Concurrence/Dissent3=Harlan |JoinConcurrence/Dissent3=Frankfurter |Concurrence/Dissent4=Whittaker |JoinConcurrence/Dissent4=Black, Douglas |LawsApplied=[[United States Constitution|U.S. Const.]], [[Sixteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|U.S. Const. amend. XVI]] }} '''''James v. United States''''', 366 U.S. 213 (1961),<ref>''James v. United States'', {{ussc|volume=366|page=213|pin=|year=1961}}.</ref> was a case in which the [[Supreme Court of the United States|United States Supreme Court]] held that [[Taxation of illegal income in the United States|the receipt of money obtained by a taxpayer illegally]] was [[taxable income]], even though the law might require the taxpayer to repay the ill-gotten gains to the person from whom they had been taken.
==Facts== The defendant, Eugene James, was an official in a [[labor union]] who had [[embezzlement|embezzled]] more than $738,000 in union funds, and did not report these amounts on his tax return. He was [[criminal trial|tried]] for [[tax evasion]], and claimed in his defense that embezzled funds did not constitute taxable income. His argument was that just as the receipt of [[loan]] proceeds is not taxable to the borrower (because of the borrower's corresponding obligation to repay the loan), the person who embezzles money should not be treated as having received income, since that person is legally obligated to return those funds to their rightful owner. Indeed, Eugene James pointed out, the Supreme Court had previously made such a determination in ''[[Commissioner v. Wilcox]]''.<ref>{{ussc|name=Commissioner v. Wilcox|volume=327|page=404|pin=|year=1946}}.</ref> However, this defense was unavailing in the [[trial court]], where Eugene James was convicted and sentenced to three years in [[prison]].
==Issue== The Supreme Court was called upon to determine whether the receipt of embezzled funds constitutes income taxable to the wrongdoer, even though an obligation to repay exists.
==Holding== The Supreme Court ruled that under section 22(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1939 and section 61(a) of the [[Internal Revenue Code|Internal Revenue Code of 1954]], the receipt of embezzled funds was includable in the gross income of the wrongdoer and was taxable to the wrongdoer, even though the wrongdoer had an obligation to return the funds to the rightful owner.
==Rationale== The Court was divided between several different rationales. The majority opinion was written by Chief Justice [[Earl Warren]], joined by Justices Brennan and Stewart. That opinion held that if a taxpayer receives income – legally or illegally – without consensual recognition of obligation to repay, that income is taxable.
The Court noted that the scope of the [[Sixteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Sixteenth Amendment]] was not limited to "lawful" income, a distinction which ''had'' been found in the [[Revenue Act of 1913]]. The absence of the "lawful" modifier indicated that the framers of the Sixteenth Amendment had intended no safe harbor for illegal income. The Court expressly overruled ''Commissioner v. Wilcox'' and ruled that James was therefore liable for the federal income tax due on his embezzled funds. The Court also ruled, however, that Eugene James could not be held liable for the willful tax evasion because it is not possible to willfully violate laws that were not established at the time of the violation.
==Effect of the decision==
Although Eugene James avoided criminal liability, the opinion of the Court left James in a situation where he would be required not only to repay the embezzled $738,000 to the union, but would also be required to pay federal income taxes on the receipt of those funds, just as though he had been able to keep them.
==Concurrences and dissents==
Justice Whittaker, joined by Justice Black and Justice Douglas, wrote an opinion concurring in the dismissal of the indictment against James, but dissenting from the overruling of ''Wilcox''. Justice Black raised a [[Federalism]] argument, arguing that this ruling constituted a preemption of state criminal jurisdiction.
Justice Harlan, joined by Justice Frankfurter, wrote an opinion concurring with the overruling of ''Wilcox'', but contending that James should have been set for a new trial, rather than set free of criminal liability. Justice Clark wrote a brief concurrence, also agreeing with the overruling of ''Wilcox'', but stating that James' conviction should also have been upheld.
==See also== *[[Taxation of illegal income in the United States]] *[[List of United States Supreme Court cases, volume 366]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{wikisource-inline|James v. United States (366 U.S. 213)}} *{{caselaw source | case = ''James v. United States'', {{ussc|366|213|1961|el=no}} | courtlistener =https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/106235/james-v-united-states/ | findlaw = https://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-supreme-court/366/213.html | justia =https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/366/213/ | oyez =https://www.oyez.org/cases/1960/63 | other_source1 = OpenJurist | other_url1 =https://openjurist.org/366/us/213 | other_source2 = Google Scholar | other_url2 =https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=9749711470332498977 }}
{{US16thAmendment}}

revision.comment: removed [[Category:French-Canadian culture in the United States]]; added [[Category:French-Canadian culture in Missouri]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
'''La Guiannée''' (or La Guignolée){{cite web|url=http://www.illinoistimes.com/gyrobase/Content?oid=oid%3A2277|author=Ted Kleine|title=French for a Night|date=2003-01-23|work=News article|publisher=Illinois Times Newspaper}}{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/riverofsong/artists/e2-ste.html|title=Ste. Genevieve Guignolée singers|date=1998-01-01|work=PBS ''The Mississippi: River of Song'' series|publisher=The Filmmakers Collaborative and The Smithsonian Institution}}, PBSEkberg, Carl J., Colonial Ste. Genevieve: An Adventure on the Mississippi Frontier, Tucson, AZ: Patrice Press, 1996, {{ISBN|1-880397-14-5}} is celebrated on December 31 (New Year's Eve) It is a [[France|French]] [[medieval]] New Year's Eve tradition that is still practiced in two towns in the United States. The tradition related to poor people being able to ask the more wealthy for food and drink at the celebrations of winter. Customarily a troupe of traveling male singers went from door to door to entertain and ring in the new year. Hosts were expected to give them food and drink. Other sources say the young men were seeking donations for [[Twelfth Night]].Ekberg, Carl J., Colonial Ste. Genevieve: An Adventure on the Mississippi Frontier, Tucson, AZ: Patrice Press, 1996, {{ISBN|1-880397-14-5}}, pp.320-321 Begun as a way for the poor to be given gratuities by the rich, it also became a community social event for young men to visit with the families of young women. Over time, the practice became an occasion for visiting with relatives and friends and was more or less a traveling feast. At first it was carried on only by young men, often in costume; women joined the party in the 20th century. In many years, the people appeared in disguise, as part of the celebration was a kind of overturning of the common order. This tradition has been practiced annually since 1722 in [[Prairie du Rocher, Illinois]]. It has been revived in [[Ste. Genevieve, Missouri]]. Both were former French colonial villages settled by French Canadians in the eighteenth century. In the latter town, current celebrations feature singers and musicians, attired in [[Colonial history of the United States|colonial]] dress, who begin their night's journey at the local [[American Legion]] Hall. They make their way through all the restaurants, bars, nursing homes and high school gyms, ending at midnight at the [[Knights of Columbus]] Hall. Translation of the words of the traditional song, ''La Guignolée'':
''Good evening master and mistress,''
''And all who live with you.''
''For the first day of the year, ''
''You owe us La Guignolée.'' ''If you have nothing to give, ''
''A chine of meat or so will do.''
''A chine of meat is not a big thing, ''
''Only ninety feet long.'' ''Again, we don't ask for very much,''
''Only the oldest daughter of the house.''
''We will give her lots of good cheer,''
''And we will surely warm her feet.'' ''Now, we greet you,''
''And beg you to forgive us please.''
''If we have acted a little crazy, ''
''We meant it in good fun.'' ''Another time we'll surely be careful''
''To know when we must come back here again.''
''Let us dance La Guenille, ''
''-- La Guenille, La Guenille!''

''

revision.text:
{{Infobox event | name = Latvia 100 | native_name = ''Latvija 100'' | image = File:18.novembra svinīgie pasākumi (31000620767).jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = | location= {{flag|Latvia}} | date = 2017-2021 | type = National | theme = 100th anniversary of the founding of [[Latvia]] | attendance = | budget = €60 million<ref>https://eng.lsm.lv/article/culture/culture/centenary-celebrations-to-cost-60-million.a214222/</ref> | patron = | website = https://lv100.lv/en/ }}
The '''100th Anniversary of the Latvian Republic''' also commercialized as '''Latvia 100''' is a national event in the [[Latvian Republic]] celebrating the country's 100th [[anniversary]] since it's 1918 establishment. The main celebrations are held on 11 November 2018, and other commemorative events are set to take place from 2017-2021. Outside from the official celebrations, 11 November is also a public holiday, being the [[Proclamation Day of the Republic of Latvia]].
== Background == {{further|History of Latvia}} On 11 November 1918, The [[Tautas padome]] (People's council), which was a coalition of competing Latvian political factions, proclaimed the independence of the Latvian region from the [[Russian Empire]] and established a new state, the [[Republic of Latvia]]. This decision was made following a summit held inside the [[Latvian National Theatre]] the day before. A [[Latvian Provisional Government|Provisional Government]] was immediately created, with [[Kārlis Ulmanis]] acting as it's first [[Prime Minister of Latvia|Prime Minister]]. 2 and a half weeks later, [[Latvian War of Liberation]] began, with the [[Red Army]] and the [[Imperial German Army]] invading the country in order to have a foothold in the [[Baltic states]]. The war ended with a Latvian/pan-baltic victory in August 1920 and the signing of the [[Latvian–Soviet Peace Treaty|Treaty of Riga]].
== Events == The centennial will be the biggest event in the history of modern Latvia. More than 800 wide range celebratory events and festivities were planned to take place from May 2017 to January 2021 in Latvia and in more than 70 countries.<ref>https://www.km.gov.lv/en/ministry/centenary-of-the-republic-of-latvia</ref> The 5-year span will include events that mark the centenaries of different stages of Latvia's path to independence, as well as Latvia's accomplishments after it's statehood was achieved. The official celebrations started on May 4, 2017, Latvia' restoration day, with the Embrace Latvia initiative when citizens planted exactly 100 oaks along the country's outer border.<ref>http://latvia.eu/latvias-centenary-0</ref>
As per events on its actual centennial anniversary on 11 November 2018, many high level government officials, dignitaries, military leaders, and public figures laid wreaths and flowers at the [[Freedom Monument]] in the capital. A musical concert was held at the [[Latvian National Theatre]], where Latvia decalred it's sovereignty in 1918. A special meeting of the [[Saeima]] was also at the theatre.<ref>https://www.rferl.org/amp/latvia-marks-100-years--independence-russian-empire/29607304.html</ref>
=== Military Parade === [[File:18.novembra svinīgie pasākumi (31000619877).jpg|thumb|The Italian [[Bersaglieri]] marching in the military parade.]] The annual military parade 11 November Embankment in [[Riga]] marked the centennial anniversary's main events. It was the largest in history with around 1,700 soldiers from the [[Latvian National Armed Forces]] participating in the march past.<ref>http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-11/19/c_137615886.htm</ref> It was composed of personnel of the [[Latvian Land Forces|Land Forces]], [[Latvian Naval Forces|Navy]], [[Latvian Air Force|Air Force]], [[Latvian National Guard|National Guard]], [[Border Guard]], [[Latvian Military Police|Military Police]] and military academies. The parade was led by Gen. [[Riho Terras]], President [[Kersti Kaljulaid]] was present to greet the different units. Estonian President [[Kersti Kaljulaid]], Lithuanian President [[Dalia Grybauskaitė]], Finnish President [[Sauli Niinistö]] and Icelandic President [[Guðni Th. Jóhannesson]] joined Latvian President [[Raimonds Vejonis]] in attending the military parade and the celebrations.
The [[NATO]] countries and other military partners of Latvia that were represented at the parade were [[Italy]], [[Estonia]], [[Lithuania]], [[Poland]], [[Romania]], the [[Czech Republic]], [[Finland]], [[Albania]], [[Croatia]], the [[Netherlands]], [[Norway]], [[Slovakia]], [[Spain]] [[Slovenia]], [[United Kingdom|Britain]], [[Denmark]], [[Sweden]], [[Germany]], [[Canada]] and the [[United States]].<ref>http://micetimes.asia/military-parade-in-honor-of-the-centenary-of-independence-of-latvia-photo/</ref>
== Focus of celebrations by year == [[File:Saeimas 18.novembra svinīgā sēde (44120825910).jpg|thumb|The anniversary concert]] Each year of the anniversary has a key word in recognition of events that took place 100 years ago, which were significant to the foundation of the country.<ref>https://lv100.lv/en/about/</ref>
* 2017 - The Year of Will. Honours the consolidation of the independence movement in Latvia. * 2018 - The Year of Birth. Commemorates the creation of Latvia as well as the countries of the [[Baltics]] and Central and [[Eastern Europe]] from the ruins of former empires. * 2019 - The Year of Courage. Commemorates those who died in the [[Latvian War of Independence]]. * 2020 - The Year of Freedom. Honours the creation of government and the election of the first Latvian President. * 2021 - the Year of Growth. Honours the days when Latvia was finally recognised as a country by the world and was accepted into the [[League of Nations]].
== See also == * [[Proclamation Day of the Republic of Latvia]] * [[Public holidays in Latvia]] * [[Lāčplēsis Day]] * [[90th anniversary of the Latvian Republic]] * [[100th Anniversary of the Estonian Republic]] * [[Centennial of the Restored State of Lithuania]]
== References == {{Reflist}}

style="background:#f90;"|4 | [[Mount Okmok]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.volcano.si.edu/world/volcano.cfm?vnum=1101-29-&volpage=erupt |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021174547/http://www.volcano.si.edu/world/volcano.cfm?vnum=1101-29-&volpage=erupt |archivedate=21 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }} </ref> || {{flag|United States}} || 2008 || || |- ! Ash plumes caused major disruption to aviation across Java. |- ! style="background:#f90;"|4 | [[Grímsvötn]] || {{flag|Iceland}} || [[2011 eruption of Grímsvötn|2011]] || || |- ! style="background:#F60;"|5 | [[Puyehue-Cordón Caulle]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.volcano.si.edu/volcano.cfm?vn=357150|title=Global Volcanism Program - Puyehue-Cordon Caulle|website=Volcano.si.edu|accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref> || {{flag|Chile}} || [[2011 Puyehue-Cordón Caulle eruption|2011]] || || Major flight disruptions across the southern hemisphere, including South America, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand. Ejecting 0.7 cu km, this event was the biggest volcanic eruption of the 21st century to date. |- ! style="background:#f90;"|4 | [[Nabro Volcano|Nabro]] || {{flag|Eritrea}} || [[2011 Nabro eruption|2011]] || 31 || |- ! style="background:#fc0;"|3 | [[Mount Etna|Etna]]<ref name="GVP-Etna">{{cite web | url=http://volcano.si.edu/volcano.cfm?vn=211060 | title=Etna | publisher=[[Smithsonian Institution]] | work=[[Global Volcanism Program]] | date=3 September 2013 | accessdate=12 December 2017}}</ref> || {{flag|Italy}} || 2013- || || An eruption on 16 March 2017 injured 10 people, including a [[BBC News]] television crew, after magma exploded upon contact with snow.<ref>{{cite news |last=Balmer |first=Crispian |date=16 March 2017 |title=Volcanic explosion on Mount Etna injures 10 people |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-italy-etna-idUSKBN16N270 |work=[[Reuters]] |accessdate=16 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-39293086|title=Mount Etna: BBC crew caught up in volcano blast|date=2017-03-16|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-03-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> |- ! style="background:#ff3;"|2 | [[Mount Sinabung]] || {{flag|Indonesia}} || 2014 || 15 || [[Mount Sinabung]]'s eruptions caused many pyroclastic flows, one resulting in the loss of 15 lives. |- ! style="background:#f90;"|4 |[[Kelud]] || {{flag|Indonesia}} || [[2014 Kelud eruption|2014]] || 2<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-26183880 | title = Mass evacuation in Indonesia as Java volcano erupts | publisher = BBC News | date = 14 February 2014 | accessdate = 2014-02-15}}</ref> || |- ! style="background:#fc0;"|3 | [[Mount Ontake]] || {{flag|Japan}} || [[2014 Mount Ontake eruption|2014]] || 63 || A [[phreatic eruption]] and pyroclastic flow occurred without warning, killing 63 people. Deadliest eruption in Japan since 1902, first volcano-related deaths in Japan since 1991. |- ! style="background:#f90;"|4 | [[Calbuco Volcano|Calbuco]] || {{flag|Chile}} || 2015 || 0 || First eruption at Calbuco since 1972. At least 4,000 people evacuated. No casualties reported.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Pyle|first1=David|title=Volcán Calbuco: what do we know so far?|url=http://blogs.egu.eu/network/volcanicdegassing/2015/04/27/volcan-calbuco-what-do-we-know-so-far/|website=Blogs.egu.eu|accessdate=14 January 2016}}</ref> |- ! style="background:#ff3;"|2 | [[Mount Sinabung]] || {{flag|Indonesia}} || 2016 || 7 || [[Mount Sinabung]] continued to erupt, with 7 fatalities over two different occasions <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.volcano.si.edu/volcano.cfm?vn=261080|title=Global Volcanism Program - Sinabung |website=Volcano.si.edu|accessdate=27 September 2017}}</ref> |- ! style="background:#fc0;"|3 | [[Volcán de Fuego]] || {{flag|Guatemala}} || [[2018 Volcán de Fuego eruption|2018-]] || 159<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://aldianews.com/articles/culture/guatemala-volcano-death-toll-hiked-159-256-people-still-missing/53470|title=Guatemala volcano death toll hiked to 159, 256 people still missing|date=30 July 2018|work=Al Día|access-date=23 Aug 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180804201022/http://aldianews.com/articles/culture/guatemala-volcano-death-toll-hiked-159-256-people-still-missing/53470|archive-date=4 Aug 2018|dead-url=no|publisher=AL DÍA News Media|location=Pennsylvania, US}}</ref> || At least 159 were killed and 256 were missing after the volcano's most powerful eruption since 1974. Ash forced the closure of [[La Aurora International Airport]] in the capital [[Guatemala City]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Perez |first1=Sonia |title=Death toll rises to 25 in Guatemala volcano eruption |url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/world/americas/104449477/guatemala-volcano-erupts-suddenly-multiple-deaths |website=Stuff |accessdate=4 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Guatemala's Fuego volcano erupts killing 25 and injuring hundreds |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/04/guatemala-fuego-volcano-erupts-dead-missing |website=The Guardian |accessdate=4 June 2018}}</ref> |- |}

{{about|the festival|the composition|Lollapalooza (Adams)}} {{Infobox recurring event | name Post Maloney is there. = | native_name = | logo = [[File:Lollapalooza logo.svg|150px]] | logo_caption = | image = Lollapalooza 2015.JPG | imagesize = 300px | caption = Bud Light Stage during the 2015 festival in Chicago | date = | begins = | ends = | frequency = Annually | location = {{bulleted list|style=font-size: 75%;|Touring (1991–97, 2003)|[[Grant Park (Chicago)|Grant Park]], [[Chicago]] (2005–present)|[[O'Higgins Park]], [[Santiago]] (2011–present)|[[:pt:Hipódromo de Cidade Jardim|Hipódromo de Cidade Jardim]], [[São Paulo]] (2012–13)|[[Autódromo José Carlos Pace|Interlagos]], São Paulo (2014–present)|[[Hipódromo de San Isidro]], [[San Isidro, Buenos Aires|San Isidro]] (2014–present)|[[Berlin Tempelhof Airport|Flughafen Berlin-Tempelhof]], [[Berlin]] (2015)|[[Treptower Park]], Berlin (2016)|Hoppegarten Hippodrome, [[Hoppegarten]] (2017)|[[:de:Olympiagelände Berlin|Olympiapark]], Berlin (2018)|[[Hippodrome de Longchamp]], [[Paris]] (2017–present)}} | years_active = 1991–1997, 2003, 2005–present | first = {{start date and age|1991|7|18}}
By [[Perry Farrell]] of [[Jane's Addiction]] | last = {{bulleted list|style=font-size: 75%;|March 16–17, 2018 (San Isidro)|March 16–18, 2018 (Santiago)|March 23–25, 2018 (São Paulo)|July 22–23, 2017 (Paris)|August 3–6, 2017 (Chicago)|September 9-10, 2017 (Berlin)}} | participants = | genre = {{hlist|[[Alternative rock]]|[[punk rock]]|[[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]]|[[pop music|pop]]|[[hip hop music|hip hop]]|[[electronic music|electronic]]}} | budget = | patron = | website = {{url|https://www.lollapalooza.com/}} | footnotes = }} '''Lollapalooza''' {{IPAc-en|ˌ|l|ɑː|l|ə|p|ə|ˈ|l|uː|z|ə}} is an annual [[music festival]] including but not limited to [[alternative rock]], [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]], [[punk rock]], [[hip hop music|hip hop]], and [[electronic music]] bands and artists, with dance and comedy performances, and craft booths. It has also provided a platform for non-profit and political groups and various visual artists. Conceived and created in 1991 by [[Jane's Addiction]] singer [[Perry Farrell]] as a farewell tour for his band, Lollapalooza ran annually until 1997, and was revived in 2003. From its inception through 1997 and its revival in 2003, the festival toured North America. In 2004, the festival organizers decided to expand the dates to two days per city, but poor ticket sales forced the 2004 tour to be cancelled.The Associated Press. [https://www.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2004-06-22-festival-canceled_x.htm "Lollapalooza 2004 cancels all dates"]. ''[[USA Today]]''. June 22, 2004. In 2005, Farrell and the [[William Morris Agency]] partnered with [[Austin, Texas]]–based company Capital Sports Entertainment (now [[C3 Presents]]) and retooled it into its current format as a weekend destination festival in [[Grant Park (Chicago)|Grant Park]], [[Chicago]]. In 2014, [[Live Nation Entertainment]] bought a controlling interest in C3 Presents.[https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/6414053/live-nation-completes-deal-for-c3-presents Live Nation Completes Deal for C3 Presents] - Billboard, 22 December 2014 In 2010 it was announced that Lollapalooza would debut outside the United States, with a branch of the festival staged in [[Chile]]'s capital [[Santiago, Chile|Santiago]] on April 2–3, 2011 where they partnered up with Santiago-based company Lotus. In 2011, the company Geo Events confirmed the Brazilian version of the event, which was held at the Jockey Club in [[São Paulo]] on 7 and 8 April 2012.{{cite web |url=http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/ilustrada/938604-festival-lollapalooza-deve-ter-edicao-em-sp-em-2012.shtml |title=Festival Lollapalooza deve ter edição em SP em 2012 |publisher= [[Folha de S.Paulo]] |date=2011-07-04 |accessdate=2011-10-21}}{{cite web|url=http://www.lollapaloozabr.com/ |title=Lollapalooza Brasil |publisher=Lollapaloozabr.com |date=2013-03-29 |accessdate=2013-08-12}} In September 2013, [[Buenos Aires]] was selected as the third Lollapalooza in [[South America]], starting on April 2014, and in November 2014, the first European Lollapalooza was announced, which was held at the former [[Berlin Tempelhof Airport|Tempelhof Airport]] in [[Berlin]].[http://www.lollapalooza.com/2014/announcing-lollapalooza-berlin-2015/ lollapalooza.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150318125031/http://www.lollapalooza.com/2014/announcing-lollapalooza-berlin-2015/ |date=2015-03-18 }}, Announcing Lollapalooza Berlin 2015, retrieved 7 November 2014 In 2014, Perry handpicked and debuted a new artist to emerge as the face of the festival. The artist, collectively known as [http://www.futurebones.com The Future Bones], or Juan Marco, rebranded the festival with funky characters and a colorful palette, inherently representing the culture of the music and festival-goers today. The music festival hosts more than 160,000 people over a two or three day period. Lollapalooza has featured a diverse range of bands and artists such as [[Nine Inch Nails]], [[Kanye West]], [[Jane's Addiction]], [[Lana Del Rey]], [[Wiz Khalifa]], [[The Smashing Pumpkins]], [[Muse (band)|Muse]], [[Eminem]], [[MGMT]], [[Coldplay]], [[Stone Temple Pilots]], [[Depeche Mode]], [[Foo Fighters]], [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]], [[Ministry (band)|Ministry]], [[Pearl Jam]], [[Siouxsie and the Banshees]], [[Noel Gallagher's High Flying Birds]], [[Atlas Genius]], [[Dev (singer)|Dev]], [[Rollins Band]], [[Kid Cudi]], [[Imagine Dragons]], [[Babes in Toyland (band)|Babes in Toyland]], [[Beastie Boys]], [[Kings of Leon]], [[Foster The People]], [[The Cure]], [[Of Monsters and Men]], [[Thirty Seconds to Mars]], [[The Killers]], [[The National (band)|The National]], [[Living Colour]], [[Rage Against the Machine]], [[We the Kings]], [[Paramore]], [[Green Day]], [[Jennifer Lopez]], [[Beyonce]], [[Arcade Fire]], [[Franz Ferdinand (band)|Franz Ferdinand]], [[X Japan]], [[Audioslave]], [[Soundgarden]], [[Cage the Elephant]], [[Alice in Chains]], [[Björk]], [[Lorde]], [[Tool (band)|Tool]], [[The Black Keys]], [[deadmau5]], [[Hole (band)|Hole]], [[Body Count (band)|Body Count]], [[Ice-T]], [[Queens of the Stone Age]], [[Cupcakke]], [[The Drums]], [[The Strokes]], [[Arctic Monkeys]], [[Calvin Harris]], [[Thenewno2]], [[Fishbone]], [[Lady Gaga]], [[Lucius (band)|Lucius]], [[Betty Who]], [[Butthole Surfers]], [[Grouplove]], [[Marina And The Diamonds]], [[Haley Reinhart]], [[Scramble Campbell]], [[Zara Larsson]], [[The Weeknd]], and [[Radiohead]]. Lollapalooza is broadcast live and globally on [[Red Bull TV]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.vibe.com/2016/07/red-bull-tv-lollapalooza-music-festival/|title=Red Bull TV Brings The 2016 Lollapalooza Music Festival To You|date=2016-07-30|access-date=2016-09-09}} ==Etymology== The word—sometimes alternatively spelled and pronounced as ''lollapalootza'' or ''lalapaloosa''{{cite book |last=Appleton |first=Victor |title=Tom Swift and His Big Tunnel |year=1916 |url=http://www.gutenberg.org/dirs/etext97/19tom10.txt |chapter=Chapter XIV: Mysterious Disappearances}}—or "lallapaloosa" ([[P.G. Wodehouse]], "Heart of a Goof") dates from a late 19th-/early 20th-century American [[idiomatic]] phrase meaning "an extraordinary or unusual thing, person, or event; an exceptional example or instance."{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/lollapalooza |title=Lollapalooza | Define Lollapalooza at Dictionary.com |publisher=Dictionary.reference.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-12}} Its earliest known use was in 1896.{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/lollapalooza |title=Lollapalooza |publisher=Merriam-Webster |date= |accessdate=2015-07-31}} In time the term also came to refer to a large lollipop.Hilburn, Robert. [http://articles.latimes.com/1991-07-22/entertainment/ca-30_1_pop-music-review "POP MUSIC REVIEW – 'Lollapalooza' – Festival Concert With '60s Concept Isn't the Hoped-For Happening"]. ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. July 22, 1991. Farrell, searching for a name for his festival, liked the [[Phonaesthetics|euphonious]] quality of the by-then-antiquated term upon hearing it in a [[Three Stooges]] short film.Grimes, Taylor and Longton, Jeff. [http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/lollapalooza/2007/story.jsp "Lollapalooza History Timeline"]. ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''. 2007. Paying homage to the term's double meaning, a character in the festival's original logo holds one of the lollipops. The word has also caused a slang suffix to appear in event-planning circles as well as in news and opinion shows that is used synonymously with other suffixes like "a-go-go", "o-rama", etc. The suffix "(a)palooza" is often used to imply (often in hyperbolic language) that an entire event or crowd was made over that term, e.g.: "Parks"-apalooza, popular Chicago sushi restaurant "Roll"-apalooza, etc. ==History== ===Creation=== [[File:Trent Reznor Lollapalooza 1991.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Nine Inch Nails]] frontman [[Trent Reznor]] during the 1991 Lollapalooza festival.]] Inspired by events such as Britain's [[Reading and Leeds Festivals|Reading Festival]] – which Lollapalooza cofounder [[Perry Farrell]] had been due to play in 1990 janesaddiction.org/tour/show/janes-addiction/1990-08-24/1091/ – Farrell, [[Ted Gardner]], Don Muller, and [[Marc Geiger]] conceived the festival in 1990 as a farewell for Farrell's band [[Jane's Addiction]].Reynolds, Simon. [https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/04/arts/pop-music-a-woodstock-for-the-lost-generation.html "POP MUSIC; A Woodstock for the Lost Generation"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. August 4, 1991. Unlike previous festivals such as [[Woodstock Festival|Woodstock]], [[A Gathering of the Tribes]] (also an influence on Lollapalooza) and the [[US Festival]], which were one-time events held at single venues, Lollapalooza toured across the United States and Canada from mid-July until late August 1991.Pope, Janey. [http://www.nme.com/reviews/bloc-party/9846 "Lollapalooza 2008"]. ''[[NME]]''. August 14, 2008. The inaugural lineup was made up of artists from [[alternative rock]] (such as [[Siouxsie and the Banshees]]), [[industrial music]] (such as [[Nine Inch Nails]]) and [[hip hop music|rap]] ([[Ice-T]] rapped and used the platform to launch [[Body Count (band)|Body Count]], his [[heavy metal music|heavy metal]] band). Another key concept was the inclusion of nonmusical features.Parvaz, D. [http://www.seattlepi.com/pop/136299_lollapalooza23.html "Lollapalooza: Then and Now"]. ''[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]''. August 23, 2003. Performers such as the [[Jim Rose Circus|Jim Rose Circus Side Show]], an alternative freak show, and the [[Shaolin Monastery|Shaolin]] monks stretched the boundaries of rock culture. There was a tent for display of art pieces, [[virtual reality]] games, and information tables for political and environmental non-profit groups, promoting counter-culture and political awareness.Wiederhorn, Jon. [http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1459531/20030114/farrell_perry.jhtml "Corporate Sponsors May Be Key To Lollapalooza's Return"]. [[MTV]].com. January 15, 2003. "Basically, I'm bored," Farrell said at the time. "I just want to see things that are unexpected and slightly bizarre. The way [[Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus|Barnum & Bailey]] perceived putting on a show… well, they had a different angle."{{cite magazine|first= James |last= Halbert |title= Nasy habits |magazine= [[Classic Rock (magazine)|Classic Rock]] |issue= 30 |date= August 2001 |page= 59}} ===Success and decline=== It was at Lollapalooza where Farrell coined the term "Alternative Nation".di Perna, Alan. "Brave Noise—The History of Alternative Rock Guitar". ''Guitar World''. December 1995. The explosion of [[alternative rock]] in the early 1990s propelled Lollapalooza forward; the 1992 and 1993 festivals leaned heavily on [[grunge]] and alternative acts, and usually featured an additional rap artist.Nager, Larry. [http://www.enquirer.com/editions/2003/07/13/tem_wwwtem1ahist13.html "A History of Lollapalooza"]. ''[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]]''. July 13, 2003. Punk rock standbys like [[Moshing|mosh pits]] and [[crowd surfing]] became part of the canon of the concerts. These years saw great increases in the participatory nature of the event with the inclusion of booths for open-microphone readings and oratory, television-smashing pits and tattooing and piercing parlors.Moses, Robert. [http://thephoenix.com/Boston/News/24935-Lotta-palooza/ "Lotta-palooza"]. ''[[The Phoenix (newspaper)|The Phoenix]]''. August 14, 1992.du Pre, Jolie. "2009 Lollapalooza Hits Chicago's Grant Park". [[Associated Content]]. August 8, 2009. After 1991, the festival included a second stage (and, in 1996, a third stage) for up-and-coming bands or local acts.Browne, David. [http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,307050,00.html "Lollapalooza's Second Stage"]. ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''. Jun 25, 1993. Attendee complaints of the festival included high ticket prices as well as the high cost for food and water at the shows.Volpi, Matt. [http://www.collegian.psu.edu/archive/1994/08/08-01-94tdc/08-01-94darts-column.asp "Lollapalooza festival alternates cool music with dumb people"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071225182341/http://www.collegian.psu.edu/archive/1994/08/08-01-94tdc/08-01-94darts-column.asp |date=2007-12-25 }}. ''[[The Daily Collegian (Penn State)|The Daily Collegian]]''. August 1, 1994. The festival played at the Alpine Valley festival in East Troy, Wisconsin on August 29, 1992, and also at [[World Music Theater]] in [[Tinley Park, Illinois|Tinley Park, IL]] (near Chicago), where concertgoers ripped up chunks of sod and grass and threw them at each other and at the bands, resulting in tens of thousands of dollars in damages to the venue. Grunge band [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]] was scheduled to headline at the festival in 1994, but the band officially dropped out of the festival on April 7, 1994. Nirvana frontman [[Kurt Cobain]]'s body was discovered in [[Seattle]] the next day. Cobain's widow, [[Courtney Love]], made guest appearances at several shows, including the [[Philadelphia]] show at [[Franklin Delano Roosevelt Park|FDR Park]] (usually taking time given to her by [[The Smashing Pumpkins]] vocalist/guitarist [[Billy Corgan]]), speaking to the crowds about the loss, then singing a minimum of two songs. Farrell worked with rock poster artist [[Jim Evans (artist)|Jim Evans (T.A.Z.)]] to create a series of posters and the complete graphic decoration for the 1994 event, including two 70 foot tall Buddha statues that flanked the main stage. In 1996, Farrell, who had been the soul of the festival, decided to focus his energy to produce his new festival project, [[Enit Festival|ENIT]], and did not participate in producing Lollapalooza. Many fans saw the addition of [[Metallica]] in 1996 as contrary to the festival's prior practice of featuring "non-mainstream" artists, and described the crowds attracted by Metallica as being singularly focused on the headliner without respect for the other performing artists.{{cite journal|last1=Humphreys|first1=Andrew|title=You Am I: "Time is on Our Side"|journal=Rolling Stone Australia|date=October 1996|issue=527|url=http://rollingstoneaus.com/music/post/flashback-you-am-i-time-is-on-our-side/2633-page-3}} Moreover, festival cofounder Farrell felt that Metallica's macho image violated his peaceful vision for the festival,{{cite news|last=Farber|first=Jim|title=Perry Farrell brings back Lollapalooza & legendary band,too|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2003-07-13/entertainment/18248130_1_sacred-acts-classic-albums-strays|newspaper=Daily News|date=July 13, 2003}} for alternative culture of the early 1990s was generally against macho behavior.For example, see Mimi Schippers, ''Rockin' out of the Box: Gender Maneuvering in Alternative Hard Rock''. New Brunswick, New Jersey: Rutgers University Press, 2002. (Especially Chapter 1, and page 14.) Farrell quit the tour in protest.Pillsbury, Glenn T. ''Damage Incorporated: Metallica and the Production of Musical Identity''. New York: Routledge, 2006. See page 143. Responding to the controversial Metallica tour, Lollapalooza made efforts to revive its relevance to audiences. The festival booked eclectic acts such as [[country music|country]] superstar [[Waylon Jennings]] in 1996, and emphasized heavily [[electronica]] groups such as [[The Orb]] and [[The Prodigy]] in 1997. 1997, however, would prove to be the final tour from the initial series of Lollapalooza tours. The festival failed to find a suitable headliner in 1998, and therefore announced Lollapalooza's cancellation.[http://www.allbusiness.com/retail-trade/miscellaneous-retail-retail-stores-not/4613736-1.html "Lollapalooza Cancelled"]. ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''. April 6, 1998. The cancellation served as a signifier of alternative rock's declining popularity. In light of the festival's troubles that year, ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]'' said, "Lollapalooza is as comatose as alternative rock right now."Weisbard, Eric. "This Monkey's Gone to Heaven". ''Spin''. July 1998. ===Revival and rebirth=== In 2003, Farrell reconvened Jane's Addiction and scheduled a new Lollapalooza tour. The festival schedule included venues in 30 cities through July and August. The 2003 tour achieved only marginal success with many fans staying away, presumably because of high ticket prices. Another tour scheduled for 2004 was to consist of a two-day festival taking place in each city. It was cancelled in June due to weak ticket sales across the country. Farrell partnered with Capital Sports & Entertainment (now [[C3 Presents]]), which co-owns and produces the [[Austin City Limits Music Festival]], to produce Lollapalooza.[http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/63172/pixies-weezer-panic-set-for-lollapalooza "Pixies, Weezer, Panic Set For Lollapalooza"]. ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''. CSE, Farrell and the [[William Morris Agency]]—along with Charles Attal Presents—resurrected Lollapalooza as a two-day destination festival in 2005 in [[Grant Park (Chicago)|Grant Park]], [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], with an even greater variety of performers (70 acts on five stages) than that of the touring festival. The festival was generally successful, attracting over 65,000 attendees, despite a 104 degree Fahrenheit Sunday (40 degrees Celsius) [[heat wave]] (two people were hospitalized for heat related illness).Matheson, Whitney. [https://www.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2005-07-23-lollapalooza-blog_x.htm "Live from Lollapalooza: An hour-by-hour report"]. ''[[USA Today]]''. July 23, 2005.Wehrle, Drew. [https://www.spin.com/2005/07/choose-or-lollapalooza/ "Choose or Lollapalooza"]. ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]''. July 25, 2005. It returned to Chicago on August 4–6, 2006. On October 25, 2006, the Chicago Park District and Capital Sports & Entertainment agreed to a five-year, $5 million deal, keeping Lollapalooza at Grant Park in Chicago until 2011.Herrmann, Andrew. [http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4155/is_20061026/ai_n16803612 "Lollapalooza to rock city for 5 more years"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071017171647/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4155/is_20061026/ai_n16803612 |date=2007-10-17 }}. ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' October 26, 2006. Lollapalooza ran August 3–5 in 2007, August 1–3 in 2008, August 7–9 in 2009, August 6–8 in 2010, August 5–7 in 2011, August 3–5 in 2012, August 2–4 in 2013 and August 1–3 in 2014. After a successful 2008 festival, another deal was signed to keep Lollapalooza in Chicago through 2018, guaranteeing the city $13 million.Kot, Greg. [http://leisureblogs.chicagotribune.com/turn_it_up/2009/07/lollapalooza-promoters-still-searching-for-chicago-identity.html "Lollapalooza promoters still searching for Chicago identity"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029190444/http://leisureblogs.chicagotribune.com/turn_it_up/2009/07/lollapalooza-promoters-still-searching-for-chicago-identity.html |date=2013-10-29 }}. Turn It Up (blog). ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''. July 31, 2009. In December 2015, it was announced that Lollapalooza 2016 would be four days long, July 28 to July 31, to celebrate the event's 25th anniversary.{{cite news |first=Alicia |last=Adamczyk |date=December 3, 2015 |title=Lollapalooza 2016 Will Last 4 Days, Cost 20% More |url=http://time.com/money/4135166/lollapalooza-2016-tickets-more-expensive-extra-day/ |website=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=3 December 2015}} In 2017, the festival kicked off on the 3rd of August celebrating its 26th year of existence.{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/pick-your-stage-lollapalooza-2017-w492437|title=Pick Your Stage: Lollapalooza 2017|work=Rolling Stone|access-date=2017-07-20}} In 2018, the festival began on August 2 with a line-up of 180 bands.http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/lollapalooza/ct-lollapalooza-2018-best-and-worst-day-1-20180802-story.html === Tickets and pricing === Tickets to the biggest Lollapalooza edition, in [[Chicago]], are usually sold out extremely quickly. In the 2016 Lollapalooza, the four-day general passes sold out in about one day after they started the sale. The one-day passes sold even more quickly: they were gone less than three hours after organizers revealed the lineup for the four-day music festival.{{Cite news |first=Tracy |last=Swartz |date=March 23, 2016 |title=Lollapalooza 1-day general admission passes sell out in under 3 hours |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/music/ct-lollapalooza-one-day-passes-sell-out-20160323-story.html |work=Chicago Tribune|access-date=2016-09-15}} Because of this phenomenon, people who can not buy the passes try to get them through alternatives sources such as [[Craigslist]] and [[StubHub]]. This is a common practice, although the prices tend to be significantly higher on these websites.{{Cite web|url=http://www.chicagomag.com/Chicago-Magazine/C-Notes/July-2013/Lollapalooza-Tickets/ |title=Where to Buy Lollapalooza Tickets Online |work=[[Chicago (magazine)|Chicago]] |access-date=2016-09-15}} In 2018, the festival experienced unusually slower sales so they released the lineup about 8 hours earlier. In its earliest editions, the official passes used to cost $31.50. However, with its growth and prominent relevance on the music scenario, Lollapalooza passes' prices have been increasing substantially over the years. Comparing the weekend passes for Lollapalooza 2016, which cost $335, not including taxes and fees, with the ones for Lollapalooza 2015, which cost $275, the increase was more than 20%.{{Cite news |last=Adamczyk|first=Alicia |title=Lollapalooza 2016 Will Last 4 Days, Cost 20% More |url=http://time.com/money/4135166/lollapalooza-2016-tickets-more-expensive-extra-day/ |website=[[Money (magazine)|Money]] |access-date=2016-09-15}} The price from 2015 to 2018 has remained the same without any increases. ==International expansion== ===Chile=== In 2010, it was announced that Lollapalooza would debut in South America, with a branch of the festival staged in [[Chile]]'s capital [[Santiago, Chile|Santiago]] on April 2–3, 2011. The [[Lollapalooza Chile]] line up included [[Jane's Addiction]], [[Thirty Seconds to Mars]], [[The National (band)|The National]], [[Manny and Gil The Latin]], [[The Drums]], [[The Killers]], [[Los Bunkers]], [[Ana Tijoux]], [[Javiera Mena]], [[Fatboy Slim]], [[Deftones]], [[Los Plumabits]], [[Cypress Hill]], [[311 (band)|311]], [[The Flaming Lips]] and many others.{{cite web |url=http://lineup.lollapalooza.cl/ |title=Lollapalooza Chile – Santiago – 6 y 7 de Abril 2013 |publisher=Lineup.lollapalooza.cl |date= |accessdate=2013-08-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130512144006/http://lineup.lollapalooza.cl/ |archivedate=2013-05-12 |df= }} The eighth edition in Chile was held on 16–18 March 2018, with [[Pearl Jam]], [[Lana Del Rey]], [[The Killers]], [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]] and [[LCD Soundsystem]] as headliners. ===Brazil=== A Brazilian version of the event was confirmed in 2011, and had its inaugural edition at the [[w:pt:Jockey Club de São Paulo|Jockey Club]] in [[São Paulo]] on April 7 and 8, 2012. In the following year, Lollapalooza was again held at Jockey Club during [[Holy Week]], this time expanding to three days that filled the whole [[Paschal Triduum]] – March 29–31, 2013.{{cite web|author= |url=http://multishow.globo.com/especiais/lollapalooza/materias/lollapalooza-2013-confirma-data-e-local.htm |title=Lollapalooza 2013 confirma data e local – Lollapalooza – MULTISHOW |publisher=Multishow.globo.com |date=2013-02-19 |accessdate=2015-07-31}} The third edition was moved to the [[Autódromo José Carlos Pace]] in São Paulo's borough of [[Interlagos]], happening on April 5 and 6, 2014.{{cite web|author= |url=http://multishow.globo.com/especiais/lollapalooza/materias/lollapalooza-brasil-2014-veja-os-horarios-dos-shows-no-multishow-no-bis-e-na-web.htm |title=Lollapalooza Brasil 2014: veja os horários dos shows no Multishow, no Bis e na web – Lollapalooza – MULTISHOW |publisher=Multishow.globo.com |date=2014-03-31 |accessdate=2015-07-31}} Interlagos remained the festival's home for the following editions, on March 28–29, 2015,{{cite web|url=http://g1.globo.com/musica/lollapalooza/2015/index.html |title=Lollapalooza 2015 |publisher=G1 |date= |accessdate=2015-07-31}} March 12–13, 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.lollapaloozabr.com/lineup-por-dia/ |title=Lollapalooza 2016 – Line-Up |publisher=Lollapalooza Brazil |date= |accessdate=2015-07-31}},March 25–26, 2017, and March 23-24-25, 2018 ===Argentina=== On September 10, 2013, it was announced that the following year the festival will also be held in [[Buenos Aires]], Argentina; thus expanding the South American branch after the festivals in [[Santiago de Chile|Santiago]] and [[São Paulo]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vX7IEz4F2wM |title=Argentina ya es parte de la familia Lollapalooza. Bienvenida! |publisher= Lollapalooza Argentina |date= |accessdate=2013-09-10}} ===Germany=== On November 4, 2014, it was announced that the very first Lollapalooza Festival will be held in Europe, in the German capital of Berlin. It is scheduled for September 12–13, 2015, the proposed location is the historical airport ground of [[Berlin Tempelhof Airport|Berlin-Tempelhof]]. In true Lollapalooza fashion, this urban location serves to incorporate regional partners in presenting international events.{{Cite web|title = Lollapalooza Heading to Berlin in 2015 {{!}} Billboard|url = http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/music-festivals/6304575/lollapalooza-heading-to-berlin-in-2015|website = Billboard|accessdate = 2015-12-13}} In the official press release, festival founder [[Perry Farrell]] stated that, "Berlin's energy, [[Culture in Berlin|vibrant art]], [[German fashion|fashion]] and [[Music in Berlin|music]] scenes are a mirror reflection of what Lollapalooza is all about and I can’t wait to share in this cultural exchange".[http://pitchfork.com/news/57345-lollapalooza-announces-berlin-festival/ Lollapalooza Announces Berlin Festival: Taking place at Tempelhof Airport September 2015], pitchfork.com, 6 November 2014 Lollapalooza Germany was produced by the Lollapalooza U.S. team in addition to Melt! Booking and Festival Republic who have helped run both Reading and Leeds festival in England.{{Cite web|title = Lollapalooza Heading to Berlin in 2015 {{!}} Billboard|url = http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/music-festivals/6304575/lollapalooza-heading-to-berlin-in-2015|website = Billboard|accessdate = 2015-12-13}} The 2016 edition of the festival took place in the [[Treptower Park]] in Berlin, 10–11 September. It drew 70,000 visitors each day.{{Cite web|url=http://www.der-letzte-berliner.de/no-lollapalooza-treptower-park/|title=Neues zu Lollapalooza im Treptower Park |website=Der letzte Berliner |access-date=2016-07-27}} At change.org an on-line petition against the festival in the Treptower Park gathered over 6400 supporters. Citizens from the area have created working groups to stop the festival taking place in the Treptower Park.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bz-berlin.de/berlin/treptow-koepenick/buergerinitiative-will-lollapalooza-festival-verhindern|title=Bürgerinitiative will Lollapalooza-Festival verhindern|access-date=2016-07-27}} There has been little communication with local inhabitants from either festival organizers or local government. People living directly next to the event location have received an invitation to move to a nearby hotel for the duration of the festival. ===Sweden=== On May 30, 2018, [[Live Nation]] announced that the very first scandinavian edition of Lollapalooza will be held in the capital of [[Sweden]], [[Stockholm]], on the 28-29 of June 2019.{{Cite web|url=https://www.livenation.se/news?id=1156911|title=Live Nation announces swedish edition of Lollapalooza|website=Live Nation (swedish)|access-date=2018-05-30}} === Paris === On October 12, 2016, Lollapalooza announced that they would be hosting a festival in Paris, France.{{Cite web|url=http://diymag.com/2016/10/12/lollapalooza-heads-to-paris-in-2017|title=Lollapalooza heads to Paris in 2017|website=DIY|access-date=2017-01-17}} The inaugural edition of this festival will be taking place at the city's [[Longchamp Racecourse]] grounds on July 22–23, 2017. The lineup for Lollapalooza Paris 2017 was announced on January 17, 2017 and includes a lineup featuring [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]] and [[The Weeknd]] as headliners. Following that, the lineup includes the likes of Imagine Dragons, [[Lana Del Rey]], [[DJ Snake]], [[London Grammar]], [[Alt-J]], [[The Roots]], [[Marshmello]], [[Liam Gallagher]], [[Martin Solveig]], [[Skepta]], [[Glass Animals]], [[Milky Chance]], [[Don Diablo]], [[Oliver Heldens]], [[Crystal Fighters]], [[Jauz]], [[Alan Walker (music producer)|Alan Walker]], and many more. ===Chicago=== Chicago's [[Grant Park, Chicago|Grant Park]] was the venue for the 13th edition of Lollapalooza from August 3–6, 2017.{{cite web|last1=Long|first1=Zach|title=Lollapalooza summer music festival|url=https://www.timeout.com/chicago/music/lollapalooza|publisher=TimeOut Chicago|accessdate=6 August 2017|date=6 August 2017}} Among the many entertainers performing during the 4-day festival, there was a small theater troupe which presented all of the over 100 poems found in [[Charles Baudelaire]]'s "[[Les Fleurs du Mal]]." Fifty artists from around the world joined [[Theater Oobleck]] to create "Baudelaire In A Box."{{cite web|last1=Weissman|first1=Dan|title=Poetry Of Failure Comes To Life At Chicago's 'Baudelaire In A Box'|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/08/05/541844712/poetry-of-failure-comes-to-life-at-chicagos-baudelaire-in-a-box|publisher=NPR|accessdate=6 August 2017|date=5 August 2017}} ===Other=== On August 7, 2012, Perry Farrell announced that Lollapalooza will be debuting in [[Tel Aviv, Israel]]. Farrell described Israel as an "international music community that listens to everything we all listen to, but the artists weren’t traveling there so it was an opportunity."{{Cite web|title = Lollapalooza music festival coming to Israel|url = http://www.jta.org/2012/08/08/arts-entertainment/lollapalooza-music-festival-coming-to-israel|website = Jewish Telegraphic Agency|accessdate = 2015-12-13}} The event was scheduled for August 20–22, 2013 in [[Hayarkon Park]], the city's largest urban park.{{cite web|url=https://www.spin.com/2012/08/perry-farrell-will-bring-lollapalooza-2013-israel/|title=Perry Farrell Will Bring Lollapalooza 2013 to Israel|publisher=Daniel Kreps |date=August 7, 2012}} However, the event has been postponed to an unknown date.{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=300707 |title=Report: Lollapalooza festival cancels Israel plans |publisher=Jpost.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-12}} While there was no definitive reasoning for the cancellation of the Israel date, various news sources report there are often financial challenges that attribute to producing a large-scale show with international artists within the political situation in the Mideast.{{Cite web|title = Lollapalooza Israel Canceled: 'We're Sorry' {{!}} Billboard|url = http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1521648/lollapalooza-israel-canceled-were-sorry|website = Billboard|accessdate = 2015-12-13}} ==Criticism== Recording engineer, guitarist, and journalist [[Steve Albini]] has criticized Lollapalooza for its corporatization of popularized "alternative" music. In a 1993 interview, Albini commented:
Lollapalooza is the worst example of corporate encroachment into what is supposed to be the underground. It is just a large scale marketing of bands that pretend to be alternative but are in reality just another facet of the mass cultural exploitation scheme. I have no appreciation or affection for those bands and I have no interest in that whole circle. If Lollapalooza had [[The Jesus Lizard|Jesus Lizard]] and the [[Melvins]] and [[Fugazi]] and [[Slint]] then you could make a case that it was actually people on the vanguard of music. What it really is the most popular bands on MTV that are not heavy metal.{{cite web |url=http://obsolete.com/convulsion/interviews/convulse/bigblack.html |title=Steve Albini 1993 |publisher=Obsolete.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19981205205919/http://www.obsolete.com/convulsion/interviews/convulse/bigblack.html |archivedate=1998-12-05 |df= }}
Both [[The Jesus Lizard]] and the [[Melvins]] have subsequently performed at the event.{{cite web |url=http://lineup.lollapalooza.com/past/1995 |title=Lollapalooza 1995 |publisher=Lineup.lollapalooza.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130806172859/http://lineup.lollapalooza.com/past/1995 |archivedate=2013-08-06 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://lineup.lollapalooza.com/past/1996 |title=Lollapalooza 1996 |publisher=Lineup.lollapalooza.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130806185026/http://lineup.lollapalooza.com/past/1996 |archivedate=2013-08-06 |df= }} In April 2010, it was reported that [[Illinois Attorney General]] [[Lisa Madigan]] had launched an [[antitrust]] investigation into the festival for imposing [[radius clause]]s on acts, contractually stipulating that they could not perform in cities within 300 miles of Chicago—including cities as far as [[Detroit]], [[Indianapolis]], and [[Milwaukee]]—for up to six months prior, and three months after Lollapalooza.{{cite web|title=Attorney General Investigates Lollapalooza|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/attorney-general-investigates-lollapalooza-20100625|website=Rolling Stone|accessdate=24 June 2014}}{{cite web|title=So maybe Coachella's booking rules aren't so egregious after all|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2010/06/so-maybe-coachellas-booking-rules-arent-so-egregious-after-all.html|website=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=24 June 2014}} ==Lineups by year== {{Main article|List of Lollapalooza lineups by year}} ==See also== {{Portal|Rock music}} * [[Alternative rock]] * [[Alternative metal]] * [[Grunge]] * [[List of historic rock festivals]] ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * {{Official website|http://www.lollapalooza.com }} * [http://www.lollapaloozade.com/ Lollapalooza Berlin/Germany website] * [http://www.lollapaloozabr.com/ Lollapalooza Brazil website] * [http://www.lollapaloozacl.com/ Lollapalooza Chile website] * [http://www.lollapaloozaar.com/ Lollapalooza Argentina website] * [https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/lollapalooza-official-2014/id507776133?mt=8 Lollapalooza 2014 iPhone app] {{Rock festivals}} {{Grant Park}} {{Perry Farrell}} {{Alternative rock}} [[Category:Concert tours]] [[Category:Festivals in Chicago]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1991]] [[Category:Rock festivals in the United States]] [[Category:Music of Chicago]] [[Category:Alternative rock festivals]] [[Category:Music festivals established in 1991]] [[Category:1991 establishments in the United States]]

revision.comment: Changed details of 2016 dates to reflect ongoing nature of festival
revision.text:
The '''London Games Festival''' is an annual [[video gaming]] [[festival]] for both consumers and trade specialists held annually in April. The Festival is part of [[Games London]] an initiative to boost investment and skills in the capital, delivered by [[Ukie]] and [[Film London]] and funded by £1.2 million investment from the [[Mayor of London]].
==2016 Events==
The 2016 London Games Festival will include 15 official events across 10 different venues in the capital. Highlights include:
* Now Play This (1 April - 3 April), a weekend of games and play in a special consumer exhibition at [[Somerset House]] [http://games.london/now-play-this-2/]. Dedicated site: [http://nowplaythis.net/] * The brand-new Games Finance Market (5 April - 7 April), connecting up-and-coming interactive content talent with global investors and partners from across sectors * A series of ‘LGF @ BFI’ talks (4 April) programmed and presented by London Games Festival in partnership with [[BFI Southbank]] * The inclusion of already influential global events: British Academy Games Awards (7 April) and Gamer Network’s Rezzed (7 April - 9 April) * A cultural programme that helps change perceptions of video games and champions the medium as a cutting-edge art form - plus a London Games Fringe of alternative and smaller events * EGX Rezzed (7 April - 9 April), at Tobacco Dock [http://www.egx.net/rezzed] * The Games Europe Plays (2 April - 10 April), digital games exhibition for young people and families with games from Europe. [http://www.finnish-institute.org.uk] [http://europe.org.uk]. Twitter hashtag #GamesEU. * Games Finance Market (6-7 April), at Grange City Hotel [http://games.london/games-finance-market/] * VR Summit (4 April), at BFI Southwark [http://games.london/virtual-reality-summit/]
==Previous Years==
A previous London Games Festival ran until 2012 featuring a series of diverse events from the world of interactive entertainment. Video games publishers, developers, partners, personalities, trade organisations, media organisations and individuals were all involved in the week-long celebrations. The LGF provided the industry with the opportunity to showcase creativity and artistry, from script-writers to animators, musicians to programmers.
The Festival also worked to enhance perceptions of interactive entertainment and the industry by engaging with existing institutional advocates ([[BAFTA]], [[ELSPA]], [[DfES]], [[Department for Culture, Media and Sport|DCMS]], [[BBFC]], [[Department of Trade and Industry (United Kingdom)|DTI]], LDA) and illustrating compelling and positive research while promoting future vision and horizons of the games industry. Alongside the week of media and/or consumer-facing events were a number of B2B events organised by the industry’s trade bodies and other organisations.
The festival was also complemented by a Fringe, an offshoot of the more mainstream and commercially focused Festival, with an abundance of interesting and diverse events for games and non-gamers alike. Highlights in 2007 included:
The [[Soho Project]], that offered players a chance to take part in a mass ‘reality game’ on the streets of [[Soho, London|Soho]], via the website<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.fictionalmedia.co.uk |title = Fictional Media : The Soho Project |accessdate = 2008-06-27 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080703202723/http://fictionalmedia.co.uk/ |archivedate = 2008-07-03 |df = }}</ref>
Games AV - a live concert, screening and club night features musicians, DJs, VJs, filmmakers, animators and digital artists whose work has been shaped by video games culture.
Sense of Play ran annually as part of the Fringe from 2005 - 2007. Each event was a one-day symposium which looked at the future of games design in its broadest sense featuring some of the most inspiring voices working in, around and beyond the games industry. The event was directed, curated and produced by Toby Barnes and Jon Weinbren. Plans are afoot for a relaunch which will look at the interplays and crossovers between games, film, television, theatre and other creative industries.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.senseofplay.com |title = senseofplay.com |accessdate = 2008-06-27}}</ref>
Also in 2007, London Games Skills Week offered a week long series of seminars designed to attract new talent into the games industry from a broad spectrum of creative disciplines. A pop-up Games Fringe Cafe and drop-in lounge was set up at Soho TV and post-production training facility 01zero-one which was open to all festival attendees. 01zero-one also housed the ZeroGamer exhibition which featured "...games that play themselves, video documents of in-game performance, game engine experiments and challenging documentaries on gameplay."
==References== <references/>
==External links== * http://games.london * http://ukie.org.uk/GamesLondon
[[Category:Festivals in London]] [[Category:Video gaming in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Video game festivals]] [[Category:Annual events in London]]

{{Infobox recurring event | name = <!--Uses page name if omitted--> | native_name = | logo = Lost 80's Live Logo.png | logo_caption = | image = | imagesize = frameless | location = Touring Concert | years_active = 14 | first = August 23, 2003 | last = | participants = | genre = [[New wave music|New wave]], [[electronic music|electronic]], [[synthpop]] | budget = | patron = | website = {{url|lost80slive.com}} | footnotes = }}
'''Lost 80's Live''' is a collection of musical artists from the time period of the 1980s that perform a [[live concert]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wierzbicki|first1=Kevin|title=A Flock of Seagulls fly into town with Lost '80s Live show|url=http://www.axs.com/a-flock-of-seagulls-fly-into-town-with-lost-80s-live-show-17947|website=AXS.com|publisher=AXS.com|accessdate=29 September 2014}}</ref> The [[concert tour]] usually consists of 7 to 9 bands that span the [[music genre]]s of [[new wave music|new wave]], [[synthpop]], [[rock music|rock]], [[pop music|pop]] and [[electronic music]]. Bands and artists that have performed in the Lost 80's Live concert tour include [[ABC (band)|ABC]], [[Thompson Twins]]' [[Tom Bailey (musician)|Tom Bailey]], [[A Flock of Seagulls]], [[Men Without Hats]], [[Dramarama]], [[Devo]], [[General Public]], [[Trans-X]], [[Anything Box]], [[Gary Myrick]], [[Real Life (band)|Real Life]], [[Animotion]], [[Nu Shooz]], [[Modern English (band)|Modern English]], [[The Flirts]], [[The Escape Club]], [[Gene Loves Jezebel]], [[Wang Chung (band)|Wang Chung]], [[Cutting Crew]], [[Berlin (band)|Berlin]], [[The English Beat]], [[Naked Eyes]], [[Missing Persons (band)|Missing Persons]], [[When in Rome (band)|When in Rome UK]], [[Bow Wow Wow]], [[The Motels]], and [[Bourgeois Tagg]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ward|first1=Jamie|title="Lost 80’s Live Comes To Downtown Long Beach on Sat, August 24" Sat, August 24"|url=http://www.musicnewschicago.com/lost-80s-live-comes-to-downtown-long-beach-on-sat-august-24/|website=Musicnewschicago.com|publisher=Music News Chicago|accessdate=17 October 2014}}</ref>
==History of shows== May 29, 2007: [[House of Blues]] presents Lost 80's Live featuring Animotion, When in Rome, Dramarama, and Gene Loves Jezebel.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wire|first1=PegNews|title=Two for One Tuesday: Lost 80’s Live at HOB|url=http://go.dallasnews.com/news/2007/may/29/two-one-tuesday-lost-80s-live-hob/|accessdate=17 October 2014|publisher=Dallas Morning News|date=29 May 2007}}</ref>
April 25, 2008: Lost 80's Live goes international playing the [[Araneta Coliseum]] in the Philippines.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Zafra|first1=Jessica|title=Sad, sadder, saddest|url=http://www.philstar.com/young-star/58128/sad-sadder-saddest|accessdate=17 October 2014|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=25 April 2008}}</ref>
May 23, 2009: Lost 80's Live plays the 106.9 The Point B-Day Bash at [[Sam Houston Race Park]] in [[Houston, Texas]] with A Flock of Seagulls, Dramarama, Gene Loves Jezebel, and When in Rome.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hlavaty|first1=Craig|title=Summer Sounds Enough shows to keep concertgoers busy all season long|url=http://www.houstonpress.com/2009-05-21/culture/summer-guide-summer-sounds/|accessdate=17 October 2014|publisher=Houston Press|date=21 May 2009}}</ref>
August 24, 2013: Iconic [[KROQ]] radio DJ [[Richard Blade]] was booked to host the Lost 80's Live in [[Long Beach, California]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Smith|first1=Ken|title=Legendary DJ Richard Blade to host Lost 80′s Live Long Beach|url=http://highwiredaze.com/wordpress/richardblade|website=http://highwiredaze.com|publisher=High Wire Daze Music Magazine|accessdate=24 October 2014}}</ref>
August 26, 2014: Animotion were highlighted in the news and played the Lost 80's Live on September 3, 2014 at the Wild Horse Casino in [[Chandler, Arizona]] alongside Men Without Hats, Naked Eyes, A Flock of Seagulls, The Flirts, Bow Wow Wow, and Dramarama.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cordova|first1=Randy|title=8/30: Animotion highlights 'Lost '80s Live'|url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/entertainment/music/2014/08/25/animotion-lost-80s-live/14580341/|accessdate=17 October 2014|publisher=The Arizona Republic|date=26 August 2014}}</ref>
October 16, 2015: Lost 80's Live celebrated its 10th anniversary at the House of Blues in Anaheim, CA with a concert featuring Wang Chung, Animotion, Gene Loves Jezebel, Dramarama, Naked Eyes, and [[Boys Don't Cry (band)|Boys Don't Cry]] with [[Annabella Lwin]] of Bow Wow Wow. Special performances were made by Clive Farrington and Rob Juarez of When in Rome, Anything Box, the original [[Mary Jane Girls]], Maxi and Cheri with a special appearance and performance by [[Benny Mardones]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hixon|first1=Michael|title=6/1/2015: Redondo Beach's Rob Juarez brings back classic 80s music|url=http://tbrnews.com/lifestyle/redondo-beach-s-rob-juarez-brings-back-classic-s-music/article_944516da-049f-11e5-8386-cf5fe766b445.html|publisher=The Beach Reporter }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20141128021200/http://lost80slive.com/ Lost 80's official web site] * [http://tbrnews.com/lifestyle/redondo-beach-s-rob-juarez-brings-back-classic-s-music/article_944516da-049f-11e5-8386-cf5fe766b445.html/ Lost 80's Live 10th Anniversary concert at House Of Blues Downtown Disney, CA]

revision.comment: Removed unnecessary statement. They are mentioned as 'reports' and 'legends'. The idea that a ghost story could ever be validated as fact is nonsensical.
revision.text:
[[File:Minsden Chapel 2 (4648214892).jpg|thumb|right|The ruined Minsden Chapel in 2010]] [[File:Reginald Hine Minsden Ghost 1907.jpg|thumb|160px|right|T.W. Latchmore's hoax photograph of the Minsden ghost (1907)]] [[File:Reginald Hine Minsden Chapel.jpg|thumb|160px|right|Memorial to [[Reginald Hine]] at Minsden Chapel]] '''Minsden Chapel''' is an isolated ruined [[chapel]] in the fields above the hamlet of Chapelfoot, near [[Preston, Hertfordshire|Preston]], [[Hertfordshire]]. Today it is a roofless shell, partly surrounded by a small wood, and accessible only by footpath. It is a Scheduled Ancient Monument and is Grade II Listed.<ref>{{NHLE|num=1347462|desc=|accessdate=17 May 2013}}</ref>
==History==
It was built in the 14th century, and by the 17th century had fallen into disrepair. Marriages continued here into the 18th century, until the crumbling masonry became too dangerous. One story says that a piece of falling stonework knocked the prayer-book out of a [[curate]]'s hand during the marriage ceremony of Enoch West and Mary Horn on the 11th of July 1738.<ref>Puttick, B. ''Ghosts of Hertfordshire'' (1994, Countryside Books) - chapter 14: "The Haunting of Minsden Chapel" p83 {{ISBN|1-85306-292-8}}</ref>
In the 20th century the chapel was closely associated with the historian [[Reginald Hine]] from nearby [[Hitchin]]. He frequently visited here, and eventually obtained a lifetime lease of the building from the vicars of Hitchin. So fond of the chapel was he, that he even bid ''"trespassers and sacrilegious persons take warning, for I will proceed against them with the utmost rigour of the law, and, after my death and burial, I will endeavour, in all ghostly ways, to protect and haunt its hallowed walls".''<ref>Hine, Reginald L. ''The History of Hitchin'', Vol II page 38 (1929, Allen and Unwin (London))</ref> Contrary to popular belief Hine is not buried at Minsden. His body was cremated at [[Golders Green Crematorium|Golders Green]] (London) and his ashes were subsequently scattered at the chapel. His family erected a memorial stone at the site, which was subsequently re-laid in its current grave-like horizontal position by them after it was damaged by vandals in the early 1980s.<ref>Whitmore, Richard ''The Ghosts of Reginald Hine'' (2007, Mattingley Press (Hitchin))</ref>
In 1907, Thomas William Latchmore, a local professional photographer and friend of Hine, took a photograph of a [[ghost]]ly monk at the Chapel. Rumours of [[paranormal activity]] first appeared around this time. The haunting most frequently reported is that of a single monk climbing stairs (which no longer exist) to the north-east area of the chapel; this is said to occur at midnight on [[Halloween]]. Other reported experiences include the sighting of a glowing cross on the wall, and the hearing of distant music or the ringing of the stolen bells. Legends also exist of a lost subterranean tunnel built during the time of the Crusades that extends to nearby [[Temple Dinsley]] and another of a murdered nun.
In an interview given in 1930 to [[Elliott O'Donnell]], a well-known contemporary writer on occult matters, Latchmore finally admitted that his 'Minsden Ghost' photograph was a hoax. He explained that the picture was the deliberate result of an experiment in the techniques of [[multiple exposure|double exposures]], a subject that interested him greatly at the time. Although Latchmore refused to disclose the identity of the individual who had posed as the ghostly figure, it seems likely that it was a young man well known for practical jokes, Latchmore's good friend Reggie Hine. Hine re-published the photograph in 1929 in his ''History of Hitchin'' but never admitted it was a fake nor his own part in it.<ref>Whitmore, Richard ''The Ghosts of Reginald Hine'' pp113-116</ref>
Paranormal investigator [[Peter Underwood (parapsychologist)|Peter Underwood]] once spent a night there in the late 1940s, during which he claimed to have heard the sound of distant music and to have seen a white glowing cross on one of the walls, which disappeared and then reappeared, although he suggested "it could possibly have been a trick of the moonlight, as a full moon was shining down through the trees at the time".<ref>{{Cite book|url=|title=No Common Task: Autobiography of a Ghost Hunter|last=Underwood|first=Peter|date=1983-11-16|publisher=George G.Harrap & Co Ltd|year=|isbn=9780245539596|edition=1st|location=London|page=53|language=English}}</ref>
The iconic arch of Minsden Chapel finally fell in 2008 due to time and erosion from the elements. In 2017, it was reported that the Church Commissioners for England, who own the site, were intending selling it to a "surrounding landowner", sparking fears that the public could lose access to the site.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thecomet.net/news/are-church-plans-to-sell-off-14th-century-grade-ii-listed-haunted-chapel-near-hitchin-an-own-ghoul-1-5013140|title=Are church plans to sell off 14th century Grade II-listed ‘haunted chapel’ near Hitchin an own ghoul?|last=Yousif|first=Layth|date=11 May 2017|work=[[The Comet (newspaper)|The Comet]]|accessdate=28 May 2017}}</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Minsden Chapel Hitchin 2016.jpg|Minsden Chapel in 2016 File:MinsdenChapelMay2004.jpg|The overgrown ruins of Minsden chapel, in May 2004 </gallery>
==References== {{Commons category}} {{Reflist}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox criminal | name = Paul Manafort | image = Paul Manafort at 2016 RNC.jpg | caption = Manafort speaks with media prior to the [[2016 Republican National Convention]]. | birth_name = Paul John Manafort Jr. | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1949|04|01}} | birth_place = [[New Britain, Connecticut]], U.S. | residence = | nationality = | education = [[Georgetown University]] ([[Bachelor of Science|BS]], [[Juris Doctor|JD]]) | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | criminal_charge = Five counts of [[tax fraud]], two counts of [[bank fraud]], and one count of failing to disclose a hidden foreign bank account; two counts of [[Conspiracy (criminal)|conspiracy]] | conviction_penalty = | conviction_status = Found guilty on 8 counts; pleaded guilty to counts of conspiracy; scheduled to be sentenced on February 8, 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/19/us/politics/paul-manafort-russia-mueller-sentencing.html|title=Manafort to Be Sentenced in February in Financial Fraud Case|publisher=|accessdate=November 27, 2018}}</ref> | spouse = {{marriage|Kathleen Bond|1978-08-12}} | children = 2 }}
'''Paul John Manafort Jr.''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|m|æ|n|ə|f|ɔːr|t}}; born April 1, 1949) is an American [[Lobbying|lobbyist]], [[Political consulting|political consultant]], lawyer, and convicted felon. A [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]], he joined [[Donald Trump]]'s [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|presidential campaign]] team in March 2016, and was campaign chairman from June to August 2016. On August 21, 2018, Manafort was convicted of five counts of [[tax fraud]], two counts of [[bank fraud]], and one count of failure to report foreign bank accounts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/manafort-jury-suggests-it-cannot-come-to-a-consensus-on-a-single-count/2018/08/21/a2478ac0-a559-11e8-a656-943eefab5daf_story.html|title=Manafort convicted on 8 counts; mistrial declared on 10 others|last=Zapotosky|first=Matt|last2=Bui|first2=Lynh|date=August 21, 2018|website=Washington Post|language=en|access-date=2018-08-21|last3=Jackman|first3=Tom|last4=Barrett|first4=Devlin}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/aug/21/paul-manafort-convicted-of-tax-in-virginia-federal-court |title=Paul Manafort: Trump's ex-campaign chair guilty on eight counts of fraud |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=August 21, 2018 |accessdate=August 22, 2018 |first=Tom |last=McCarthy |first2=Ben |last2=Jacobs }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/21/us/politics/paul-manafort-trial-verdict.html |title=Paul Manafort, Trump’s Former Campaign Chairman, Guilty of 8 Counts |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=August 21, 2018 |access-date=September 15, 2018 |first=Sharon |last=LaFraniere }}</ref> On September 14, 2018, he pleaded guilty to an additional two counts of [[Conspiracy (criminal)|conspiracy]], per a plea deal in which he also agreed to cooperate with the [[Special Counsel investigation (2017-present)|Special Counsel investigation]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/paul-manafort-pleads-guilty-mueller-probe-n909576|title=Paul Manafort expected to plead guilty in Mueller probe|work=NBC News|access-date=2018-09-14|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/14/us/politics/manafort-plea-deal.html |title=Paul Manafort Agrees to Cooperate With Special Counsel; Pleads Guilty to Reduced Charges |last=LaFraniere |first=Sharon |date=September 14, 2018 |work=The New York Times |access-date=September 14, 2018 |language=en-US}}</ref> On November 26, 2018, [[Robert Mueller]] reported that Manafort violated his plea deal by repeatedly lying to investigators.<ref>{{cite news |last1=LaFraniere |first1=Sharon |title=Manafort Breached Plea Deal by Repeatedly Lying, Mueller Says |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/26/us/politics/mueller-paul-manafort-cooperation.html |accessdate=27 November 2018 |publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' |date=November 26, 2018}}</ref>
Manafort was an adviser to the U.S. presidential campaigns of Republicans [[Gerald Ford]], [[Ronald Reagan]], [[George H. W. Bush]], and [[Bob Dole]]. In 1980, he co-founded the Washington, D.C.-based lobbying firm [[Black, Manafort, Stone and Kelly|Black, Manafort & Stone]], along with principals [[Charles R. Black Jr.]], and [[Roger J. Stone]],<ref name="NYT_Edsall_2012">{{cite web |url=http://campaignstops.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/05/14/the-lobbyist-in-the-gray-flannel-suit/ |title=The Lobbyist in the Gray Flannel Suit |first=Thomas B. |last=Edsall |date=May 14, 2012 |access-date=June 16, 2017 |series=The Opinion Page |work=The New York Times Blog}}</ref><ref name="NYT_1989_BMSK">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/21/us/a-political-power-broker.html |title=A Political Power Broker |date=June 20, 1989 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=June 16, 2017 |location=Washington}}</ref><ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://www.fara.gov/docs/3600-Exhibit-AB-19851101-D0XCT601.pdf|title=Registration with the Foreign Agents Registration Act (FARA)|last=|first=|date=August 1982|work=|publisher=[[United States Department of Justice]]|format=PDF|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180615191143/https://www.fara.gov/docs/3600-Exhibit-AB-19851101-D0XCT601.pdf|archive-date=June 15, 2018|dead-url=No|access-date=June 16, 2017}}</ref> joined by [[Peter G. Kelly]] in 1984.<ref name="Choate_1990">{{cite book |title=Agents of Influence |first=Pat |last=Choate |isbn=0671743392 |date=1990 |publisher=Simon and Schuster |pages=307}}</ref>
