Manafort often lobbied on behalf of foreign leaders such as former [[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]], former dictator of the [[Philippines]] [[Ferdinand Marcos]], former dictator of [[Zaire]] [[Mobutu Sese Seko]], and [[Angola]]n [[Guerrilla warfare|guerrilla]] [[UNITA|leader]] [[Jonas Savimbi]].<ref name="Mufson-WP"/><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/apr/27/paul-manafort-donald-trump-campaign-past-clients|title=Trump's new right-hand man has history of controversial clients and deals|last=Stone|first=Peter|date=April 27, 2016|work=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=July 24, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2016-04-13/trump-just-hired-his-next-scandal-lobbyist-paul-manafort|title=Trump Just Hired His Next Scandal|last=Lake|first=Eli|date=April 13, 2016|website=Bloomberg View|access-date=July 24, 2016}}</ref> Lobbying to serve the interests of foreign governments requires registration with the [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] under the [[Foreign Agents Registration Act]] (FARA); however, as of June 2, 2017, Manafort had not registered.<ref name="Time_2017_Mueller"/><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.com/rachel-maddow/watch/exclusive-doj-won-t-say-if-sessions-is-recused-on-manafort-942096451556|title=Exclusive: DoJ won't say if Sessions is recused on Manafort|publisher=MSNBC|access-date=May 13, 2017}}</ref><ref name=":3" /> On June 27, he retroactively registered as a [[foreign agent]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/former-trump-campaign-chairman-paul-manafort-files-as-foreign-agent-for-ukraine-work/2017/06/27/8322b6ac-5b7b-11e7-9fc6-c7ef4bc58d13_story.html|title=Former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort files as foreign agent for Ukraine work|last=Hamburger|first=Tom|website=The Washington Post|access-date=June 28, 2017}}</ref>
Manafort has been under investigation by multiple federal agencies. The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) has had an active criminal investigation on him since 2014 regarding business dealings while he was lobbying for Yanukovych. He is also a person of interest in the FBI [[counterintelligence]] probe looking into the [[Government of Russia|Russian government's]] [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections|interference in the 2016 United States presidential election]].
On October 27, 2017, Manafort and his business associate [[Rick Gates (political consultant)|Rick Gates]] were indicted by a [[District of Columbia]] grand jury on multiple charges arising from his consulting work for the pro-Russian government of Viktor Yanukovych in [[Ukraine]] before Yanukovych's [[2014 Ukrainian revolution|overthrow in 2014]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/30/us/politics/special-counsel-indictments.html|title=What It Means: The Indictment of Manafort and Gates|last=Savage|first=Charlie|date=October 30, 2017|work=The New York Times|accessdate=October 30, 2017}}</ref> The indictment had been requested by Robert Mueller's special investigation unit.<ref name="Surrender">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/30/us/politics/paul-manafort-indicted.html|title=Paul Manafort, Who Once Ran Trump Campaign, Surrenders to F.B.I.|last1=Apuzzo|first1=Matt|date=October 30, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=October 30, 2017}}</ref><ref name="IndictmentText"/> Manafort surrendered and was released on bail confined to house arrest.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.msnbc.com/rachel-maddow/watch/manafort-placed-under-house-arrest-weight-of-evidence-cited-1185325635929|title=Manafort placed under house arrest; weight of evidence cited|work=NBC News|access-date=March 26, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> In June 2018, additional charges were filed against Manafort for obstruction of justice and witness tampering that are alleged to have occurred while he was under house arrest, and he was ordered to jail.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/15/us/politics/manafort-bail-revoked-jail.html|title=Judge Orders Manafort Jailed Before Trial, Citing New Obstruction Charges|last=LaFraniere|first=Sharon|date=June 15, 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=June 15, 2018}}</ref> In February 2018, a new set of indictments were filed in the Eastern District of Virginia, alleging tax evasion and bank fraud.<ref name="auto1">{{citation|url=https://www.sltrib.com/news/nation-world/2018/02/22/mueller-files-32-new-charges-in-manafort-gates-case/|access-date=June 12, 2018|work=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|date=February 22, 2018|title=Mueller files 32 new charges in Manafort, Gates case}}</ref> Manafort was brought to trial on those charges in August 2018, and on August 21 he was convicted on eight out of eighteen charges of tax and bank fraud. A [[mistrial]] was declared on the other ten, with one juror stating there had been a single holdout on those charges.<ref name = guilty/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/23/us/manafort-juror-paula-duncan.html|title=Manafort Jury Holdout Blocked Guilty Verdicts on 10 of 18 Charges, Juror Says|publisher=|accessdate=August 23, 2018}}</ref> A separate trial on the District of Columbia charges was scheduled for September 2018,<ref name = convicted>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/paul-manafort-pleads-not-guilty-charges-filed-after-gates-plea-n851936|first=Charlie |last=Gile |first2=Tracy |last2=Connor |title=Judge reprimands Paul Manafort for speaking out after Gates plea deal|publisher=[[NBC News]]|access-date=February 28, 2018|language=en}}</ref> though his plea deal with Mueller has negated the need for another trial.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-45526341|first=Anthony|last=Zurcher|title=Winners and losers from the Manafort plea deal|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=September 15, 2018|date=September 14, 2018}}</ref>
==Early life and education== On April 1, 1949, Manafort was born as Paul John Manafort Jr.<ref name="rwr">Reagan, Ronald (May 13, 1981)."[http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=43806 Nomination of Paul J. Manafort, Jr., To Be a Member of the Board of Directors of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110522041546/http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=43806# |date=May 22, 2011 }}." In Gerhard Peters and John T. Woolley, ''The American Presidency Project''. Hosted online by the University of California, Santa Barbara, CA. www.presidency.ucsb.edu. Retrieved August 1, 2016.</ref> in the city of [[New Britain, Connecticut]]. Manafort's parents are Antoinette Mary Manafort (née Cifalu; 1921–2003) and Paul John Manafort Sr. (1923–2013).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/hartfordcourant/obituary.aspx?n=antoinette-manafort-cifalu&pid=868617&fhid=4179|title=Antoinette (Cifalu) Manafort's Obituary on Hartford Courant|publisher=[[Legacy.com]]|date=March 18, 2003|accessdate=August 2, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Legacy.com-PJM-Sr">"[http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/hartfordcourant/obituary.aspx?pid=162629782 Paul J. Manafort]" (January 25, 2013). Obituary by ''Hartford Courant'' [[Legacy.com]]. Retrieved August 1, 2016.</ref> His grandfather immigrated to the United States from Italy in the early 20th century, settling in Connecticut.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2016/08/15/5-things-you-need-to-know-about-paul-manafort/|title=5 Things You Need to Know About Paul Manafort|author=Tully|first=Shawn|date=August 15, 2016|website=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]|access-date=}}</ref> He founded the construction company New Britain House Wrecking Company in 1919 (later renamed Manafort Brothers Inc.).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.manafort.com/pages/about-us.asp|title=About Us|publisher=Manafort Brothers Inc.|access-date=October 30, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171103015229/http://www.manafort.com/pages/about-us.asp#|archive-date=November 3, 2017|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> His father served in the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] combat engineers during World War II<ref name="Legacy.com-PJM-Sr"/> and was [[Mayor of New Britain, Connecticut|mayor of New Britain]] from 1965 to 1971.<ref name="Mufson-WP">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/in-business-as-in-politics-trump-adviser-no-stranger-to-controversial-figures/2016/04/26/970db232-08c7-11e6-b283-e79d81c63c1b_story.html|title=Inside Trump adviser Manafort's world of politics and global financial dealmaking|last1=Mufson|first1=Steven|date=April 26, 2016|work=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=July 24, 2016|last2=Hamburger|first2=Tom}}</ref> His father was indicted in a corruption scandal in 1981 but not convicted.<ref name="risefall">{{cite news |last=LaFraniere |first=Sharon|last2=Vogel|first2=Kenneth P.|last3=Haberman|first3=Maggie |date=August 12, 2018 |title=The Rise and Fall of Paul Manafort: Greed, Deception and Ego |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/12/us/politics/manafort-trump-trial.html |work=New York Times |location= |access-date=August 14, 2018 }}</ref>
In 1967, Manafort graduated from St. Thomas Aquinas High School, a private [[Roman Catholic]] secondary school, since closed, in [[New Britain, Connecticut|New Britain]], [[Connecticut]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/01/us/paul-manafort-connecticut-new-britain.html |title=Paul Manafort's Roots Run Deep in a Connecticut City |work=[[The New York Times]] |author=Yee, Vivian |date=November 1, 2017 |accessdate=June 15, 2018}}</ref> He attended [[Georgetown University]], where he received his [[B.S.]] in [[business administration]] in 1971 and his [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] in 1974.<ref>{{cite web|last=Levy|first=Gabrielle|date=March 29, 2017|title=10 Things You Didn't Know About Paul Manafort|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2017-03-29/10-things-you-didnt-know-about-paul-manafort|website=US News and World Report|accessdate=July 31, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Peters|first1=Gerhard|last2=Woolley|first2=John|title=Ronald Reagan's Nomination of Paul J. Manafort, Jr., To Be a Member of the Board of Directors of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=43806|website=The American Presidency Project|accessdate=February 23, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180613014841/http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=43806#|archive-date=June 13, 2018|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==Career== Between 1977 and 1980, Manafort practiced law with the firm of [[Vorys, Sater, Seymour and Pease]] in Washington, D.C.<ref name="rwr"/>
===Political activities=== [[File:Ford B1541 NLGRF photo contact sheet (1976-09-18)(Gerald Ford Library) (cropped9).jpg|thumb|Manafort greeting [[President of the United States|President]] [[Gerald Ford]] in 1976]] [[File:Reagan Contact Sheet C11150 (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|Manafort with [[President of the United States|President]] [[Ronald Reagan]] and then [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[George H. W. Bush]] in 1982]] [[File:Reagan Contact Sheet C39691 (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|Manafort greeting [[President of the United States|President]] [[Ronald Reagan]] in 1987]] In 1976, Manafort was the delegate-hunt coordinator for eight states for the [[Gerald Ford|President Ford Committee]]; the overall Ford delegate operation was run by [[James Baker|James A. Baker III]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/19/us/politics/potential-gop-convention-fight-puts-older-hands-in-sudden-demand.html|title=Potential G.O.P. Convention Fight Puts Older Hands in Sudden Demand|last=Peters|first=Jeremy W.|date=April 18, 2016|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=April 20, 2016}}</ref> Between 1978 and 1980, Manafort was the southern coordinator for [[Ronald Reagan presidential campaign, 1980|Ronald Reagan's presidential campaign]], and the deputy political director at the [[Republican National Committee]]. After Reagan's election in November 1980, he was appointed Associate Director of the [[Presidential Personnel Office]] at the [[White House]]. In 1981, he was nominated to the [[Board of directors|Board of Directors]] of the [[Overseas Private Investment Corporation]].<ref name="rwr"/>
Manafort was an adviser to the presidential campaigns of [[Republican Party (United States) presidential primaries, 1988|George H. W. Bush in 1988]]<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/presidential-races/274511-trump-hires-strategist-paul-manafort|title = Trump hires strategist Paul Manafort|last = Savransky|first = Rebecca|date = March 28, 2016|website = TheHill|access-date = March 31, 2016}}</ref> and [[United States presidential election, 1996|Bob Dole]] in 1996.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/06/25/AR2008062502858.html?sid=ST2008062502934|title=Top McCain Adviser Has Found Success Mixing Money, Politics|last=Mosk|first=Matthew|date=June 26, 2008|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=March 31, 2016}}</ref>
====Chairman of Donald Trump's 2016 campaign==== In February 2016, Manafort approached [[Donald Trump]] through a mutual friend, [[Thomas J. Barrack Jr.]] He pointed out his experience advising presidential campaigns in the United States and around the world, described himself as an outsider not connected to the Washington establishment, and offered to work without salary.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/08/us/to-charm-trump-paul-manafort-sold-himself-as-an-affordable-outsider.html?_r=0|title=To Charm Trump, Paul Manafort Sold Himself as an Affordable Outsider|last=Thrush|first=Glenn|date=April 8, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=November 23, 2017}}</ref> In March 2016, he joined [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|Trump's presidential campaign]] to take the lead in getting commitments from convention delegates.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.nytimes.com/politics/first-draft/2016/03/28/donald-trump-hires-paul-manafort-to-lead-delegate-effort/|title = Donald Trump Hires Paul Manafort to Lead Delegate Effort|last = Burns|first = Alexander|last2 = Haberman|first2 = Maggie|date = March 28, 2016|website = The New York Times – First Draft|access-date = March 31, 2016}}</ref> On June 20, 2016, Trump fired campaign manager [[Corey Lewandowski]] and promoted Manafort to the position. Manafort gained control of the daily operations of the campaign as well as an expanded $20 million budget, hiring decisions, advertising, and media strategy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2016/04/how-paul-manafort-took-over-the-trump-campaign.html|title=How Paul Manafort Took Over the Trump Campaign|last=Sherman|first=Gabriel|date=April 19, 2016|website=New York|access-date=April 20, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN0Z61L5|title=Trump fires campaign manager in shakeup for election push|author=Flitter|first=Emily|date=June 21, 2016|work=|accessdate=August 2, 2016|agency=[[Reuters]]|last2=Stephenson|first2=Emily}}</ref><ref name="NYTResigns">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/20/us/politics/paul-manafort-resigns-donald-trump.html|title=Paul Manafort Quits Donald Trump's Campaign After a Tumultuous Run|last1=Haberman|first1=Maggie|date=August 19, 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=November 7, 2016|last2=Martin|first2=Jonathan|author1-link=Maggie Haberman}}</ref>
On June 9, 2016, Manafort, [[Donald Trump Jr.]], and [[Jared Kushner]] were participants in [[Trump campaign–Russian meeting|a meeting]] with Russian attorney [[Natalia Veselnitskaya]] and several others at [[Trump Tower]]. A British music agent, saying he was acting on behalf of [[Emin Agalarov]] and the Russian government, had told Trump Jr. that he could obtain damaging information on [[Hillary Clinton]] if he met with a lawyer connected to the [[Kremlin]].<ref name=NYT11july17>{{cite news|last1=[[Matt Apuzzo]]|last2=[[Jo Becker]]|last3=[[Adam Goldman]]|last4=[[Maggie Haberman]]|title=Trump's Son Heard of Link To Moscow Before Meeting – Russian Government Sought to Help Father and Hurt Clinton, Email Suggested|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/10/us/politics/donald-trump-jr-russia-email-candidacy.html|accessdate=July 11, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 11, 2017|page=A1}}</ref> At first, Trump Jr. said the meeting had been primarily about the Russian ban on international adoptions (in response to the [[Magnitsky Act]]) and mentioned nothing about Mrs. Clinton; he later said the offer of information about Clinton had been a pretext to conceal Veselnitskaya's real agenda.<ref>{{cite news|last1=[[Jo Becker]]|last2=[[Matt Apuzzo]]|last3=[[Adam Goldman]]|title=Trump Team Met Russian Offering Dirt on Clinton – Key Time in Campaign – Account Shows an Inner Circle Open to Using Foreign Help|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/09/us/politics/trump-russia-kushner-manafort.html|accessdate=July 11, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 10, 2017|page=A1}}</ref>
In August 2016, Manafort's connections to former [[Ukrainian President]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]] and his pro-Russian [[Party of Regions]] drew national attention in the US, where it was reported that Manafort may have received $12.7 million in off-the-books funds from the Party of Regions.<ref name="ukraine">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/15/us/politics/paul-manafort-ukraine-donald-trump.html|title=Secret Ledger in Ukraine Lists Cash for Donald Trump's Campaign Chief|last=Kramer|first=Andrew E.|date=August 14, 2016|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=August 15, 2016|last2=McIntire|first2=Mike|last3=Meier|first3=Barry}}</ref>
On August 17, 2016, Donald Trump received his first security briefing.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2016-election/what-donald-trump-s-intelligence-briefing-will-entail-n632816|title=Donald Trump Receives First Intelligence Briefing|last1=Dilanian|first1=Ken|date=August 17, 2016|work=[[NBC News]]|accessdate=November 7, 2016|last2=Windrem|first2=Robert}}</ref> The same day, August 17, Trump shook up his campaign organization in a way that appeared to minimize Manafort's role. It was reported that members of Trump's family, particularly Jared Kushner who had originally been a strong backer of Manafort, had become uneasy about his Russian connections and suspected that he had not been forthright about them.<ref>{{cite news |last=McCaskill |first=Nolan |display-authors=etal |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2016/08/paul-manafort-resigns-from-trump-campaign-227197 |title=Paul Manafort resigns from Trump campaign |work=[[Politico]] |date=August 19, 2016 |quote=The [Trump] family was particularly troubled by reports of Manafort's involvement with Russia and felt he hadn't been entirely forthright about his activities overseas, the source said. Family members were also unhappy about changes made to the GOP platform that were seen as beneficial to Russia, which they felt Manafort played a role in, the source added. }}</ref> Manafort stated in an internal staff memorandum that he would "remain the campaign chairman and chief strategist, providing the big-picture, long-range campaign vision".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/18/us/politics/donald-trump-stephen-bannon-paul-manafort.html|title=Donald Trump appoints media firebrand to run campaign|author1=Martin|first=Jonathan|date=August 17, 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=August 20, 2016|author2=Rutenberg|first2=Jim|author3=Haberman|first3=Maggie}}</ref> However, two days later, Trump announced his acceptance of Manafort's resignation from the campaign after [[Steve Bannon]] and [[Kellyanne Conway]] took on senior leadership roles within that campaign.<ref name="nmcaskill1">{{cite news|last1=McCaskill|first1=Nolan|title=Paul Manafort resigns from Trump campaign|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2016/08/paul-manafort-resigns-from-trump-campaign-227197|publisher=[[Politico]]|date=August 19, 2016|accessdate=August 19, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/08/19/490621159/trump-campaign-chair-paul-manafort-resigns|title=Trump campaign chair Paul Manafort resigns|last=Kelly|first=Amita|date=August 19, 2016|work=|accessdate=August 19, 2016|publisher=[[NPR]]}}</ref>
Upon Manafort's resignation as campaign chairman, [[Newt Gingrich]] stated, "nobody should underestimate how much Paul Manafort did to really help get this campaign to where it is right now."<ref name="bump-faq">{{cite news|last1=Bump|first1=Phillip|title=Paul Manafort: A FAQ about Trump's indicted former campaign chairman|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/politics/wp/2017/10/30/paul-manafort-what-we-know-he-did-and-why-he-might-have-been-ensnared-by-the-investigation/?hpid=hp_hp-top-table-high_fix-manafortqanda-1008am%3Ahomepage%2Fstory|accessdate=October 30, 2017|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=October 30, 2017}}{{paywall}}</ref> Gingrich later added that, for the Trump administration, "It makes perfect sense for them to distance themselves from somebody who apparently didn't tell them what he was doing."<ref>{{cite news |last=Nussbaum |first=Matthew |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/03/white-house-paul-manafort-russia-236361 |title=White House: Manafort who? |work=[[Politico]] |date=March 22, 2017 |accessdate=August 22, 2018 }}</ref>
===Lobbying career=== In 1980, Manafort was a founding partner of Washington, D.C.-based lobbying firm Black, Manafort & Stone, along with principals [[Charles R. Black Jr.]], and [[Roger J. Stone]].<ref name="NYT_Edsall_2012"/><ref name="NYT_1989_BMSK"/><ref name="auto"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://content.time.com/time/subscriber/article/0,33009,960803-1,00.html |title=The Slickest Shop in Town |first=Evan |last=Thomas |date=March 3, 1996 |publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''}}</ref> After [[Peter G. Kelly]] was recruited, the name of the firm was changed to [[Black, Manafort, Stone and Kelly]] (BMSK) in 1984.<ref name="Choate_1990"/>{{rp|124}}
Manafort left BMSK in 1996 to join [[Richard H. Davis]] and Matthew C. Freedman in forming Davis, Manafort, and Freedman.<ref name="Politico_Manafort_2016">{{cite news |title=Paul Manafort's Wild and Lucrative Philippine Adventure: as Ferdinand Marcos used his fortune to cling to power, he found an ally in Trump's campaign chairman |url=https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/06/2016-donald-trump-paul-manafort-ferinand-marcos-philippines-1980s-213952 |first=Kenneth P. |last=Vogel |date=June 10, 2016 |access-date=June 16, 2017 |work=[[Politico]]}}</ref>
====Association with Jonas Savimbi==== [[File:Jonas Savimbi.jpg|thumb|right|Manafort has represented Angolan rebel leader [[Jonas Savimbi]].]] In 1985, Manafort's firm, BMSK, signed a $600,000 contract with [[Jonas Savimbi]], the leader of the Angolan rebel group [[UNITA]], to refurbish Savimbi's image in Washington and secure financial support on the basis of his anti-communism stance. BMSK arranged for Savimbi to attend events at the [[American Enterprise Institute]] (where [[Jeane Kirkpatrick]] gave him a laudatory introduction), [[The Heritage Foundation]], and [[Freedom House]]; in the wake of the campaign, Congress approved hundreds of millions of dollars in covert American aid to Savimbi's group.<ref name="Foer">{{Cite news|url = http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/politics/2016/04/paul_manafort_isn_t_a_gop_retread_he_s_made_a_career_of_reinventing_tyrants.html|title = The Quiet American|last = Foer|first = Franklin|newspaper = Slate|date=April 28, 2016|access-date = August 1, 2016}}</ref> Allegedly, Manafort's continuing lobbying efforts helped preserve the flow of money to Savimbi several years after the Soviet Union ceased its involvement in the Angolan conflict, forestalling peace talks.<ref name="Foer"/>
====Lobbying for other foreign leaders==== [[File:Marcos in Washington 1983.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Manafort was a lobbyist for former Philippine President [[Ferdinand Marcos]].]] [[File:Mobutu.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Manafort lobbied on behalf of former Zairean President [[Mobutu Sese Seko]].]] Between June 1984 and June 1986, Manafort was a [[Foreign Agents Registration Act|FARA]]-registered lobbyist for [[Saudi Arabia]]. The Reagan Administration refused to grant Manafort a waiver from federal statutes prohibiting public officials from acting as foreign agents; Manafort resigned his directorship at OPIC in May 1986. An investigation by the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] found 18 lobbying-related activities that were not reported in FARA filings, including lobbying on behalf of [[The Bahamas]] and [[Saint Lucia]].<ref name="bb">{{cite news |url=https://www.bloombergquint.com/politics/2018/07/11/mueller-wants-manafort-jury-to-hear-of-saudi-lobbying-in-1984 |publisher=[[Bloomberg News]] |date=July 12, 2018 |title=Mueller Wants Manafort Jury to Hear of Lobbying Decades Ago |first=David |last=Voreacos}}</ref>
Manafort's firm, BMSK, accepted $950,000 yearly to lobby for then-president of the [[Philippines]] [[Ferdinand Marcos]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/06/2016-donald-trump-paul-manafort-ferinand-marcos-philippines-1980s-213952|title=Paul Manafort's Wild and Lucrative Philippine Adventure|last=|first=|date=|website=Politico|access-date=August 15, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fara.gov/docs/3600-Exhibit-AB-19851101-D0XCT601.pdf|title=Black, Manafort, Stone and Kelly, Public Affairs Company document for U.S. Department of Justice|website=U.S. Foreign Agents Registration Act website (FARA.gov)|access-date=August 15, 2016}}</ref> He was also involved in lobbying for [[Mobutu Sese Seko]] of [[Zaire|Zaïre]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1989/09/25/mobutu-in-search-of-an-image-boost/d0626644-1a49-4414-82b2-70701894dfae/|title=Mobutu in Search of an Image Boost|last=Anderson|first=Jack|date=September 25, 1989|work=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=August 15, 2016|last2=van Atta|first2=Dale}}</ref> securing a US$1 million annual contract in 1989,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2016/08/10/en-afrique-les-liaisons-dangereuses-de-paul-manafort-directeur-de-campagne-de-trump_4980994_3212.html|title=En Afrique, les liaisons dangereuses de Paul Manafort, directeur de campagne de Trump|last=Hauchard|first=Amaury|date=August 10, 2016|work=[[Le Monde]]|access-date=August 20, 2016|language=French}}</ref> and attempted to recruit [[Siad Barre]] of [[Somalia]] as a client.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/31/donald-trump-paul-manafort-riva-levinson-book|title=Trump chair Paul Manafort: 'mercenary' lobbyist and valuable asset|last=Smith|first=David|date=May 31, 2016|work=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=July 25, 2016}}</ref> His firm also lobbied on behalf of the governments of the [[Dominican Republic]], [[Equatorial Guinea]], [[Kenya]] (earning between $660,000 and $750,000 each year between 1991 and 1993), and [[Nigeria]] ($1 million in 1991). These activities led Manafort's firm to be listed amongst the top five lobbying firms receiving money from human-rights abusing regimes in the [[Center for Public Integrity]] report "The Torturers' Lobby".<ref name=":2">{{cite book|url=http://cloudfront-files-1.publicintegrity.org/legacy_projects/pdf_reports/THETORTURERSLOBBY.pdf|title=The Torturers' Lobby. How Human Rights-Abusing Nations Are Represented in Washington|date=1992|publisher=The Center for Public Integrity|isbn=0-9629012-9-6|location=Washington DC|pages=7|last1=Brogan|first1=Pamela|accessdate=April 29, 2016}}</ref>
''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that Manafort accepted payment from the [[Kurdistan Regional Government]] to facilitate Western recognition of the [[Iraqi Kurdistan independence referendum, 2017|2017 Iraqi Kurdistan independence referendum]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/20/us/politics/manafort-kurdish-referendum.html|title=Manafort Working on Kurdish Referendum Opposed by U.S.|last=Vogel|first=Kenneth P.|date=September 20, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=|last2=Becker|first2=Jo|last3=Confessore|first3=Nicholas|last4=Arango|first4=Tim|last5=Bennett|first5=Kitty}}</ref>
====Involvement in the Karachi affair==== Manafort wrote the campaign strategy for [[Édouard Balladur]] in the 1995 French elections, and was paid indirectly.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20130804-karachi-affair-karachigate-us-political-consultant-new-clues-balladur-france-pakistan|title=US Consultant Admits Role in Karachi Affair|last=|first=|date=August 24, 2013|work=[[France 24]]|accessdate=April 29, 2016}}</ref> The money, at least $200,000, was transferred to him through his friend, [[Lebanon|Lebanese]] arms-dealer Abdul Rahman al-Assir, from middle-men fees paid for arranging the sale of three French {{sclass-|Agosta|submarine|1}}s to Pakistan, in a scandal known as the [[Karachi affair]].<ref name="Foer"/>
====Association with Pakistani Inter-Service Intelligence Agency==== Manafort received $700,000 from the [[Kashmir]]i American Council between 1990 and 1994, supposedly to promote the plight of the Kashmiri people. However, an FBI investigation revealed the money was actually from Pakistan's [[Inter-Service Intelligence]] (ISI) agency as part of a disinformation operation to divert attention from terrorism. A former Pakistani ISI official claimed Manafort was aware of the nature of the operation.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/top-trump-aide-lobbied-for-1409744144007222.html|title=Top Trump aide lobbied for Pakistani spy front|last1=Isikoff|first1=Michael|date=April 18, 2016|work=[[Yahoo! News]]|accessdate=April 29, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160418183829/https://www.yahoo.com/news/top-trump-aide-lobbied-for-1409744144007222.html|archive-date=2016-04-18|dead-url=yes}}</ref> While producing a documentary as part of the deal, Manafort interviewed several Indian officials while pretending to be a [[CNN]] reporter.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Drinkard|first1=Jim|title=Public-Relations Ethics Questioned as Some Agents Pose as Journalists : Information: Deception violates PR code, but critics say it's common nonetheless.|agency=Associated Press|date=December 4, 1994|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-12-04/news/mn-4610_1_one-public-relations|accessdate=April 29, 2016}}</ref>
====HUD scandal==== In the late 1980s, Manafort was criticized for using his connections at [[United States Department of Housing and Urban Development|HUD]] to ensure funding for a $43 million rehabilitation of dilapidated housing in [[Seabrook, New Jersey]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Michael |last=Riley |url=https://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,958215-2,00.html |title=Where Were the Media on HUD? |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=July 24, 1989 |accessdate=August 22, 2018 }}</ref> Manafort's firm received a $326,000 fee for its work in getting HUD approval of the grant, largely through personal influence with [[Deborah Gore Dean]], an executive assistant to former HUD Secretary [[Samuel Pierce]].<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://articles.latimes.com/1989-06-21/news/mn-2408_1_hud-housing-authority-housing-for-low-income-people|title = GOP Consultant Admits Using Influence to Obtain HUD Grant but Defends Action|last = Eaton|first = William J.|date = June 21, 1989|newspaper = Los Angeles Times|issn = 0458-3035|access-date = March 31, 2016}}</ref>
====Transition to Ukraine==== Manafort's involvement in Ukraine can be traced to 2003, when [[Russian oligarch]] [[Oleg Deripaska]] hired [[Bob Dole]], Manafort's prior campaign candidate, to lobby the State Department for a waiver of his visa ban, primarily so that he could solicit otherwise unavailable institutional purchasers for shares in his company, RusAL.<ref name="DMP">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenation.com/article/mccains-kremlin-ties/|title=McCain’s Kremlin Ties|last=Ames|first=Mark|date=October 1, 2008|website=[[The Nation]]|access-date=August 27, 2018}}</ref><ref name="GSimpson">{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB117674837248471543|title=How Lobbyists Help Ex-Soviets Woo Washington|last=Simpson|first=Glenn|date=April 17, 2007|website=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150920212025/http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB117674837248471543|archive-date=2015-09-20|dead-url=yes|access-date=August 27, 2018}}</ref> Then in early 2004, Deripaska met with Manafort's Partner, [[Rick Davis]], also a prior campaign advisor to [[Bob Dole]], to discuss hiring Manafort and Davis to return the former Georgian Minister of State Security, Igor Giorgadze, to prominence in Georgian politics.<ref name="OVD">{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/paul-manaforts-overseas-political-work-had-a-notable-patron-a-russian-oligarch-1504131910|title=Paul Manafort’s Overseas Political Work Had a Notable Patron: A Russian Oligarch|last=Forrest|first=Brett|date=August 30, 2017|website=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170830222840/https://www.wsj.com/articles/paul-manaforts-overseas-political-work-had-a-notable-patron-a-russian-oligarch-1504131910|archive-date=2017-08-30|dead-url=yes|access-date=August 27, 2018}}</ref> By December 2004, however, Deripaska shelved his plans in Georgia and dispatched Manafort to meet with [[Rinat Akhmetov]] in Ukraine to help Akhmetov and his holding firm, System Capital Management, weather the political crisis brought by the [[Orange Revolution]].<ref name="OVD" /> [[Rinat Akhmetov|Akhmetov]] would eventually flee to Monaco after being accused of murder, but during the crisis Manafort shepherded [[Rinat Akhmetov|Akhemtov]] around Washington, meeting with U.S. Officials like [[Dick Cheney]].<ref name="DMP" /><ref name="GSimpson" /><ref name="OVD" /> Meanwhile, the [[Orange Revolution]] would push Deripaska to also hire Davis-Manafort, this time to work for [[Viktor Yanukovych]] and the [[Party of Regions]].<ref name="pmsuOB" />
====Lobbying for Viktor Yanukovych and involvements in Ukraine==== [[File:Agência Brasil 2011 Viktor Yanukovich.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Ukrainian President [[Viktor Yanukovych]], for whom Manafort lobbied]] Manafort also worked as an adviser on the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|Ukrainian presidential campaign]] of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] (and his [[Party of Regions]] during the same time span) from December 2004 until the February [[2010 Ukrainian presidential election]],<ref name=YamontU>{{cite news |url=https://www.politifact.com/global-news/article/2016/may/02/paul-manafort-donald-trumps-top-adviser-and-his-ti/ |first=Aleksandra |last=Kharchenko |title=Paul Manafort, Donald Trump's top adviser, and his ties to pro-Russian politicians in Ukraine |work=[[PolitiFact.com]] |date=May 2, 2016 |accessdate=August 22, 2018 }}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/30/world/europe/30ukraine.html|title=Ukrainian Prime Minister Reinvents Himself|last=Levy|first=Clifford J.|date=September 30, 2007|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=March 31, 2016}}</ref><ref name="pmsuOB">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/01/us/paul-manafort-ukraine-donald-trump.html|title=How Paul Manafort Wielded Power in Ukraine Before Advising Donald Trump|last=Myers|first=Steven Lee|date=July 31, 2016|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=July 31, 2016|last2=Kramer|first2=Andrew E.}}</ref> even as the U.S. government (and U.S. Senator [[John McCain]]) opposed Yanukovych because of his ties to Russia's leader [[Vladimir Putin]].<ref name=":0" /> Manafort was hired to advise Yanukovych months after massive street demonstrations known as the [[Orange Revolution]] overturned Yanukovych's victory in the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 presidential race]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703630404575053850989810346|title=Candidates Sought Guidance From American Consultants|last=Boudreaux|first=Richard|date=February 9, 2010|website=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160124215920/http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703630404575053850989810346|archive-date=2016-01-24|dead-url=yes|access-date=March 31, 2016}}</ref> [[Borys Kolesnikov]], Yanukovych's campaign manager, said the party hired Manafort after identifying organizational and other problems in the 2004 elections, in which it was advised by Russian strategists.<ref name=":1" /> Manafort rebuffed U.S. Ambassador [[William B. Taylor Jr.|William Taylor]] when the latter complained he was undermining U.S. interests in Ukraine.<ref name="Foer"/> According to a 2008 [[U.S. Justice Department]] annual report, Manafort's company received $63,750 from Yanukovych's Party of Regions over a six-month period ending on March 31, 2008, for consulting services.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/53251/|title=Paid advisers descend on candidates, nation|last=Pastukhova|first=Alina|date=November 24, 2009|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|access-date=March 31, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091124072239/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/53251/|archivedate=November 24, 2009|deadurl=unfit|last2=Grushenko|first2=Kateryna}}</ref> In 2010, under Manafort's tutelage, the opposition leader put the Orange Revolution on trial, campaigning against its leaders' management of a weak economy. Returns from the presidential election gave Yanukovych a narrow win over Prime Minister [[Yulia Tymoshenko]], a leader of the 2004 demonstrations. Yanukovych owed his comeback in Ukraine's presidential election to a drastic makeover of his political persona, and—people in his party say—that makeover was engineered in part by his American consultant, Manafort.<ref name=":1" />
In 2007 and 2008, Manafort was involved in investment projects with [[Russian oligarch]] Oleg Deripaska (the acquisition of a Ukrainian telecoms company) and [[Ukrainian oligarch]] [[Dmytro Firtash]] (redevelopment of the site of the former [[Drake Hotel (New York City)|Drake Hotel]] in [[New York City]]).<ref name="MuinvG16816">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/aug/16/donald-trump-campaign-paul-manafort-ukraine-yanukovich |title=How Trump's campaign chief got a strongman elected president of Ukraine |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=August 16, 2016 |accessdate=August 22, 2018 }}</ref> The [[Associated Press]] has reported that Manafort negotiated a $10 million annual contract with Deripaska to promote Russian interests in politics, business, and media coverage in Europe and the United States, starting in 2005.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.apnews.com/122ae0b5848345faa88108a03de40c5a/Manafort's-plan-to-'greatly-benefit-the-Putin-Government|title=Trump campaign chief linked to Putin interests|last=Horwitz & Day|date=March 22, 2017|agency=Associated Press|access-date=March 22, 2017}}</ref> A witness at Manafort's 2018 trial for fraud and tax evasion testified that Deripaska loaned Manafort $10 million in 2010, which to her knowledge was never repaid.<ref name="risefall" />
At Manafort's trial, federal prosecutors alleged that between 2010 and 2014 he was paid more than $60 million by Ukrainian sponsors, including Rinat Akhmetov, believed to be the richest man in Ukraine.<ref name="risefall" />
In 2013, Yanukovych became the main target of the [[Euromaidan]] protests.<ref name=VYBBCp/> After the February [[2014 Ukrainian revolution]] (the conclusion of Euromaidan), Yanukovych fled to Russia.<ref name=VYBBCp>{{cite news |date=February 28, 2014 |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-25182830 |title=Profile: Viktor Yanukovych |work=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=August 22, 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-26304842 |title=Ukrainian MPs vote to oust President Yanukovych |work=[[BBC News]] |date=February 22, 2014 |accessdate=August 22, 2018 }}</ref> On March 17, 2014, the day after the [[Crimean referendum, 2014|Crimean status referendum]], Yanukovych became one of the first eleven persons who were placed under executive sanctions on the [[Office of Foreign Assets Control#Specially Designated Nationals List|Specially Designated Nationals List (SDN)]] by [[Barack Obama|President Barack Obama]], freezing his assets in the US and banning him from entering the United States.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/crimea-vote-referendum-sanctions-obama-putin-2014-3|title=Obama Just Announced Sanctions Against 7 Russian 'Cronies'|journal=[[Business Insider]] |first=Brett| last=Logiurato| date=March 17, 2014|accessdate=November 7, 2016}}</ref><ref name="StateUkraineRussiaSanctions">{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/e/eb/tfs/spi/ukrainerussia/|title=Ukraine and Russia Sanctions|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[United States Department of State]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140720051902/http://www.state.gov/e/eb/tfs/spi/ukrainerussia/|archive-date=2014-07-20|dead-url=yes|accessdate=November 7, 2016}}</ref><ref name=FirstListWhiteHouse>{{cite web | title = Fact Sheet: Ukraine-Related Sanctions | url = https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/03/17/fact-sheet-ukraine-related-sanctions | publisher = The White House: Office of the Press Secretary | date = March 17, 2014 | accessdate = November 7, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | title = Executive Order – Blocking Property of Additional Persons Contributing to the Situation in Ukraine | url = http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/03/20/executive-order-blocking-property-additional-persons-contributing-situat | publisher = The White House: Office of the Press Secretary | date = March 20, 2014 | accessdate =November 7, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.treasury.gov/press-center/press-releases/Pages/jl23331.aspx|title=Treasury Sanctions Russian Officials, Members Of The Russian Leadership's Inner Circle, And An Entity For Involvement In The Situation In Ukraine|last=|first=|date=March 20, 2014|website=|publisher=[[United States Department of the Treasury]]|access-date=}}</ref><ref name="TreasurySanctionsUkraineFirstList">{{cite web|url=https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/OFAC-Enforcement/Pages/20140317.aspx|title=Issuance of a new Ukraine-related Executive Order; Ukraine-related Designations|last=|first=|date=March 17, 2014|website=|publisher=[[United States Department of the Treasury]]|accessdate=November 7, 2016}}</ref><ref name="TreasurySanctionsUkraineSecondList">{{cite web|url=https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/OFAC-Enforcement/Pages/20140320_33.aspx|title=Ukraine-related Designations|last=|first=|date=March 20, 2014|website=|publisher=[[United States Department of the Treasury]]|accessdate=November 7, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/SDN-List/Pages/default.aspx|title=Specially Designated Nationals List (SDN)|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[United States Department of the Treasury]]|access-date=}}</ref><ref name="Sanctions">{{cite web|url=https://news.liga.net/articles/politics/1066761-blizhniy_krug_putina_kto_popal_v_novyy_spisok_sanktsiy_ssha.htm|title=Putin's inner circle: who got in a new list of US sanctions|last=Shuklin|first=Peter|date=March 21, 2014|website=|publisher=liga.net|language=Russian|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207152258/http://news.liga.net/articles/politics/1066761-blizhniy_krug_putina_kto_popal_v_novyy_spisok_sanktsiy_ssha.htm|archivedate=February 7, 2015|deadurl=yes|accessdate=November 7, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Ukraine-EO13660">{{cite web|url=https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/Programs/Documents/ukraine_eo.pdf|title=Ukraine EO13660|last=President of The United States|first=|date=March 10, 2014|website=|publisher=[[Federal Register]]|accessdate=November 7, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Ukraine-EO13661">{{cite web|url=https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/Programs/Documents/ukraine_eo2.pdf|title=Ukraine EO13661|last=President of The United States|first=|date=March 19, 2014|website=|publisher=[[Federal Register]]|accessdate=November 7, 2016}}</ref>{{efn|The individuals on the first list of United States sanctions for individuals or entities involved in the Ukraine crisis are Sergey Aksyonov, Sergey Glazyev, Andrei Klishas, Vladimir Konstantinov, Valentina Matviyenko, Victor Medvedchuk, Yelena Mizulina, Dmitry Rogozin, Leonid Slutsky, Vladislav Surkov, and Victor Yakunovich.<ref name=FirstListWhiteHouse/><ref name=TreasurySanctionsUkraineFirstList/>}}
Manafort then returned to Ukraine in September 2014 to become an advisor to Yanukovych's former head of the [[Presidential Administration of Ukraine]] [[Serhiy Lyovochkin]].<ref name=pmsuOB/> In this role, he was asked to assist in rebranding Yanukovych's Party of Regions.<ref name=pmsuOB/> Instead, he argued to help stabilize Ukraine. Manafort was instrumental in creating a new political party called [[Opposition Bloc]].<ref name=pmsuOB/> According to Ukrainian political analyst Mikhail Pogrebinsky, "He thought to gather the largest number of people opposed to the current government, you needed to avoid anything concrete, and just become a symbol of being opposed".<ref name=pmsuOB/> According to Manafort, he has not worked in Ukraine since the October [[2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2016/08/paul-manafort-ukraine-payment-new-york-times-227004 |title=Manafort blasts NYT, denies he accepted Ukraine cash payments |work=[[Politico]] |date=August 15, 2016 |accessdate=August 22, 2018 }}</ref><ref name=PM19816/> However, according to Ukrainian border control entry data, Manafort traveled to Ukraine several times after that election, all the way through late 2015.<ref name=PM19816/> According to ''[[The New York Times]]'', his local office in Ukraine closed in May 2016.<ref name=ukraine/> According to ''[[Politico]]'', by then Opposition Bloc had already stopped payments for Manafort and this local office.<ref name=PM19816>{{cite news |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2016/08/paul-manafort-ukraine-kiev-russia-konstantin-kilimnik-227181 |title=Manafort's man in Kiev |work=[[Politico]] |date=August 19, 2016 |first=Kenneth P. |last=Vogel |accessdate=August 22, 2018 }}</ref>
In an April 2016 interview with [[ABC News]], Manafort stated that the aim of his activities in Ukraine had been to lead the country "closer to Europe".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.dw.com/en/trump-campaign-manager-manafort-has-ukrainian-history/a-19432826|title=Trump campaign manager Manafort has Ukrainian history|author1=Maksym Sydorzhevskyj|first=|date=July 28, 2016|work=|access-date=|publisher=[[Deutsche Welle]]|author2=Markian Ostaptschuk}}</ref>
Ukrainian government [[National Anti-Corruption Bureau]] studying secret documents claimed in August 2016 to have found handwritten records that show $12.7 million in cash payments designated for Manafort, although they had yet to determine if he had received the money.<ref name=ukraine/> These undisclosed payments were from the pro-Russian political party [[Party of Regions]], of the former [[president of Ukraine]].<ref name=ukraine/> This payment record spans from 2007 to 2012.<ref name=ukraine/> Manafort's lawyer, Richard A. Hibey, said Manafort didn't receive "any such cash payments" as described by the anti-corruption officials.<ref name=ukraine/> The Associated Press reported on August 17, 2016, that Manafort secretly routed at least $2.2 million in payments to two prominent Washington lobbying firms in 2012 on Party of Regions' behalf, and did so in a way that effectively obscured the foreign political party's efforts to influence U.S. policy.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/c01989a47ee5421593ba1b301ec07813/ap-sources-manafort-tied-undisclosed-foreign-lobbying|title=AP Sources: Manafort tied to undisclosed foreign lobbying|agency=[[Associated Press]]|access-date=August 17, 2016}}</ref> Associated Press noted that under federal law, U.S. lobbyists must declare publicly if they represent foreign leaders or their political parties and provide detailed reports about their actions to the Justice Department, which Manafort reportedly did not do.<ref name=":3" /> The lobbying firms unsuccessfully lobbied [[U.S. Congress]] to reject a resolution condemning [[Criminal cases against Yulia Tymoshenko since 2010|the jailing]] of Yanukovych's main political rival, [[Yulia Tymoshenko]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/e7acd0dbb64c4bcd8e29736b99b1224c/trump-aides-covertly-fought-freeing-ukraine-prisoner|title=Trump aides covertly fought freeing of Ukraine prisoner|last=Horwitz|first=Jeff|date=August 23, 2016|work=|access-date=August 24, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160824003535/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/e7acd0dbb64c4bcd8e29736b99b1224c/trump-aides-covertly-fought-freeing-ukraine-prisoner|archive-date=2016-08-24|dead-url=yes|agency=[[Associated Press]]|last2=Day|first2=Chad}}</ref>
Financial records certified in December 2015 and filed by Manafort in Cyprus showed him to be approximately $17 million in debt to interests connected to interests favorable to Putin and Yanukovych in the months before joining the Trump presidential campaign in March.<ref name="McIntyre2017a">{{cite news|last1=McIntyre|first1=Mike|title=Manafort Was in Debt to Pro-Russia Interests, Cyprus Records Show|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/19/us/politics/paul-manafort-russia-trump.html|accessdate=July 20, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 19, 2017}}</ref> These included a $7.8 million debt to Oguster Management Limited, a company connected to [[Russian oligarch]] and close Putin associate Oleg Deripaska.<ref name="McIntyre2017a"/> This accords with a 2015 court complaint filed by Deripaska claiming that Manafort and his partners owed him $19 million in relation to a failed Ukrainian cable television business.<ref name="McIntyre2017a"/> In January 2018, Surf Horizon Limited, a Cyprus-based company tied to Deripaska, sued Manafort and his business partner Richard Gates, accusing them of financial fraud by misappropriating more than $18.9 million that the company had invested in Ukrainian telecom companies, known collectively as the “Black Sea Cable.”<ref>{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFKBN1EZ2FX|title=Cyprus company sues ex-Trump campaign manager Manafort for fraud|last=Lynch|first=Sarah N.|date=January 10, 2018|work=|access-date=|publisher=|agency=[[Reuters]]}}</ref> An additional $9.9 million debt was owed to a Cyprus company that tied through [[shell company|shell companies]] to {{ill|Ivan Fursin|uk|Фурсін Іван Геннадійович}}, a Ukrainian Member of Parliament of the Party of Regions.<ref name="McIntyre2017a"/> Manafort spokesman Jason Maloni maintained in response that "Manafort is not indebted to Deripaska or the Party of Regions, nor was he at the time he began working for the Trump campaign."<ref name="McIntyre2017a"/> During the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 Presidential campaign]], Manafort, via [[Kiev]]-based operative [[Konstantin Kilimnik]], offered to provide briefings on political developments to Deripaska, though there is no evidence that the briefings took place.<ref name="WaPo">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/manafort-offered-to-give-russian-billionaire-private-briefings-on-2016-campaign/2017/09/20/399bba1a-9d48-11e7-8ea1-ed975285475e_story.html |date=September 20, 2017 |title=Manafort offered to give Russian billionaire ‘private briefings’ on 2016 campaign |first=Tom |last=Hamburger |first2=Rosalind S. |last2=Helderman |first3=Carol D. |last3=Leonnig|authorlink3 = Carol D. Leonnig |first4=Adam |last4=Entous |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170921003301/https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/manafort-offered-to-give-russian-billionaire-private-briefings-on-2016-campaign/2017/09/20/399bba1a-9d48-11e7-8ea1-ed975285475e_story.html |archive-date=September 21, 2017 |work=[[The Washington Post]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |publisher=[[Politico]] |title=Manafort used Trump campaign account to email Ukrainian operative |first=Josh |last=Dawsey |date=September 20, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170921003929/http://www.politico.com/story/2017/09/20/paul-manafort-trump-campaign-email-ukrainian-operative-242949 |archive-date=September 21, 2017 |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/09/20/paul-manafort-trump-campaign-email-ukrainian-operative-242949 }}</ref> ''Reuters'' reported on June 27, 2018, that an FBI search warrant application in July 2017 revealed that a company controlled by Manafort and his wife had received a $10 million loan from Deripaska.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-russia-manafort/manafort-had-10-million-loan-from-russian-oligarch-court-filing-idUSKBN1JN2YF|title=Manafort had $10 million loan from Russian oligarch: court filing |first=Reuters|last=Editorial|publisher= |accessdate=June 27, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |work=[[Politico]] |first=Josh |last=Meyer |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/06/27/paul-manafort-mueller-russia-oleg-deripaska-680630 |title=Mueller reveals closer Manafort ties to Russian oligarch |date=June 27, 2018 |accessdate=August 22, 2018 }}</ref>
According to leaked text messages between his daughters, Manafort was also one of the proponents of violent removal of the [[Euromaidan]] protesters, which resulted in police shooting dozens of people during [[2014 Hrushevskoho Street riots]]. In one of the messages, his daughter writes that it was his "strategy that was to cause that, to send those people out and get them slaughtered."<ref name=CNN2017-03-12>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/03/10/politics/ukraine-manafort-hacked-texts/index.html|title=Ukraine seeks probe of hacked Manafort texts|last=Ostrovsky|first=Simon|date=March 11, 2017|work=[[CNN]]|access-date=March 12, 2017|website=}}</ref>
Manafort has rejected questions about whether Russian-Ukrainian operative Konstantin Kilimnik, with whom he consulted regularly, might be in league with Russian intelligence.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/03/trump-russia-manafort-235850 |title=Authorities looked into Manafort protégé; An associate of an ex-Trump campaign chairman is suspected of connections to Russian intelligence.|author=Vogel|first=Kenneth P.|last2=Stern|first2=David|date=March 8, 2017|website=|publisher=[[Politico]]|access-date=March 12, 2017}}</ref> According to [[Yuri Shvets]], Kilimnik previously worked for the [[GRU]], and every bit of information about his work with Manafort went directly to Russian intelligence.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.svoboda.org/a/27949833.html|title=Зачем Путину Трамп?|last=Голицына|first=Наталья|date=March 3, 2016|website=[[Радио Свобода]]|language=Russian|access-date=August 22, 2018 }}</ref>
===2017 activities=== ====Registering as a foreign agent==== Lobbying for foreign countries requires registration with the [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] under the [[Foreign Agents Registration Act]] (FARA). Manafort did not do so at the time of his lobbying. In April 2017, a Manafort spokesman said Manafort was planning to file the required paperwork; however, according to [[Associated Press]] reporters, as of June 2, 2017, Manafort had not yet registered.<ref name="Time_2017_Mueller"/><ref name=":3" /> On June 27, he filed to be retroactively registered as a [[foreign agent]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/former-trump-campaign-chairman-paul-manafort-files-as-foreign-agent-for-ukraine-work/2017/06/27/8322b6ac-5b7b-11e7-9fc6-c7ef4bc58d13_story.html|title=Former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort files as foreign agent for Ukraine work|last=Hamburger|first=Tom|first2=Rosalind S.|last2=Helderman|date=June 27, 2018|work=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=June 27, 2017}}</ref> Among other things, he disclosed that he made more than $17 million between 2012 and 2014 working for a pro-Russian political party in Ukraine.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/06/27/manafort-foreign-agent-ukraine-240027|title=Manafort registers as foreign agent|last=Meyer|first=Theodoric|date=June 27, 2017|work=Politico|accessdate=June 28, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/06/28/politics/manafort-registers-foreign-agent/index.html|title=Former Trump campaign chairman registers as a foreign agent|last1=Perez|first1=Evan|date=June 28, 2017|work=[[CNN]]|accessdate=July 2, 2017|last2=Devine|first2=Curt}}</ref>
====China, Puerto Rico, and Ecuador==== Early in 2017, Manafort supported Chinese efforts at providing development and investment worldwide and in Puerto Rico and Ecuador.<ref name=NYT2017-09-20>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/20/us/politics/manafort-kurdish-referendum.html|title=Manafort Working on Kurdish Referendum Opposed by U.S.|date=September 20, 2017|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|last1=Vogel|first1=Kenneth P.|last2=Becker|first2=Jo|access-date=October 9, 2018}}</ref> Early in 2017, he discussed possible Chinese investment sources for Ecuador with [[Lenín Moreno]] who later obtained loans worth several billion US dollars from the [[China Development Bank]].<ref name=NYT2017-09-20/> Manafort acted as the go between for the China Development Bank's investment fund to support bailout bonds for [[Puerto Rican government-debt crisis|Puerto Rico's sovereign debt]] financing and other infrastructure items.<ref name=NYT2017-09-20/> Also, he advised a Shanghai construction billionaire, Yan Jiehe (严介和) who owns the [[:zh:太平洋建設|Pacific Construction Group (太平洋建设)]] and is China's seventh richest man with a fortune estimated at $14.2 billion in 2015, on obtaining international contracts.<ref name=NYT2017-09-20/><ref name=Politico2017-06-15>{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/06/15/paul-manafort-fbi-trump-239573|title=Manafort still doing international work: Trump’s former campaign chairman is under FBI investigation, but some say he is touting access to the president to prospective business partners|date=June 15, 2017|work=[[Politico]]|last=Vogel|first=Kenneth P.|access-date=October 15, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://baike.baidu.com/item/%E4%B8%A5%E4%BB%8B%E5%92%8C|title=Yan Jiehe (严介和)|publisher=|accessdate=November 27, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/1cddb8cc-a7ac-11e4-8e78-00144feab7de|title=Yan Jiehe, CPCG: the Chinese billionaire turned debt collector|date=February 1, 2015|work=[[Financial Times]]|access-date=}}</ref>
====Kurdish independence referendum==== In mid-2017, Manafort left the United States in order to help organize the September 25, 2017, [[Iraqi Kurdistan independence referendum, 2017|Kurdish independence referendum]], something that surprised both investigators and the media.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.alaraby.co.uk/english/comment/2017/9/26/how-paul-manafort-is-profiting-from-kurdistans-independence-referendum|title=How Paul Manafort is profiting from the Kurdish independence referendum|last=Fouad|first=Sam|date=September 26, 2017|website=The New Arab|publisher=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170927124626/https://www.alaraby.co.uk/english/comment/2017/9/26/how-paul-manafort-is-profiting-from-kurdistans-independence-referendum|archive-date=2017-09-27|dead-url=yes|accessdate=June 27, 2018}}</ref> He was hired by the [[President of Iraqi Kurdistan|Iraqi Kurdish Leader]] [[Masoud Barzani]]'s son [[Masrour Barzani]] who heads the [[Kurdistan Region Security Council|Kurdish Security Council]].<ref name=NYT2017-09-20/><ref name=Hill2017-09-20>{{cite news|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/news/351679-manafort-working-on-kurdish-independence-referendum-report|title=Manafort working on Kurdish independence referendum: report|work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|date=September 20, 2017|last=Greenwood|first=Max|access-date=October 9, 2018}}</ref> To help Manafort's efforts in supporting Kurdish freedom and independence, his longtime associate Phillip M. Griffin traveled to [[Erbil]] prior to the vote.<ref name=NYT2017-09-20/> The referendum was not supported by [[United States Secretary of Defense]] [[James Mattis]].<ref name=Newsweek2017-09-21>{{cite news|url=https://www.newsweek.com/paul-manafort-working-promote-kurdish-referendum-vote-washington-opposes-668736|title=Manafort has a new job: Helping the Kurdish referendum, a vote the U.S. opposes|date=September 21, 2018|work=Newsweek|last=Moore|first=Jack|access-date=October 9, 2018}}</ref> Manafort returned to the United States just before both his indictment and the start of the [[2017 Iraqi–Kurdish conflict]] in which the [[Peshmerga]]-led Kurds lost the [[Mosul Dam]] and their main revenue source at the [[Baba Gurgur|Baba GurGur]] [[Kirkuk Field|Kirkuk oilfields]] to Iraqi forces.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/iraqi-forces-take-back-sinjar-in-latest-effort-to-roll-back-kurdish-gains-of-the-past-years/2017/10/17/61032770-b30d-11e7-9e58-e6288544af98_story.html|title=Iraqi forces move deeper into Kurdish-held areas, redrawing political map|first1=Loveday|last1=Morris|first2=Tamer|last2=El-Ghobashy|first3=Aaso Ameen|last3=Shwan|date=October 17, 2017|publisher=[[Washington Post]]|access-date=October 9, 2018|via=www.WashingtonPost.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171018092525/https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/iraqi-forces-take-back-sinjar-in-latest-effort-to-roll-back-kurdish-gains-of-the-past-years/2017/10/17/61032770-b30d-11e7-9e58-e6288544af98_story.html|archive-date=October 18, 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=Politico2017-10-30>{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/10/30/full-text-paul-manafort-indictment-244307|title=Full Text: Paul Manafort indictment|date=October 30, 2017|work=Politico|access-date=October 9, 2018}}</ref>
==Homes, home loans and other loans== Manafort's work in Ukraine coincided with the purchase of at least four prime pieces of real estate in the United States, worth a combined $11 million, between 2006 and early 2012.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fusion.net/story/337482/trump-manafort-ukraine-mansions-movies-mobsters/|title=How Trump Aide Paul Manafort Got Ridiculously Wealthy While Aiding a Ukrainian Strongman|last=Silverstein|first=Ken|date=August 17, 2016|newspaper=Fusion|access-date=February 24, 2017|last2=Weinstein|first2=Adam|language=en-US}}</ref> In 2006, Manafort purchased an apartment on the 43rd floor of Trump Tower for a reported $3.6 million.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/controversial-residents-trump-tower/story?id=52577191|title=The controversial residents of Trump Tower|last=Koenigs|first=Michael|date=February 23, 2018|newspaper=ABC News|access-date=August 27, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> Manafort, however, purchased the unit indirectly, through an LLC named after him and his partner [[Rick Davis (politics)|Rick Hannah Davis]], "John Hannah, LLC."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/11/01/561330641/what-manaforts-indictment-reveals-his-new-york-city-real-estate-deals|title=What Manafort's Indictment Reveals About His New York City Real Estate Deals|last=Bernstein|first=Andrea|date=November 1, 2017|newspaper=NPR|access-date=August 27, 2018|last2=Marritz|first2=Ilya|language=en-US}}</ref> That LLC, according to court documents in Manafort's indictment, came into existence in April 2006,<ref>{{cite web |author1=Robert S. Mueller, III |title=SUPERSEDING INDICTMENT |url=https://www.justice.gov/sco/page/file/1070326/download |website=justice.gov |publisher=U.S. Department of Justice |accessdate=August 27, 2018 |page=4}}</ref> roughly one month after the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2006|Ukrainian parliamentary elections]] that saw Manafort help bring [[Viktor Yanukovych|Yanukovych]] back to power on March 22, 2006.<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/2006/mar/26/world/fg-ukraine26 Ukraine Is the Winner as Nation Heads to the Polls], [[LA Times]] (March 26, 2006)</ref> According to Ukrainian journalist [[Mustafa Nayyem]], the Ukrainian Oligarch sponsoring [[Viktor Yanukovych|Yanukovych]], [[Rinat Akhmetov]], paid the $3 million purchase price for Manafort's Trump Tower unit for helping win the election.<ref name="DMP"/> It was not until March 5 of 2015, when Manafort's income from Ukraine dwindled,<ref>{{cite web |author1=Robert S. Mueller, III |title=SUPERSEDING INDICTMENT |url=https://www.justice.gov/file/1038391/download |website=justice.gov |publisher=U.S. Department of Justice |accessdate=August 27, 2018 |page=3}}</ref> that Manafort would transfer the property out of John Hannah, LLC, and into his own personal name so that he could take out a $3 million loan against the property.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Sugar |first1=Rachel |title=Paul Manafort’s ‘puzzling’ NYC real estate transactions raise eyebrows |url=https://ny.curbed.com/2017/3/28/15088596/paul-manafort-money-laundering-trump-tower-wnyc |website=Curbed New York |accessdate=August 27, 2018}}</ref>
Since 2012, Manafort has taken out seven home equity loans worth approximately $19.2 million on three separate New York-area properties he owns through holding companies registered to him and his then son-in-law Jeffrey Yohai, a real estate investor.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://theintercept.com/2017/02/24/former-trump-campaign-manager-paul-manafort-took-out-19-million-in-puzzling-real-estate-loans/|title=Former Trump Campaign Manager Paul Manafort Took Out $19 Million in Puzzling Real Estate Loans|last=Dayen|first=David|date=February 24, 2017|website=The Intercept|access-date=February 24, 2017}}</ref> In 2016, Yohai declared [[Chapter 11, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 11 bankruptcy]] for [[Limited liability company|LLC]]<nowiki/>s tied to four residential properties; Manafort holds a $2.7 million claim on one of the properties.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://therealdeal.com/la/2016/12/23/paul-manaforts-son-in-law-files-for-bankruptcy-protection-for-four-la-properties/|title=Paul Manafort's son-in-law files for bankruptcy protection for four LA properties|last=Chen|first=Cathaleen|date=December 23, 2016|newspaper=The Real Deal (Los Angeles)|access-date=February 24, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref>
{{As of|2017|February}}, Manafort had about $12 million in home equity loans outstanding. For one home, loans of $6.6 million exceeded the value of that home; the loans are from the Federal Savings Bank of Chicago, Illinois, whose CEO, [[Stephen Calk]], was a campaign supporter of Donald Trump and was a member of Trump's economic advisory council during the campaign.<ref name=":4" /> In July 2017, New York prosecutors subpoenaed information about the loans issued to Manafort during the 2016 presidential campaign. At the time, these loans represented about a quarter of the bank's equity capital.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/new-york-seeks-bank-records-of-former-trump-associate-paul-manafort-1500327062|title=New York Seeks Bank Records of Former Trump Associate Paul Manafort|last=Rothfeld|first=Michael|date=July 17, 2017|work=The Wall Street Journal|access-date=July 21, 2017|issn=0099-9660}}</ref>
The Mueller investigation is reviewing a number of loans that Manafort has received since leaving the Trump campaign in August 2016, specifically, $7 million from Oguster Management Limited, a British Virgin Islands-registered company connected to Russian billionaire [[Oleg Deripaska]], to another Manafort-linked company, Cyprus-registered LOAV Advisers Ltd.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/19/us/politics/paul-manafort-russia-trump.html|title=Manafort Was in Debt to Pro-Russia Interests, Cyprus Records Show|last=McIntire|first=Mike|date=July 17, 2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=October 14, 2017}}</ref> This entire amount was unsecured, carried interest at 2%, and had no repayment date. Additionally, NBC News found documents that reveal loans of more than $27 million from the two Cyprus entities to a third company connected to Manafort, a limited-liability corporation registered in Delaware. This company, Jesand LLC, bears a strong resemblance to the names of Manafort's daughters, Jessica and Andrea.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/manafort-had-60m-relationship-russian-oligarch-n810541|title=Manafort Had $60 Million Relationship With a Russian Oligarch|last=Petropoulos|first=Aggelos|date=October 13, 2017|publisher=NBC News|access-date=October 14, 2017}}</ref>
==Investigations== ===FBI and special counsel investigation=== {{Main|Special Counsel investigation (2017–present)}} The FBI reportedly began a criminal investigation into Manafort in 2014, shortly after Yanukovych was deposed.<ref name="Porter">{{cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/donald-trump-paul-manafort-michael-flynn-russia-robert-mueller-turkey-620215|title=Trump-Russia investigation expands to take in criminal probes on Manafort and Flynn-Turkey|last=Porter|first=Tom|date=June 3, 2017|work=Newsweek|accessdate=June 28, 2017}}</ref> That investigation predated the 2016 election by several years and is ongoing. In addition, Manafort is also a person of interest in the FBI counterintelligence probe looking into the Russian government's interference in the 2016 presidential election.<ref name="AP_Gurman_Mueller_Manafort" /><ref name="Time_2017_Mueller" />
On January 19, 2017, the eve of the [[Inauguration of Donald Trump|Trump's presidential inauguration]], it was reported that Manafort was under active investigation by multiple federal agencies including the [[Central Intelligence Agency]], [[National Security Agency]], [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI), [[Director of National Intelligence]] and the [[Financial Crimes Enforcement Network|financial crimes unit of the Treasury Department]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/19/us/politics/trump-russia-associates-investigation.html|title=Intercepted Russian Communications Part of Inquiry Into Trump Associates|last=Goldman|first=Michael S. Schmidt, Matthew Rosenberg, Adam|date=January 19, 2017|last2=Apuzzo|first2=Matt|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=January 20, 2017}}</ref> Investigations were said to be based on intercepted Russian communications as well as financial transactions.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thehill.com/policy/national-security/315213-us-intelligence-agencies-law-enforcement-will-examine-intercepted|title=Manafort part of intelligence review of intercepted Russian communications|last=Greenwood|first=Max|date=January 19, 2017|work=The Hill|accessdate=March 22, 2017}}</ref> It was later confirmed that Manafort was wiretapped by the FBI "before and after the [2016] election ... including a period when Manafort was known to talk to President Donald Trump." The surveillance of Manafort began in 2014, before Donald Trump announced his candidacy for President of United States.<ref name="Manafort wiretap">{{cite web|last1=Perez|first1=Evan|last2=Prokupecz|first2=Shimon|last3=Brown|first3=Pamela|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/09/18/politics/paul-manafort-government-wiretapped-fisa-russians/index.html|title=Exclusive: US government wiretapped former Trump campaign chairman|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=September 18, 2017|accessdate=September 19, 2017}}</ref>
[[Special Counsel]] [[Robert Mueller]], who was appointed on May 17, 2017, by the [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] to oversee the investigation into [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]] and related matters, took over the existing criminal probe involving Manafort.<ref name="AP_Gurman_Mueller_Manafort">{{cite news |url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/ap-report-special-counsels-russia-investigation-includes-former-trump-campaign-chair/ |title=AP report: Special counsel's Russia investigation includes former Trump campaign chair |date=June 2, 2017 |access-date=June 16, 2017 |work=[[PBS]] via AP |first1=Sadie |last1=Gurman|first2=Eric |last2=Tucker |first3=Jeff |last3=Horwitz}}</ref><ref name="Time_2017_Mueller">{{cite magazine |url=http://amp.timeinc.net/time/4804010/donald-trump-investigation-robert-mueller-paul-manafort/?source=dam |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] via AP|date=June 2, 2017 |access-date=June 16, 2017 |title=Robert Mueller's Russia Investigation Takes Over Paul Manafort Case |first1=Eric |last1=Tucker |first2=Jeff |last2=Horwitz }}</ref><ref name="WaPo_SpecialCounsel_2017">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/special-counsel-is-investigating-trump-for-possible-obstruction-of-justice/2017/06/14/9ce02506-5131-11e7-b064-828ba60fbb98_story.html |title=Special counsel is investigating Trump for possible obstruction of justice, officials say |first1=Devlin|last1=Barrett |first2=Adam|last2=Entous |first3=Ellen|last3=Nakashima |first4=Sari|last4=Horwitz |work=The Washington Post |date=June 14, 2017 |accessdate=June 15, 2017}}</ref> On July 26, 2017, the day after Manafort's [[United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence]] hearing and the morning of his planned hearing before the [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary]], FBI agents at Mueller's direction conducted a raid on Manafort's [[Alexandria, Virginia]] home, using a search warrant to seize documents and other materials, in regard to the Russian meddling in the 2016 election.<ref>{{Cite new |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/fbi-conducted-predawn-raid-of-former-trump-campaign-chairman-manaforts-home/2017/08/09/5879fa9c-7c45-11e7-9d08-b79f191668ed_story.html |title=FBI conducted raid of former Trump campaign chairman Manafort's home |newspaper=The Washington Post |access-date= June 29, 2018 |first1= Carol D. |last1= Leonnig |first2= Tom |last2= Hamburger |first3= Rosalind S. |last3= Helderman|authorlink1 = Carol D. Leonnig }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/08/09/politics/paul-manafort-search-fbi-russian-interference/index.html|title=FBI raided Manafort home as part of Russia probe|last1=Diaz|first1=Daniella|last2=Perez|first2=Evan|date=August 10, 2017|publisher=CNN|accessdate=August 10, 2017}}</ref> Initial press reports indicated Mueller obtained a [[no-knock warrant]] for this raid, though Mueller's office has disputed these reports in court documents.<ref>{{cite web |last=Ma |first=Alexandra |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/robert-mueller-attacks-ny-times-washpost-for-inaccurate-reports-2018-6|title=Mueller's office attacked The New York Times and The Washington Post for 'inaccurately' reporting on his investigation |work=Business Insider |date=June 22, 2018 |accessdate=June 29, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Svab |first=Petr |url=https://www.theepochtimes.com/mueller-team-calls-out-new-york-times-washington-post-for-incorrect-stories-on-manafort_2571661.html |title=Mueller Team Calls Out New York Times, Washington Post for Incorrect Stories on Manafort |date=June 23, 2018 |work=The Epoch Times |accessdate=June 29, 2018}}</ref> ''United States v. Paul Manafort'' was analyzed by attorney [[George T. Conway III]], who wrote that it strengthened the constitutionality of the Mueller investigation.<ref>{{citation|first=George|last=Conway|authorlink=George T. Conway III|url=https://lawfareblog.com/terrible-arguments-against-constitutionality-mueller-investigation|title=Executive Power: The Terrible Arguments Against the Constitutionality of the Mueller Investigation|date=June 11, 2018|work=[[Lawfare (blog)|Lawfare]]|publisher=Published by the [[Lawfare (blog)|Lawfare Institute]] in Cooperation With the [[Brookings Institution]]|quote=In ''United States v. Manafort'', former Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort moved to dismiss the indictment against him, on the ground that the special counsel had exceeded the scope of his appointment order. The United States District Court for the District of Columbia squarely rejected this assertion}}</ref>
===Congressional investigations=== In May 2017, in response to a request of the [[United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence|Senate Select Committee on Intelligence]] (SSCI), Manafort submitted over "300 pages of documents...included drafts of speeches, calendars and notes from his time on the campaign" to the Committee "related to its investigation of Russian election meddling".<ref name="CNN_Perez_2017">{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/05/23/politics/manafort-documents-senate-intelligence/index.html |title=Manafort turns over hundreds of pages of documents to Senate intelligence |first=Evan |last=Perez |publisher=CNN|date=May 23, 2017 |access-date=June 16, 2017}}</ref> On July 25, he met privately with the committee.<ref name = Perez>{{cite news|last1=Perez|first1=Evan|title=Manafort subpoenaed by judiciary panel, met with Senate intel|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/07/25/politics/paul-manafort-senate-russia-investigation/index.html|accessdate=July 25, 2017|publisher=CNN|date=July 25, 2017}}</ref>
A [[congressional hearing]] on Russia issues, including the [[Trump campaign-Russian meeting]], was scheduled by the [[Senate Committee on the Judiciary]] for July 26, 2017. Manafort was scheduled to appear together with Trump Jr., while Kushner was to testify in a separate closed session.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jul/19/donald-trump-jr-paul-manafort-testify-congress-russia-election |title= Donald Trump Jr and Paul Manafort to testify before Congress about Russia |work= [[The Guardian]] |first= Ben |last= Jacobs |date= July 19, 2017 |accessdate= July 20, 2017}}</ref> After separate negotiations, both Manafort and Trump Jr. met with the committee on July 26 in closed session and agreed to turn over requested documents. They are expected to testify in public eventually.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2017/07/24/get-ready-jared-kushner-donald-trump-jr-manafort-head-senate/504535001/|title=Get ready: Jared Kushner, Donald Trump Jr., Manafort head to Senate|last=Kinery|first=Emma|date=July 24, 2017|work=USA Today|accessdate=August 5, 2017}}</ref>
===Private Investigation=== {{Main|Trump–Russia dossier}}
The [[Trump–Russia dossier]], also known as the Steele dossier,<ref name="Vogel_Haberman_10/27/2017">{{cite news |first=Kenneth P. |last=Vogel |authorlink= Kenneth Vogel |first2=Maggie |last2=Haberman |authorlink2= Maggie Haberman |title=Conservative Website First Funded Anti-Trump Research by Firm That Later Produced Dossier |date=October 27, 2017 |website=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/27/us/politics/trump-dossier-paul-singer.html | access-date=April 1, 2018 }}</ref> is a [[Private intelligence agency|private intelligence]] report comprising investigation memos written between June and December 2016 by [[Christopher Steele]].<ref name="Shane_Confessore_Rosenberg_1/12/2017">{{cite news | last=Shane | first=Scott | last2=Confessore | first2=Nicholas | last3=Rosenberg | first3=Matthew | title=How a Sensational, Unverified Dossier Became a Crisis for Donald Trump | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=January 12, 2017 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/11/us/politics/donald-trump-russia-intelligence.html | access-date=February 11, 2018}}</ref> Manafort is a major figure mentioned in the Trump–Russia dossier, where allegations are made about Manafort's relationships and actions toward the Trump campaign, Russia, Ukraine, and Viktor Yanukovych. The dossier claims:
* That "the Republican candidate's campaign manager, Paul MANAFORT" had "managed" the "well-developed conspiracy of co-operation between [the Trump campaign] and the Russian leadership", and that he
