{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox Magazine | title = The Ukrainian Week | image_file = Tyzhden-2008.jpg | image_size = 200px | image_caption = Ukrainskyi Tyzhden's front
cover issue 2014:5. | editor = Serhiy Lytvynenko | editor_title = Chief editor | frequency = Weekly | circulation = 41,500 weekly | category = [[Newsmagazine]] | company = TOV Ukrainskyi Tyzhden | publisher = | firstdate = {{start date and age|2007|11|2|df=yes}} | country = [[Ukraine]] | based = [[Kiev]] | language = [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]], [[English language|English]] | website = [http://tyzhden.ua// http://tyzhden.ua] (Ukrainian edition), [http://ukrainianweek.com// http://ukrainianweek.com] (English edition) | issn = 1996-1561 }} {{For|the English-language newspaper of the Ukrainian diaspora in the United States and North America with a similar name|The Ukrainian Weekly}} '''''The Ukrainian Week''''' ({{lang-uk|Український Тиждень, Тиждень.ua}}) is an illustrated weekly magazine covering politics, economics and the arts and aimed at the socially engaged Ukrainian-language reader. It provides a range of analysis, opinion, interviews, feature pieces, including travel both in Ukraine and outside, and art reviews and events calendar. ==History and profile== ''The Ukrainian Week'' is published in Ukraine by ECEM Media Ukraine GmbH (Austria)[http://tyzhden.ua/Politics/60972 Statement of the Ukrainian Week about harassment for publishing after holding the World Newspaper Forum (Заява «Українського тижня» про утиски видання після проведення Всесвітнього газетного форуму)]''. The Ukrainian Week. 27 September 2012. and was established in November 2007. the magazine is one of several Ukrainian language magazines that have appeared in Ukraine in the wake of the [[Orange Revolution]].{{cite news|url=http://www.businessukraine.com.ua/booming-magazine-market-flooded |title=Booming magazine market flooded with news weeklies |work=[[Business Ukraine]] |date=26 November 2007 |accessdate=15 September 2008 |last=Bondarchuk |first=Oksana |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070814084852/http://www.businessukraine.com.ua/booming-magazine-market-flooded |archivedate=14 August 2007 }} The English edition of ''The Ukrainian Week'' is published bi-monthly and contains a selection of articles deemed to be of most interest to non-Ukrainian readers. In 2012 it published its statement accusing the state powers and major media-holdings ''de-facto'' monopolizing the market, of harassment. ==See also== [[List of magazines in Ukraine]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://tyzhden.ua Official website] (Тиждень.ua, tyzhden.ua) *[http://ukrainianweek.com Official website] (International edition, ukrainianweek.com) {{DEFAULTSORT:Ukrainian Week}} [[Category:2007 establishments in Ukraine]] [[Category:Magazines established in 2007]] [[Category:English-language magazines]] [[Category:Ukrainian-language magazines]] [[Category:Ukrainian news magazines]] [[Category:Weekly magazines]] [[Category:Magazines published in Kiev]] {{News-mag-stub}} {{Ukraine-stub}}

{{Infobox wrestling event |image=MascaraSagrada.jpg |caption=[[Máscara Sagrada]], teamed up with [[Art Barr|Love Machine]] and [[Mascarita Sagrada]] in the sixth match of the night. |name=Triplemanía I |promotion=[[Asistencia Asesoría y Administración]] |date=April 30, 1993<ref name="Trip1">{{cite web | url = http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html#i | title = Asistencia Asesoría y Administración TripleManía | accessdate = 2009-02-19| publisher = ProWrestlingHistory.com}}</ref> |air_date=May 21, 1993 |attendance=48,000<ref name="Trip1"/> - 50,000<ref name=AAATM1/> |sponsor = [[Corona (beer)|Corona beer]] |venue=[[Plaza México|Plaza de Toros]]<ref name="Trip1"/> |city=[[Mexico City]], [[Mexico]]<ref name="Trip1"/> |liveevent=y |event=[[Triplemanía]] |lastevent2='''''First''''' |nextevent2=[[Triplemanía II-A]] }} '''Triplemanía I''' (Referred to as just "Triplemanía" the first year) was the first ever [[Triplemanía]] ''[[lucha libre]]'', or [[professional wrestling]] show promoted by [[Asistencia Asesoría y Administración]] (AAA). The show took place on April 30, 1993 in [[Mexico City]], [[Mexico]]'s [[Plaza México|Plaza de Toros]] [[bullfighting]] arena. The Main event featured a "Retirement" match between [[Konnan]] and [[Cien Caras]], where the [[Narrative thread|storyline]] was that the person that lost would have to retire from professional wrestling. The match was billed as the first time such a stipulation had ever been used in ''Lucha Libre'', while it was rare, retirement matches had happened in Mexico before that time. The semi-main event featured the zenith of the storyline feud between [[Perro Aguayo]] and [[Máscara Año 2000]] as the two fought in a ''[[Lucha de Apuestas]]'', or bet match, where Aguayo put his hair on the line and Máscara Año 2000 bet his [[wrestling mask]] on the outcome of the match.
The show was the first major show for AAA, taking place just short of a year after [[Antonio Peña]] and a number of wrestlers broke away from [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (CMLL) to establish AAA. With time the annual Triplemanía show(s) would become AAA's biggest show of the year, serving as the culmination of major storylines and feature wrestlers from all over the world competing in what has been described as AAA's version of [[WrestleMania]] or their [[Super Bowl]] event.<ref>{{cite book|author=Madigan, Dan|title=Mondo Lucha Libre: the bizarre and honorable world of wild Mexican wrestling|publisher=HarperColins Publisher|year=2007|chapter=A family affair|pages=128–132|isbn=978-0-06-085583-3}}</ref>
==Production== ===Background=== In early 1992 [[Antonio Peña]] was working as a booker and storyline writer for [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (CMLL), Mexico's largest and the world's oldest wrestling promotion, and was frustrated by CMLL's very conservative approach to ''[[lucha libre]]''. He joined forced with a number of younger, very talented wrestlers who felt like CMLL was not giving them recognition they deserved and decided to split from CMLL to create [[Asistencia Asesoría y Administración]] (AAA). After making a deal with the ''Televisa'' television network AAA held their first show in April, 1992.<ref name=SLOrbit>{{cite web | url= http://superluchas.net/2006/10/07/el-fin-de-una-era/| title= El fin de una era| date= October 7, 2006 | accessdate= October 14, 2009 | author= Ocampo, Ernesto | publisher= ''SuperLuchas'' Magazine | language=Spanish}}</ref> Peña's ideas included playing up the show aspects of wrestling, elaborate entrances, fireworks and shows that would rival those put on by the [[WWE|World Wrestling Federation]] (WWF), particularly their [[WrestleMania]] shows. Originally he wanted to hold three shows of that caliber close together, which combined with the nickname for AAA, Triple A, led to him creating the [[Triplemanía]] concept. In 1993 they only put on one Triplemanía show but in subsequent years Peña's vision for multiple Triplemanías would come true.<ref name="Trip2">{{cite web | url = http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html#ii-a | title = Asistencia Asesoría y Administración TripleManía | accessdate = July 11, 2015| publisher = ProWrestlingHistory.com}}</ref><ref name="Trip2B">{{cite web | url = http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html#ii-b | title = Asistencia Asesoría y Administración TripleManía | accessdate = July 11, 2015| publisher = ProWrestlingHistory.com}}</ref><ref name="Trip2C">{{cite web | url = http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html#ii-c | title = Asistencia Asesoría y Administración TripleManía | accessdate = July 11, 2015| publisher = ProWrestlingHistory.com}}</ref>
Peña and the AAA management staff booked the ''[[Plaza México|Plaza de Toros]]'' [[bullfighting]] arena for the first Triplemanía event, which was considered a huge financial gamble for a promotion that was not even one year old.<ref name=TripleSlam>{{cite web | url=http://slam.canoe.com/SlamWrestlingInternational/triplemania.html | title=TripleMania: Mexico's answer to WrestleMania | first=John F. | last=Molinaro | year=2000 | accessdate=June 22, 2015}}</ref> The arena could normally accommodate 41,262 spectators for bullfighting,<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.lamexico.com/historia.php |title=Historia de la Plaza México |publisher=Plaza México |accessdate=30 October 2014}}</ref> but with additional seats on the actual floor of the arena around the ring the capacity grew to over 48,000.
===Storylines=== [[Image:LaParka.jpg|thumb|left|270px|[[La Parka]] challenged for the [[Mexican National Light Heavyweight Championship]].]] The Triplemanía I event featured eight [[Professional wrestling match types|professional wrestling matches]] with different wrestlers involved in pre-existing [[Screenplay|scripted]] feuds, [[plot (narrative)|plots]] and [[narrative thread|storylines]]. Wrestlers were portrayed as either [[Heel (professional wrestling)|heels]] (referred to as ''rudos'' in Mexico, those that portray the "bad guys") or [[Face (professional wrestling)|faces]] (''técnicos'' in Mexico, the "good guy" characters) as they followed a series of tension-building events, which culminated in a wrestling match or series of matches.
{{Quote box|width=35%|align=right|quote="Whenever Konnan appears on TV, everyone stops what they are doing and focuses on whatever television that is around. Waitresses in restaurants will stop what they are doing and watch whatever program that Konnan appears on."|source=<small>Mike Tenay on Konnan's popularity during the broadcast of [[AAA When Worlds Collide]].</small><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.wwe.com/videos/konnan-vs-perro-aguayo-steel-cage-match-aaa-when-worlds-collide-nov-6-1994-26151347 | title=Konnan vs. Perro Aguayo - Steel Cage Match: AAA When Worlds Collide, Nov. 6, 1994 | publisher=[[WWE]] | accessdate=June 27, 2015}}</ref>}}
To help make the show a success Peña relied greatly on the rivalry between [[Konnan]] and [[Cien Caras]] to sell tickets. Konnan and Cien Carasa had been rivals back when both were in CMLL, in fact Konnan had defeated Cien Caras in a tournament final to become the first [[CMLL World Heavyweight Championship|CMLL World Heavyweight Champion]] and Caras had later won the title from Konnan, holding the title when they both jumped from CMLL to AAA.<ref>{{cite book |author=Royal Duncan and Gary Will |title=Wrestling Title Histories | publisher=Archeus Communications |chapter = MEXICO: EMLL CMLL Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre heavyweight Title | page = 395 |year= 2000 |isbn=0-9698161-5-4}}</ref> The two had previously wrestled each other in the main event of the [[EMLL 58th Anniversary Show]]<ref group=Note>CMLL was previously known as Empresa Mexicana de Lucha Libre but changed their name in 1991.</ref> and the rivalry was a natural one between the charismatic ''tecnico'' Konnan and the cheating ''rudo'' Cien Caras, especially when he brought his brothers [[Universo 2000]] and [[Máscara Año 2000]] to help him gain an unfair advantage during matches. With his growing popularity Konnan was offered several roles on TV and had hopes of pursuing an acting career, which led to Peña and Konnan devising the idea of a "retirement match" stipulation for the Triplemanía main event. It was billed as if it was the first time ever such a stipulation had been used in Mexico, which was more a work of marketing than fact but was a stipulation that helped sell out the ''Plaza del Toros'' stadium.<ref name=TripleMania1SL>{{cite web | url=http://superluchas.com/2009/02/20/imagenes-del-pasado-se-acercaba-el-aniversario-de-triple-a/ | title=1993: Se acercaba Triplemanía I | date=February 20, 2009 | accessdate=July 11, 2015 | work=SuperLuchas Magazine | language=Spanish | first=Sergio | last=Ssio}}</ref>
==Event== {| class=wikitable style="font-size:90%; margin: 0.5em 0 0.5em 1em; float: right; clear: right;" |+Other on-screen talent<ref name=YIR1993/> |- !Role: !Name: |- |rowspan=2|Commentators |Arturo Rivéra |- |Dr. Alfonso Morales |- |rowspan=2|Referees |Pepe Casas |- |El Tirantes |} The under-card matches were all held under "single fall" rules and not the traditional [[Professional wrestling match types#Two out of three falls match|best two-out-of-three falls]] rule that most ''lucha libre'' matches used at that point. That stipulation was saved for the championship match, the ''Apuesta'' match and the main event. Prior to the show opening Televisa commentator Arturo Rivéra showed shots from outside the ''Plaza del Toros'' where people were being turned away as the bullfighting arena was at maximum capacity. Besides the paid attendance in ''La Plaza del Toros'' an estimated 6,000 fans watched the show from the arena's parkinglot where AAA had erected giant screen televisions to accommodate the additional fan interest.<ref name=YIR1993/>
For the [[Mexican National Light Heavyweight Championship]] match between [[Lizmark]] and [[La Parka]] Lizmark had [[Super Parka|Volador]] in his corner, who was the uncle of La Parka. La Parka had Solomon Grundy in his corner for the match. The title match originally ended in a 15-minute time limit draw without either wrestler even winning a single fall. Both Lizmark and La Parka requested five more minutes, which was approved by a representative of the Mexico City boxing and wrestling Commission. During the final five minutes Lizmark is able to pin La Parka and retain the championship.<ref name=YIR1993/> The mixed ''Trios'' match that pitted [[Máscara Sagrada]], [[Art Barr|Love Machine]], and [[Mascarita Sagrada]] against [[Jerry Estrada]], [[Blue Panther]], and [[Mini Psicosis|Jerrito Estrada]] was broken down into the two main storylines; Love Machine/Blue Panther and the Sagradas against the Estradas for most of the match. In a call back to the ''Luchas de Apuestas'' match between Blue Panther and Love Machine the previous year Panther used a [[piledriver (professional wrestling)#kneeling reverse piledriver|Kneeling reverse piledriver]], a move that according to ''lucha libre'' traditions is outlawed and led to Pather's disqualification. To underscore the "lethal" nature of the move Love Machine was checked on by ringside physicians and removed from the ring on a stretcher.<ref name=YIR1993/>
During the main event cameras panned to the front row where former [[WWE|World Wrestling Federation]] (WWF, now WWE) wrestler [[Jake Roberts|Jake "The Snake" Roberts]] was seated, with the storyline explanation being that he bought a ticket to the show and was supposedly just there as a fan. During the first fall of the match Roberts kept distracting Konnan, yelling loudly and reaching out towards him as he passed by on the outside of the ring. After losing the first fall to Cien Caras Konnan got into a fight with Roberts at ringside, diverting his attention from the referee's count and failed to get back in the ring before he was counted out. Due to the count out Konnan was forced to retire and Jake Roberts immediately became one of the most hated ''rudo'' wrestlers in AAA by the end of the show.<ref name=YIR1993/>
In 2016 [[La Parka II|La Parka]] (second version) revealed that he was one of the wrestlers who worked the security detail for the first show.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://superluchas.com/2016/07/28/rumbo-a-triplemania-xxiv-grandes-sorpresas-en-el-cartel/ | title=Rumbo a Triplemanía XXIV, grandes sorpresas en el cartel | date=July 28, 2016 | accessdate=July 29, 2016 | first=Jose | last=Vaca | publisher=SuperLuchas Magazine | language=Spanish}}</ref>
==Aftermath== [[File:Eddie Guerrero on SmackDown cropped.jpg|thumb|right|220px|[[Eddy Guerrero]], became a major ''rudo'' in AAA after teaming up with [[Art Barr|Love Machine]].]] Konnan took time off from wrestling to pursue his acting career, but it did not turn out as he had expected and Konnan returned to AAA four months later. Peña and AAA used the controversial finish to the match as a storyline to explain that Konnan had petitioned the Mexico City Boxing and Wrestling Commission to reinstate his wrestling license and allow him to return.<ref name=YIR1993/> He returned to AAA and immediately continued his feud with Cien Caras as well as continue the storyline with Jake Roberts, facing and defeating both of them at AAA's ''La Revencha'' show on August 28, 1993.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=43090 | title=AAA LA Revencha | date=August 28, 1993 | accessdate=July 12, 2015 | publisher=Cagematch.net}}</ref> The storyline would expand and pit Konnan against Robers as well as his newfound allies [[Eddy Guerrero]] and Love Machine, better known as ''[[Los Gringos Locos|La Pareja del Terror]]'' ("The Terror Team") while Konnan had back up in the form of [[Blue Panther]] and [[Perro Aguayo]]. Roberts and ''La Pareja del Terror'' defeated Konnan, Aguayo and Blue Panther in the main event of ''La Lucha del Honor'' in the [[Los Angeles Sports Arena]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=43138 | title=AAA La Lucha del Honor | date=November 12, 1993 | accessdate=July 12, 2015 | publisher=Cagematch.net}}</ref> The storyline with Jake Robers culminated a year after it started at [[Triplemanía II-C]], as Konnan defeated Jake Roberts in a ''Luchas de Apuestas'' match, forcing Roberts to be shaved bald.<ref name="Trip2C"/>
The storyline between Blue Panther and Love Machine continued past Triplemanía, with the two facing off in another ''Luchas de Apuestas'' match two months after Triplemanía. During the match the previously ''tecnico'' Love Machine began to act more and more like one of the bad guys, berating his opponent during the match, pulling Panther's shoulders off the mat during pinfalls etc. In the end he intentionally and in full view of the referee Love Machine used the piledriver move on Blue Panther, drawing both the disqualification and disapproving boos from the crowd. While he was shaved bald as a result Love Machine did not seem to care, celebrating that he hurt Blue Panther. With one match AAA flipped the roles of Love Machine and Blue Panther, turning Panther ''tecnico'' out of sympathy and making Love Machine an arrogan anti-Mexican ''rudo''. In a subsequent match where Love Machine and a partner wrestled ''La Pareja Atomica'' ("The Atomic Team") of [[El Hijo del Santo]] and Eddy Guerrero, Love Machine stole El Hijo del Santo's mask, put it on and then attacked Guerrero pretending to be El Hijo del Santo. Moments later he returned the mask to El Hijo del Santo and ducked out of the ring as Guerrero came to. At this point Guerrero attacked his own partner, leaving with Love Machine after the match. Together Guerrero and Love Machine would become known as ''La Pareja del Terror'' ("The Terror Team") and formed the basis of a group known as ''[[Los Gringos Locos]]'' that became the most hated ''rudo'' team, not just in AAA but in all of Mexico at the time.<ref name=TripleSlam/><ref name=EGBook94>{{cite book | last1=Guerrero | first1=Eddie| first2=Michael | last2=Krugman | title=Cheating Death, Stealing Life: The Eddie Guerrero Story | page=94 | date=December 20, 2005 | publisher=Simon and Schuster | isbn=0-7434-9353-2}}</ref><ref name=AAAOficial>{{cite web | url=http://www.luchalibreaaa.com/historia/when-worlds-collide.html | title= El evento que comenzo la revolucion mundial | publisher=[[Asistencia Asesoría y Administración]] | accessdate=June 27, 2015 | language=Spanish}}</ref>
===Reception=== John Molinario, who writes about wrestling for the [[Canadian Online Explorer]], stated that the first Triplemanía show demonstrated that AAA "had arrived and they weren't going anywhere."<ref name=TripleSlam>{{cite web | url=http://slam.canoe.com/SlamWrestlingInternational/triplemania.html | title=TripleMania: Mexico's answer to WrestleMania | first=John F. | last=Molinaro | year=2000 | accessdate=June 22, 2015}}</ref> He also stated that it was a "stellar card" and set the standard for ''lucha libre'' from that point on.<ref name=TripleSlam/> Wrestling commentator and ''lucha libre'' expert [[Mike Tenay]] noted that "To be able to take the lion's share of the market like that so immediately sort of put AAA as a promotion on the map. Pena's own marketing plan for Mexican wrestling was so revolutionary he was on top for that era. With a promotion that was less than a year old he did a tremendous job of creating stars."<ref name=TripleSlam/>
==Results== {{Pro Wrestling results table |results=<ref name="Trip1"/><ref name=AAATM1>{{cite web | url=http://www.luchalibreaaa.com/eventos-magnos/triplemania/item/86-triplemanía-i-konnan-y-cien-caras-por-todo.html | title=Triplemanía I: Konnan y Cien Caras, por todo | accessdate=July 11, 2015 | publisher=[[Asistencia Asesoría y Administración]] | language=Spanish}}</ref><ref name=YIR1993>{{cite news|title=1993 Especial!|work=Box y Lucha Magazine|pages=2–28|id=issue 2214|date=January 7, 1994|language=Spanish}}</ref>
|match1=[[Martha Villalobos]], [[Pantera Sureña]] and Wendy defeated [[Lola Gonzales]], Vicky Caranza, and Larrosa |stip1=[[Professional wrestling tag team match types#Trios rules (Relevos Australianos)|Six-woman "Lucha Libre rules" tag team match]] |time1=
|match2=[[Abismo Negro|Winners]], [[Super Caló]], and [[Rafael Herbert Reyes|El Salsero]] defeated [[May Flowers]], Rudy Reyna, and Baby Sharon. |stip2=Six-man "Lucha Libre rules" tag team match |time2=
|dark3=yes |match3=[[Super Parka|Volador]], [[Misterioso (wrestler)|Misterioso]], and [[Rey Misterio, Jr.]] defeated ''[[Los Destructores]]'' (Tony Arce, Vulcano, and Rocco Valente) |stip3=Six-man "Lucha Libre rules" tag team match |time3=
|dark4=yes |match4=[[Octagón]], [[El Hijo del Santo]], and [[Villano III]] defeated [[Fuerza Guerrera]], [[Heavy Metal (wrestler)|Heavy Metal]], and Rambo. |stip4=Best two-out-of-three six-man "Lucha Libre rules" tag team match |time4=
|match5=[[Lizmark]] (c) (with Volador) defeated [[La Parka]] (with Solomon Grundy) |stip5=[[Professional wrestling match types#Two out of three falls match|Best two-out-of-three falls match]] for the [[Mexican National Light Heavyweight Championship]] |time5=
|match6=[[Máscara Sagrada]], [[Art Barr|Love Machine]], and [[Mascarita Sagrada]] defeated [[Jerry Estrada]], [[Blue Panther]], and [[Jerrito Estrada]] |stip6=Six-man "Lucha Libre rules" tag team match |time6=
|match7=[[Perro Aguayo]] defeated [[Máscara Año 2000]] |stip7=Best two-out-of-three falls ''[[Lucha libre#Luchas de Apuestas|Lucha de Apuestas]]'', "Hair vs. Mask" match.<ref name=TMWinners>{{cite web | url=http://superluchas.com/2009/05/29/los-grandes-ganadores-de-triplemania/ | title=Los grandes ganadores de Triplemania | first=Alex G | last=Ruiz | work=SuperLuchas Magazine | date=May 29, 2009 | accessdate=July 11, 2015 | language=Spanish}}</ref> |time7=
|match8=[[Cien Caras]] defeated [[Konnan]] * First fall: Cien Caras pinned Konnan. * Second fall: Konnan was counted out after interference from [[Jake Roberts]]. |stip8=Best two-out-of-three falls retirement match.<ref name=TMWinners/> |time8= }}

revision.text:
{{advert|date=December 2017}} {{infobox music festival |music_festival_name = White Wonderland |location = [[Anaheim, California]] |years_active = 2011-present |dates = December 31 ([[New Year's Eve]]) |founders = Insomniac Events, Giant |genre = [[Dance music]], [[Electronic dance music]] |website = {{Official website|whitewonderland.com}} }} '''White Wonderland''' is an [[electronic music]] [[music festival|festival]] co-organized by [[Insomniac Events]] and fellow club promoter Giant. The event was first held for [[New Year's Eve]] in 2011, following the announcement that Insomniac had pulled out of co-organizing the New Year's Eve festival [[Together as One (festival)|Together as One]] due to conflicts with its fellow organizer Go Ventures.
==History== From 1999 to 2011, Insomniac had partnered with Go Ventures to organize [[Together as One (festival)|Together as One]], an annual festival historically held on New Year's Eve at the [[Los Angeles Memorial Sports Arena]]. Shortly prior to the 2011 event, Insomniac founder Pasquale Rotella announced that they would no longer co-produce Together as One, due to "various issues" surrounding Go Ventures' commitments to "safety, production quality and the overall value of our fans' experience." Rotella also felt that there were conflicts between his creative visions and those of Go Ventures' Reza Gerami.<ref name=latimes-split/>
At the same time, Rotella announced that Insomniac would partner with the club promoter Giant to form a new, competing New Year's Eve event known as White Wonderland, a two-night festival which would be held at the [[Anaheim Convention Center]] on December 31, 2011 and January 1, 2012.<ref name=latimes-split>{{cite web|last=Amter|first=Charlie|title=Together as One promoters split|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/dec/23/entertainment/la-et-night-together-as-one23-20111223|work=Los Angeles Times|date=December 23, 2011}}</ref><ref name=ocr-ww>{{cite web|last=Carpenter|first=Eric|title=Up to 29,000 to attend O.C. New Year's rave|url=http://www.ocregister.com/news/event-333672-anaheim-insomniac.html|work=Orange County Register|date=December 30, 2011}}</ref> Similarly to [[Montreal]]'s [[Bal en Blanc]] festival and the [[Sensation White]] tour, the winter-themed event would require all of its attendees to wear white-colored clothing.<ref name=latimes-split/><ref name=thr-ww11/> Despite the break-up, Together as One would still be held for 2011–12, organized solely by Go Ventures.<ref name=latimes-split/> However, the following year's edition would ultimately be cancelled.<ref name=ocw-taocancelled>{{cite web|last=Jackson|first=Nate|title=Shrine Expo Hall Says Together As One Cancelled|url=http://blogs.ocweekly.com/heardmentality/2012/12/shrine_expo_hall_says_together.php|work=OC Weekly|date=December 18, 2012}}</ref>
==Editions== The inaugural 2011–12 edition of White Wonderland was a two-night event, headlined by [[Benny Benassi]], [[Dada Life]], [[Paul Van Dyk]], and [[Steve Angello]] of [[Swedish House Mafia]].<ref name=thr-ww11>{{cite web|last=Amter|first=Charlie|title=Kaskade, Swedish House Mafia's Steve Angello to Headline New Insomniac NYE Event|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/kaskade-steve-angello-white-wonderland-268252|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=December 1, 2011}}</ref> The event concluded with a total of 24,000 attendees across both nights, with Saturday night hosting a sell-out crowd of 14,000 attendees.<ref name=ocr-ww11post>{{cite web|last=Carpenter|first=Eric|title=24,000 attend Anaheim rave; 1 minor arrest|url=http://www.ocregister.com/news/year-334102-white-anaheim.html|work=Orange County Register|date=January 4, 2012}}</ref>
The 2012–13 edition would be reduced to a one-night event on New Year's Eve, and featured performances by [[Above & Beyond (band)|Above & Beyond]], [[Avicii]], [[Bingo Players]], [[Dash Berlin]], Dannic, [[Ferry Corsten]], [[Hardwell]], [[Madeon]], [[Sebastian Ingrosso]], and [[Tritonal (band)|Tritonal]].<ref name=ocw-top52013>{{cite web|last=Loera|first=Alejandra|title=The Top Five EDM Parties on New Year's Eve|url=http://blogs.ocweekly.com/heardmentality/2012/12/the_top_five_edm_nye_parties.php?page=2|work=OC Weekly|date=December 26, 2012}}</ref>
Insomniac announced the 2013-14 lineup on November 24, 2013, featuring [[ATB]], [[Congorock]], [[Cosmic Gate]], Dash Berlin, [[Laidback Luke]], and Steve Angello.<ref name=inthemix-14lineup>{{cite web|title=Insomniac reveals White Wonderland NYE line-up|url=http://inthemix.com/news/insomniac-reveals-white-wonderland-nye-line-up/12933|work=InTheMix.com|accessdate=20 December 2013}}</ref> The 2014-15 edition was headlined by [[Armin van Buuren]], Laidback Luke, [[Showtek]], and [[W&W]].<ref name=ww15-lineup>{{cite web|title=Announcing: White Wonderland 2014 Lineup|url=https://www.insomniac.com/media/announcing-white-wonderland-2014-lineup|publisher=Insomniac Events|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref>
